articles.subject: Momentum Topologies
articles.keywords: Momentum, topology, single node, combined cluster, two-tier configuration
articles.body:
Momentum Topologies

The principle components of Momentum are Platform node and Analytics nodes:
 
  • Platform nodes handle the MTA including injection and message generation, the configuration server, engagement tracking, and engagement proxy server responsibilities. They also host the distributed online transaction processing (OLTP) database and event hose.
  • Analytics nodes host the distributed analytics database and the web-based UI. Event data is loaded into the database via the event hose and is available via the web-based UI, reporting API, and jlogs for integration with external processes or systems. Analytics nodes are also responsible for the API proxy server, which handles both message and reporting APIs.




You can configure Momentum in five topologies: Single Node, Combined Cluster, or Two-Tier, 3P + 1A and MTA only (no analytics). Each topology can be run on a local cluster or on an Amazon Web Services (AWS) cluster.
 

Topologies

Single Node

Local

AWS

Combined Cluster

Local

AWS

Two-Tier Configuration

Local

AWS
3P + 1A Local
AWS
MTA only Local
AWS


A Single Node topology deploys to a single server supporting all Momentum functionality. It is designed to support development and other non-production roles. It should not be used for performance testing or production due to its lack of redundancy.

A Combined Cluster topology consists of at least three Platform and Analytics nodes installed onto the same physical node and running all roles. 

A baseline Two-Tier Configuration consists of a three-node Platform cluster and a three-node Analytics cluster. You can scale this configuration by adding nodes to the Platform cluster independently of the Analytics cluster. Both Platform and Analytics nodes contain multiple roles within the cluster:
  • Platform includes Cassandra, Momentum, and Engagement Tracking
  • Analytics includes Vertica, API services, and WebUI

A 3P + 1A consists of 3 Combined Nodes and 1 Vertica Node. Once created the Platform nodes in theory can be extended. Unfortunately, extending the analytics nodes becomes a lot more complex and generally is not recommended. Both Platform and Analytics nodes contain multiple roles within the cluster:
  • Platform includes Cassandra, Momentum, Engagement Tracking, API services and WebUI
  • Analytics in this scenario only includes Vertica.

MTA only install, this consists of no Analytics, no webhooks, no message generation, along with the log aggregator this particular setup parallels most closely the previous versions on premise solution (a 3.x cluster). This does mean that most of the services that run by default on a 4.x environment will not be running on this.

articles.subject: Hardware Considerations - Introduction
articles.keywords: hardware, configuration, deployment, production environment
articles.body:
Hardware Considerations
Hardware Considerations - Introduction


Table of Contents

 
  • Server and Hardware Configuration Considerations
  • Hardware Deployment Configuration
  • Production Environment Configurations


The Momentum platform is designed to deliver high volumes of messaging traffic. This is accomplished through architecture that can be scaled vertically on all nodes and horizontally by adding nodes. When planning a Momentum deployment, you must understand both the physical hardware and the deployment environment.

These articles will help you determine the best deployment for the volumes you need to support, as well as the correct hardware for your current configuration and for expected growth.

articles.subject: Server and Hardware Configuration Considerations
articles.keywords: Server Roles, Configuration Options, Hardware Scaling Approach, Environmental Considerations
articles.body:
Hardware Considerations
Server and Hardware Configuration Considerations

Table of Contents
 

  • Server Roles
  • Configuration Options
  • Hardware Scaling Approach
  • Environmental Considerations
  • Additional Configuration Notes
 

Server Roles

Momentum is deployed as several distinct “roles”, each providing different functionality of the Momentum Solution. The available roles are:

 

  • Platform Role

    • MTA - Supports all Message delivery functionality including Adaptive Delivery. Optionally, also supports Message Generation.

    • Platform DB - Stores all templates, recipient lists, and generation task data.

    • Event Hose – Distributes all system events to the Analytics node and Webhook subscriptions.
       

  • Analytics Role

    • Analytics DB – Stores aggregated data of all system events delivered by the event hose.

    • Web User Interface – Provides graphical reporting summaries, template editing and management, recipient list storage management, and authentication key generation and management.

    • HTTP Proxy Service - Supports all REST API including message generation, administration, and metrics (reporting) functions.

 
You do not need to install all roles. Also, some sub-roles can be deployed on separate nodes. Listing all possible permutations is not feasible. Please consult with a Momentum Product Manager for more information on highly distributed deployments.
 

Configuration Options

Momentum enables you to create standardized cluster configurations with hardware specifications appropriate for different levels of messaging capacity. You can deploy Momentum in multiple configurations to meet specific performance and operational requirements. Consult with your Message Systems account team to address requirements not covered here.



 

Hardware Scaling Approach

Although you can deploy hardware capable of processing over five million messages per hour, it is not cost effective to do so if that volume level is not required. This section will provide guidance on deploying the appropriate level of hardware resources to support different volume levels.

Environmental Considerations

Momentum can send very high volumes of traffic; however, it can be constrained by external systems in the deployment environment, such as network throughput. You should consider the impact of Momentum traffic volumes on your environment.

 

External Network Bandwidth

You must consider the total bandwidth required to support your traffic volumes. A single node can readily saturate a one Gbps Network Interface Card (NIC). This is accounted for in the configurations specified below. It is also important to consider the total volumes of the entire cluster. It is possible to saturate a one Gbps network. It should also be noted that larger message sizes saturate available network bandwidth more quickly than smaller message sizes. Depending upon your expected message size, this can be an extremely important consideration when calculating rough estimates of required network bandwidth.

 

Firewall

Momentum’s queuing architecture allows delivery over hundreds or even thousands of parallel connections. Furthermore, Adaptive delivery rules allow for multiple parallel connections to receiving ISPs. Momentum takes full advantage of parallel connections to maximize delivery throughput. Firewalls need to support high connection volumes and bandwidth requirement of the total volume. Additionally, the firewall should not be stateful as firewalls are not able to keep up with the session management.

 
Internal Network Bandwidth

When sending transactional or SMTP traffic into Momentum, the injection network must match the bandwidth of the external network.

 

Additional Configuration Notes

 
File System

Momentum writes a copy of every message to the spool disk to assure no loss of messages. Sending at high volumes requires sufficient disk IOP capacity, particularly for the spool disk. Message Systems recommends the use of ext4 file systems. You can also use SANs or network attached file systems; however, these storage options introduce additional network IO and latency that can degrade performance. Make sure you account for this additional network traffic or consider a separate network for the storage components.

 
Memory Speed

Momentum is a memory and CPU intensive application. For optimal performance, the system memory must operate at 1866 MHz or faster.

 
Network Interface

Ensure that you are running on a kernel that is 2.6.18-194 or newer. This will help you avoid bugs that were found in previous Linux kernels related to Broadcom NICs. Also, if you build custom kernels, review RedHat bug numbers 587799 and 581148 for more information.

 
noatime

Momentum does not require the creation, modification or access times on either the data or metadata files to be correct (or maintained). So mounting a volume with the noatime mount option will greatly reduce the number of unnecessary disk accesses. The spool array should be formatted using either the ext2 or ext4 file system. ext2 and ext4 have comparable performance, with ext4 being considered more reliable (because of journaling). ext3 can slow down performance, so is not recommended. Set the following options in your fstab:

 

ext2:

  
LABEL=/var/spool/ecelerity /var/spool/ecelerity ext2 rw,noatime 0 2
 

ext4:

  
LABEL=/var/spool/ecelerity /var/spool/ecelerity ext4 rw,noatime,barrier=0 0 2
 
 
RAID

RAID Arrays should be configured only in RAID1 or RAID10 configurations. The Momentum software maintains a very high write load that is not suitable for a RAID5 array; therefore, RAID5 is not supported.

 
Virtualization

Momentum performance testing is executed on physical (non-virtualized) servers. If you run Momentum in Amazon Web Services (AWS) or OpenStack environments, or in other common virtualized environments such as VMware, you should plan for a potential loss of 20% - 30% in performance.

 
  Introduction Next Article

articles.subject: Momentum is Running Out of File Handles
articles.keywords: File handles,
articles.body:
Momentum is Running Out of File Handles

A file handle identifies the file in various function calls. It is associated with an open file until either the process terminates or the handle is closed. If you find that your box is running out of file handles, add the following line to /etc/sysctl.conf: 
fs.file-max = 250000
Then either execute the following command or reboot the box: 
sysctl -p

articles.subject: After upgrading to 4.1, we see "fbl: Header must be in JSON format since Momo 4.1. error: unexpected character" in paniclog.ec
articles.keywords: JSON, paniclog.ec , fbl, momentum, 4.x, format, X-MSFBL, header
articles.body:
After upgrading to 4.1, we see "fbl: Header must be in JSON format since Momo 4.1. error: unexpected character" in paniclog.ec

If you recently upgraded to Momentum 4.1 or later, you may notice an influx of the following message in your /var/log/ecelerity/paniclog.ec:
 
fbl: Header must be in JSON format since Momo 4.1. error: unexpected character

This log entry will be written each time your new >4.1 system receives an incoming FBL message that contains the legacy X-MSFBL header. Please note that this error does not mean the message was not properly processed. The FBL module is backwards compatible and will still read and process legacy X-MSFBL headers. You can confirm this is the case using the fbllog.ec and rejectlog.ec.

Unfortunately, if for any case you decide to downgrade from 4.1+ to something earlier, the earlier versions will not be able to read the JSON format X-MSFBL header.

articles.subject: Authentication failed at /opt/msys/3rdParty/lib/perl5/vendor_perl/5.16.3/Expect.pm line 760. Unable to commit changes.
articles.keywords: perl5, Expect.pm, SVN, authentication, failed, bootstrap, syntax, 3.x, momentum
articles.body:
"Authentication failed at /opt/msys/3rdParty/lib/perl5/vendor_perl/5.16.3/Expect.pm line 760.
Unable to commit changes."


If you see the this error when trying to commit to the SVN repo:

ERROR: Authentication failed at /opt/msys/3rdParty/lib/perl5/vendor_perl/5.16.3/Expect.pm line 760.
Unable to commit changes. If the configuration is out of date, please run "eccfg pull" to refresh it.
If unresolved conflicts remain, please edit the files manually to remove the conflicts and run "eccfg resolve"
then you may need to check the following items.
  • The credentials needed to commit are your admin username and password for Momentum. Please double-check your password.
  • Something may be wrong with the syntax in ecelerity.conf. Run /opt/msys/ecelerity/bin/ec_console shim:// to check and fix if applicable. 
  • If your node is having issues pulling the config from the manager, bootstrapping may be the best way to go. Please see this article for more information on bootstrapping: https://help.messagesystems.com/link/portal/30069/30093/Article/9/How-do-I-bootstrap-a-clean-version-of-the-repository-in-Momentum-3-x

articles.subject: Configuration Invalid or not Working Although Seemingly Correct
articles.keywords: Linux, Configuration, shim, config_shim_wrapper, paniclog.ec, non, linux, invalid, config
articles.body:
Configuration invalid or not working although seemingly correct
 
First step in verifying that your config is valid is to use the following command considering :
  • If ecelerity is running: /opt/msys/ecelerity/bin/ec_console shim://

    (If this gets to the password prompt, then the syntax of the configuration and lua is good, ctrl c will break out of the console)
     
  • If ecelerity is not running: opt/msys/ecelerity/bin/config_shim_wrapper

    (If you get to this entry "auth_state=0 user=(null)" then the syntax of the config and lua is good, ctrl c will break out of this).

From here any issues with configuration could be as simple as invalid characters in the configuration, any files that were edited in a non linux environment will need to be opened in a text editor and copy and pasted into a linux file.

If this fails, then reviewing the /var/log/ecelerity/paniclog.ec would be advisable, as if an upgrade has occurred in the interim between creating the conf, then it's possible that some custom modules or other aspects of the system have been moved into the core.

articles.subject: "Could not connect to service" Error When Attempting to log into Momentum 4 Web UI
articles.keywords: Cassandra, load_cluster, singlenode, log, install???????.log, Unexpected, error, schema, installer, cluster, cqlsh
articles.body:
"Could not connect to service" error when attempting to log into Momentum 4 web UI

When you attempt log into the Momentum 4 Web UI and that error is pops up, go back and check your install????????.log file (located in the directory from which you installed the Momentum bundle). There may be a few of these errors listed:

ERROR creating user: Unexpected error.
{ name: 'PoolConnectionError', 
info: 'Represents a error while trying to connect the pool, all the connections failed.', 
individualErrors:  
[ { name: 'ResponseError', 
message: 'Keyspace \'authentication\' does not exist',  info: 'Represents a error message from the server', 
code: 8704, 
isServerUnhealthy: false }, 
{ name: 'ResponseError', 
message: 'Keyspace \'authentication\' does not exist',  info: 'Represents a error message from the server',  code: 8704,  
 
.........
 
stack: 'undefined\n (event loop)\n at Client.executeAsPrepared (/opt/msys/app/users-api/node_modules/node-cassandra-cql/index.js:242:9)\n at Object.model.checkUserExists (/opt/msys/app/users-api/resources/model.js:486:10)\n at Object.<anonymous> (/opt/msys/app/users-api/etc/add_user.js:40:7)\n at Module._compile (module.js:456:26)\n at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:474:10)\n at Module.load (module.js:356:32)\n at Function.Module._load (module.js:312:12)\n at Function.Module.runMain (module.js:497:10)\n at startup (node.js:119:16)\n at node.js:902:3',
 
query: 'SELECT * FROM users WHERE username = ?' }
 
These errors indicate that the installer was unable to fully create the schema within the Cassandra data store. Here is the portion of the installer script that failed to execute:

qx|/etc/init.d/msys-cassandra start|;
my $keyspace = $selections->{'cluster'}
? 'load_cluster_keyspace.cql'
: 'load_singlenode_keyspace.cql';
qx|cd $etcdir/cql ; $thirdparty/bin/cqlsh $ipaddress -f $keyspace|;
qx|cd $appdir/users-api/cql; $thirdparty/bin/cqlsh $ipaddress -f $keyspace
qx|cd $appdir/webhooks-api/cql; $thirdparty/bin/cqlsh $ipaddress -f $keysp
qx|/etc/init.d/msys-cassandra stop|;

If you are running in a cluster, you'll want to select the load_cluster_keyspace.cql keyspace, and if you are running a single node, you'll want to select the load_singlenode_keyspace.cql keyspace. Both keyspaces are located in /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/cql/. Here is an example of actual commands to run in the command line:

/etc/init.d/msys-cassandra start cd /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/cql /opt/msys/3rdParty/bin/cqlsh <IP.of.first.Cassandra.node> -f /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/cql/load_cluster_keyspace.cql cd /opt/msys/app/users-api/cql /opt/msys/3rdParty/bin/cqlsh <IP.of.first.Cassandra.node> -f /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/cql/load_cluster_keyspace.cql cd /opt/msys/app/webhooks-api/cql /opt/msys/3rdParty/bin/cqlsh <IP.of.first.Cassandra.node> -f /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/cql/load_cluster_keyspace.cql
/etc/init.d/msys-cassandra stop
/etc/init.d/msys-cassandra start

That should recreate the schema, and you should be able to log in afterwards.

articles.subject: “Data could not be retrieved” in Momentum 4 Web UI
articles.keywords: Bindings, Campaigns, Protocols, Momentum, 4.x, could, not, load, data, summary, nodes, bindings, binding groups, protocols, vertica
articles.body:
“Data could not be retrieved” in Momentum 4 web UI
 
The following errors are present after logging into the Momentum 4 web UI:
Data could not be retrieved. Following is a list of errors:
 
  • Could not load data for binding groups.
  • Could not load data for bindings.
  • Could not load data for campaigns.
  • Unable to load summary data.
  • Could not load data for nodes.
  • Could not load data for protocols.
Example screenshot:


​
 
These errors are caused by the Vertica database not being available. For example, the service may have failed to start.
Solution: Start the Vertica database using a restart or service msys-vertica start .

articles.subject: DKIM: Implicit domain configuration disabled since no global selector and/or key format is defined.
articles.keywords: Domain, key format, DKIM, config, reload, opendkim, %s, %d
articles.body:
DKIM: Implicit domain configuration disabled since no global selector and/or key format is defined.


The following messages are commonly displayed in the /var/log/ecelerity/paniclog.ec:


DKIM: Implicit domain configuration disabled since no global selector and/or key format is defined. domainkeys: Implicit domain configuration disabled since no global selector and/or key format is defined. OpenDKIM: Implicit domain configuration disabled since no global selector and/or key format is defined.


This is an informational message, in most cases. It simply means that you are using a %s and/or %d in your DKIM/domainkeys/OpenDKIM configuration to find selector/keys dynamically based on the domain name.

These entries will usually show up in the paniclog.ec upon startup or "config reload", so it can be used as a bookmark when looking through logs.

articles.subject: ecconfigd process fails to start due to "YAML::XS::Load Error"
articles.keywords: PIDS, ecelerity, ecconfigd, error, stop, admin_setting
articles.body:
ecconfigd process fails to start due to "YAML::XS::Load Error"

In the situation where the ecconfigd process fails to start, you'll first want to attempt to run the binary in debug mode via:

/opt/msys/ecelerity/sbin/ecconfigd -d

When doing so, this attempts to start the service in the foreground, and provides details as to what happens during this process. Occasionally we receive reports of the following output:

[root@msystest ~]# /opt/msys/ecelerity/sbin/ecconfigd -d
YAML::XS::Load Error: The problem:
control characters are not allowed
was found at document: 0
Killed

This is due to a bad cache file with invalid characters in it. To resolve the issue, perform the following steps:
  1. Perform a /etc/init.d/ecconfigd stop 
  2. Verify all PIDS are killed that are ecconfigd or httpd using the ecconfigd.conf file 
  3. Delete this cache file: /var/ecconfigd/admin_setting
  4. Then  start /etc/init.d/ecconfigd start again
After doing so, you should have no issues starting ecconfigd.

articles.subject: Ecelerity Fails to Start
articles.keywords: Ecelerity, ecelerity.conf, unable, start, re-install, failed
articles.body:
Ecelerity Fails to Start


If Ecelerity fails to start with the following string of errors, you will need to uninstall and reinstall with the recommended steps. For Momentum 3.x versions please refer to the KB articles and for 4.x versions please search "momentum uninstall" in the Momentum 4 Reference Manual and you should see "7.9. Uninstalling Momentum 4" in the search results. 

[root@ec8-momentum etc]# /sbin/service ecelerity start
Pulling latest config files from repo
service password not defined (please re-install)
Running startup includes (if any)
Starting Ecelerity: failed
Testing dynamic module licensing.
[Tue 09 Jun 2015 10:44:49] <(nil)> CFG-08214 Syntax error in /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/ecelerity.conf at end of input
Failed to parse configuration file '/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/ecelerity.conf'
Global configuration error, can't validate license.

articles.subject: Graphs not showing up in the Web UI for 3.x versions of Momentum
articles.keywords: ec_rt_stats, rollup, var, log, ecelerity, chmod, chown, mainlog, rejectlog, bouncelog, ecwebui, momentum, 3.x, var, tmp, webconsole, webui, graphs
articles.body:
Graphs not showing up in the Web UI for 3.x versions of Momentum.

Issue:
Steps to Resolve:
  1. Ensure that the Ec_rt_stats is not stuck in memory on any of the nodes, run a ps aux | grep ec_rt_stats2
  2. Ensure that the Rollup is not stuck in memory on any of the nodes, run a ps aux | grep rollup
  3. Verify that the ownership of the /var/log/ecelerity directory on the manager is set to root:ecuser or possibly ecuser:ecuser.
  4. Verify that the mods on the directory are minimum of 775
  1. Verify Ec_rt_stats2 is pushing changes up to the rlogs tables in the Postgres database. Best way to test this is to run the following command on each node:

       /opt/msys/ecelerity/bin/ec_rt_stats2 -v 

    on each node of the cluster, if the results are

    Not enough data in window for mainlog
    System health updated.

    Then the ec_rt_stats2 are up to date and healthy.
  2. Verify the Rollup is executing on the manager and massaging data across all the of rtlog_ tables in Postgres. To do this check the following:

    /opt/msys/ecwebui/scripts/rollup -v

    If all the entries come back with "incomplete window ... deferring" or "no data .... skipping" then rollup is in a good state and the system from this perspective is healthy.
  3. The only other thing that can cause an issue is the server cache, which you can clear out by doing the following commands:

         rm -rf /var/tmp/webconsole
         rm sess*

    This will clear out the server cache and disconnect anyone currently connected to the server. In theory at the same time you should clear your local browser cache to ensure that there is nothing in the local browser causing an issue either.
  4. If you continue to see issues with a particular cron'd job on either the manager on the node you can change the log output of the cron from /dev/null to a log location of your preference (ie. /var/tmp/rollup.log or /var/tmp/ec_rt_stats.log) this may give you an idea of why the issue is occurring. You can also login as the ecuser and attempt to run the process as this user, via the -v commands listed above.

articles.subject: My singlenode from constantly creating ecconfigd trace files:
articles.keywords: singlenode, ecconfigd, gimli, watchdog, interval, ecelerity
articles.body:
It is a known issue that singlenode systems may cause the watchdog to trigger, and restart Momentum every 60 second interval. The steps to fixing this are very simple:
  1. Open "/etc/init.d/ecconfigd" in the text editor of your choosing.
  2. At the beginning of the file, you will want to place the following environment variable: $ENV{GIMLI_WATCHDOG_INTERVAL} = 300;
  3. Restart ecelerity
After that, you should no longer be seeing the traces building up for this issue.

articles.subject: Transient failures with reason "403 4.7.0 encryption too weak 0 less than 128"
articles.keywords: tls, encryption, transient, failures, mainlog.ec
articles.body:
I am seeing transient failures 

I am seeing transient failures (@T@) with the reason "403 4.7.0 encryption too weak 0 less than 128" on the mainlog.ec. What does that mean?
 
That means the remote mailserver requires TLS encryption otherwise it won't be able to accept messages.
 
More information on: https://support.messagesystems.com/docs/web-ref/conf.ref.tls.php

articles.subject: If we do not have analytics nodes installed, /var/log fills up with a large event_hydrant.rt file. How can we prevent this?
articles.keywords: event, hydrant, collector, delete. jlog
articles.body:
If we do not have analytics nodes installed, /var/log fills up with a large event_hydrant.rt file. How can we prevent this?

In this issue, the /var/log partition fills up due to event_hydrant.rt growing to a very large size. This is due to the fact that analytics nodes are not consuming this jlog. Here is the procedure which should correct this issue, both now (freeing up all that space) and in the future (preventing this issue from happening again).

1) Modify the configuration. In ecelerity.conf, delete the following two stanzas:

# Journal Event Hose data
event_hydrant "event_collector" {
}

event_hose "momentum_metrics" {
}

Commit the configuration. This step will only need to be done once, of course, as restarting the nodes will make them pull the new configuration.

On each platform node that has a large event_hydrant.rt file (probably all of them):

2) If you can restart Momentum, do so ("service ecelerity stop" then "service ecelerity start"). If a restart would impact operations too much, a "config reload" in ec_console should work.

3) Delete the /var/log/ecelerity/event_hydrant.rt file on the node.

articles.subject: Messages are being placed into a #mmove queue and not being delivered.
articles.keywords: clustering, msgc, cluster, fqdn, host, smtp, trace, #mmove, mmove, mailq, delivery, no, clustermetadata, go-ahead
articles.body:
Messages are being placed into a #mmove queue and not being delivered.

Symptoms
 
451 4.7.5 [internal] no clustermetadata go-ahead
 
 
 
When injecting messages that should be #mmoved to another node in the cluster you get this in the mainlog:
 
...@451 4.7.5 [internal] no clustermetadata go-ahead
 
 
Looking in the console, the queues are stacking up
 
ec_console /tmp/2025> "mailq"
Group/Binding Domain AQ DQ
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
default/#mmove binding-a-a(cluster) 0 953
default/#mmove binding-a-b(cluster) 0 894
 
 
Identification
 
The SMTP trace (ec_console> trace smtp add #mmove #cluster#binding-name /tmp/smtp_trace.txt) resulted in the following:
 
421 esmtp: protocol deviation\r\n
1393526350:(172.16.137.103)[]>>> QUIT\r\n
1393526350:(172.16.137.103)[B6/E1-06876-E468F035]<<< 220 2.0.0 momo1 ESMTP ecelerity 3.6.0.39694 r(Platform:3.6.0.0) Thu, 27 Feb 2014 13:39:10 -0500\r\n
1393526350:(172.16.137.103)[B6/E1-06876-E468F035]>>> EHLO momo1\r\n
1393526350:(172.16.137.103)[B6/E1-06876-E468F035]<<< 250-momo1 says EHLO to 172.16.137.103:62950
250-8BITMIME
250-PIPELINING
250 XCLUSTERMETADATA  V=1 SIZE\r\n
1393526350:(172.16.137.103)[B6/E1-06876-E468F035]>>> MAIL FROM:<root@momo1>\r\n
1393526350:(172.16.137.103)[B6/E1-06876-E468F035]<<< 250 2.0.0 MAIL FROM accepted\r\n
1393526350:(172.16.137.103)[B6/E1-06876-E468F035]>>> RCPT TO:<LucaWawn@spambob.com>\r\n
1393526350:(172.16.137.103)[B6/E1-06876-E468F035]<<< 250 2.0.0 RCPT TO accepted\r\n
1393526350:(172.16.137.103)[B6/E1-06876-E468F035]>>> XCLUSTERMETADATA V=1 SIZE=128\r\n
1393526350:(172.16.137.103)[B6/E1-06876-E468F035]<<* 451 You are me, please requeue
421 esmtp: protocol deviation\r\n
1393526350:(172.16.137.103)[]>>> QUIT\r\n
 
 
Note particularly these three lines, which reflect that Momentum is actually connecting to itself to try to #mmove the message:
 
1393526350:(172.16.137.103)[B6/E1-06876-E468F035]<<< 220 2.0.0 momo1 ESMTP ecelerity 3.6.0.39694 r(Platform:3.6.0.0) Thu, 27 Feb 2014 13:39:10 -0500\r\n
1393526350:(172.16.137.103)[B6/E1-06876-E468F035]>>> EHLO momo1\r\n
1393526350:(172.16.137.103)[B6/E1-06876-E468F035]<<< 250-momo1 says EHLO to 172.16.137.103:62950
 
 
This is further echoed in the specific error at the end:
 
1393526350:(172.16.137.103)[B6/E1-06876-E468F035]<<* 451 You are me, please requeue
Cause
 
There are a few reasons this could happen, but the primary cause behind all of them is confusion about who is who within the cluster, and most of the time this will be oriented around either the hostname of the server, the hosts file, or DNS depending on how the environment. 
 
Solution
 
The key here is to ensure that all nodes have the same understanding of the names of all nodes participating in the cluster.  While hosts files don't have to be exactly alike, they do need to contain the same data.  Sometimes this may even appear to be the case, but if momentum was started before the name resolution was correct, the cluster may still be confused.  Making sure that any hard-coded names in the configuration are correct, and that the /etc/hosts were identical on each of the MTA's, and then completely stopping and restarting momentum across all nodes in the cluster should resolve the issue.

articles.subject: Momentum 4 login screen does nothing when you attempt to log in.
articles.keywords: login, screen, momentum 4.x, FQDN, etc, hosts
articles.body:
Momentum 4 login screen does nothing when you attempt to log in

This is a difficult issue to identify because there is no error message. The login screen will simply not respond when you enter your credentials and submit.

This is because the login screen is built on node.js and runs client side. So if you installed momentum using short names instead of fully qualified domain names (FQDN) that are resolvable, your local desktop computer needs to be able to resolve those hostnames. You can see the http request for the shortname in your browser Developer Tools.

It is easily fixed, you just need to make entries into your local /etc/hosts file (OSX, Linux) or C:\Windows\System32\Drivers\etc\hosts (Windows) mapping the hostname to the applicable IP address.
No need to restart services, or flush cache, or restart browser (usually).

articles.subject: Momentum accepting messages and host not on relay_hosts?
articles.keywords: RCPT, domain,relay, hosts, bounce, domains
articles.body:
Momentum accepting messages and host not on relay_hosts?

First thing to check would be the relay_hosts stanza has the correct IP and if there is not an include on the configuration which contains other relay_hosts stanza.
That said, what happens is that people get confused when they try to send a test message to the box in question and when they issue a MAIL FROM: the message is accepted, like this:
 
ehlo loca
250-momentum says EHLO to x.x.x.x:yyyy
250-PIPELINING
250-ENHANCEDSTATUSCODES
250 8BITMIME
mail from: test@example.com
250 2.0.0 MAIL FROM accepted
 
So even after checking your entire configuration, you believe your box is an open relay due to that. 
You need to check your bounce_domains configuration. If you have a domain (or some domains) configured, it means a MAIL FROM: from any domain will always be accepted (allowing inbound bounces). That does not mean you have an open relay; if the domain used on the RCPT TO: is not the same configured on the bounce_domains configuration, the message will be dropped. If it is, it will allow the message to go through the system to be processed.
 
Example.com configured on bounce_domains:
 
ehlo loca
250-momentum says EHLO to x.x.x.x:yyyy
250-PIPELINING
250-ENHANCEDSTATUSCODES
250 8BITMIME
mail from: test@xyz.com
250 2.0.0 MAIL FROM accepted
rcpt to: test@example.com
250 2.0.0 RCPT TO accepted
 
If you try the RCPT TO: to a different domain (trying to use it as an open relay and not configured on bounce_domains), you will get:
 
ehlo loca
250-momentum says EHLO to x.x.x.x:yyyy
250-ENHANCEDSTATUSCODES
250-PIPELINING
250 8BITMIME
mail from: test@xyz.com
250 2.0.0 MAIL FROM accepted
rcpt to: test@test.com
550 5.7.1 relaying denied

articles.subject: No valid hosts message on a domain with 5 MXs. First 3 MXs are unreachable but just the last 2 MXs are never contacted. Why?
articles.keywords: host, failure, retry, mx, domain
articles.body:
No valid hosts message on a domain with 5 MXs. First 3 MXs are unreachable but just the last 2 MXs are never contacted. Why?

This scenario will only occur when a domain that is being sent to has a priority on their mx's in the

gmail.com.   MX  10  gmail-smtp-in.1.google.com
gmail.com.   MX  20  gmail-smtp-in.2.google.com
gmail.com.   MX  30  gmail-smtp-in.3.google.com
gmail.com.   MX  40  gmail-smtp-in.4.google.com
gmail.com.   MX  50  gmail-smtp-in.5.google.com

The host_failure_retry option ( default is 120 seconds) is how long a host is considered down before Momentum can retry it. 

The MX precedence is respected on all cases.
So in this case (example.com) we have:
  
MX 10
MX 20
MX 30
MX 40
MX 50

The fundamental issue here is that each mx is given a 120 second time out

1. Query first mx and it times out after 120 secs (t = 0)
2. Query second MX and times out for 120 seconds (t = 119)
3. Query the third MX, which then times out at 120 seconds (t = 239)
4. Return to step 1
 
In this scenario Momentum will never connect to the last two in this case. Eventually after not making a connection, it will tempfail all mail to that domain.
Although this is quite a difficult situation to have (a domain with 5 MXs having 3 with lowest preference not reachable. 
If you increase the host_failure_retry for that domain, like this:
 
Domain example.com {
Host_failure_retry = 240
}
 
It will allow delivery to the other MXs seeing that 240 seconds is enough to try all the MXs on that particular domain.

articles.subject: Paniclog shows "event_hose: Failed login to event hose, error code -9" (Momentum 4.x)
articles.keywords: event_hose, Momentum, 4.x, error, code, -9, rabbitmqctl, rabbitmq, list_users, paniclog
articles.body:
Paniclog shows "event_hose: Failed login to event hose, error code -9" (Momentum 4.x)

The actual error you will see in the paniclog will be three lines:

1424825621:event_hose: cannot proceed, no amqp connection available after 2 retires.
1424825621:event_hose: No connection available, will write data into backup storage.
1424825624:event_hose: Failed login to event hose, error code -9

This can be caused either by a problem in the creation of the RabbitMQ administrator user during installation or upgrade, or the changing of a hostname, which requires reconfiguration of RabbitMQ. To confirm, please execute the following command:

/opt/msys/3rdParty/sbin/rabbitmqctl list_users

This should only list the "rabbitmq" user, and should not list a "guest" user
To remedy this, the Message Systems Support Team will need to execute a script on your system to recreate the administrator user and apply the appropriate permissions. Please open a support ticket with the applicable paniclog entries, along with:
  • A copy of /opt/msys/app/metrics-etl/config/default.json
  • A copy of /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf/global/msgc.conf
  • The output of "ls /var/db/rabbitmq/mnesia/"
  • A copy of /etc/hosts

articles.subject: Permission denied for relation webhook_batch_status file=/opt/msys/app/webhooks-api/resources/webhooks/controller.js, line=240
articles.keywords: webhooks, api, vertica, vertica_admin, webhook, batch, status,
articles.body:
Permission denied for relation webhook_batch_status file=/opt/msys/app/webhooks-api/resources/webhooks/controller.js, line=240

The above error can be printed in the /var/log/msys-nodejs/webhooks-api.js.log, and the full context of the error is as follows:
 
error: [June 5 2015 12:40:08 PM] [/opt/msys/app/webhooks-api/resources/webhooks/controller.js#240] - Permission denied for relation webhook_batch_status file=/opt/msys/app/webhooks-api/resources/webhooks/controller.js, line=240
 
This is caused by a permissions problem within the Vertica database. This can be confirmed by entering the Vertica console ("sudo /opt/vertica/bin/vsql -U vertica_dba"), and executing:
 
\dp
 
This will present a lot of output. You may notice that there are no lines that says this:
 
 vertica_api   | vertica_admin | INSERT, SELECT                                  | momo     | webhook_batch_status  vertica_admin | vertica_admin | INSERT*, SELECT*, UPDATE*, DELETE*, REFERENCES* | momo     | webhook_batch_status
 
 
You will need to grant permissions by executing the following:
 
grant select, insert on momo.webhook_batch_status to vertica_api;
 
After which, you should tail the log file again to confirm the message is no longer appearing.

articles.subject: [Solaris] Node Stuck in Maintenance Mode (License Expired)
articles.keywords: solaris, svcs, maintenance, mode, status, MAC, license, invalid, svcadm
articles.body:
[Solaris] Node Stuck in Maintenance Mode (License Expired)

If you are running Momentum on Solaris and it is unable to start due to maintenance mode, you can use the following commands to check which services are being held in maintenance mode:

svcs status | grep maintenance

Then, for the services that are in maintenance mode, run the following for the service(s) that show as being in maintenance mode:

svcs -xv status <SERVICE>

​That should give you information as to why Solaris is not letting that service start.
 
If you see the following error messages in the paniclog, you will need to renew your license. If you anything other than a MAC-based license, please make note of it when contacting Support. 
(You can look at your current license file (in /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/) and if Hardware binding: MAC: xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx ​is in the file, you have a MAC-based license.)

1430158887:Invalid license [MAC]
1430158887:License machine mismatch
1430158887:Terminating unlicensed instance.
1430158887:Please contact Message Systems to acquire a new license.
1430158887:ec_cluster: Shutting down all clustering.

(If you do not have a MAC-based license you will have to manually copy into the /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/ directory as Momentum will not automatically pull it.)
Once a valid license is in place Ecelerity can be restarted with the following commands:

svcadm disable ecelerity
svcadm enable ecelerity

articles.subject: Some examples of bounce errors their causes and how to investigate
articles.keywords: bounce, errors, investigation, bouncelog, rejections, messageid
articles.body:
Some examples of bounce errors their causes and how to investigate.

554 5.7.1 <{hash}.http://mailendo.com>: Helo command rejected: ACCESS DENIED. Your email was rejected because the sending mail server appears to be on a dynaI’m pretty sure that the error goes on to say ‘dynamic IP address’. This will be a receiver deciding that your IP is part of a dynamic range. You may need to speak to your hosts about this – and in the meantime, you should grep the bounce log (/var/log/ecelerity/bouncelog.ec) on each node to see whether you can identify the domain(s) that are generating this error.

550 5.7.1 [internal] discarded by policy This error is about messages being rejected because they’re not authorised to be accepted by your system. The numbers should match up with those on the rejections page in the UI.

500 5.5.2 unrecognized command and  550 5.7.1 ...@... Unwanted contents of the HELO command
In this case, the best approach would be to check the mainlog to see if there is/are particular domain/domains which those errors happen.
The mainlog is at /var/log/ecelerity and also contains the failures when attempting deliveries.
The mainlog format ( https://support.messagesystems.com/docs/web-momo4/log_formats.mainlog.php  ) is as follows:

1064871280@20/00-25593-945A87F3@00/00-03736-F4101B54@00/00-04532-A3456B54@D@ » postalengine.com@266@group-a@binding-a@0@0.393@10.0.0.1

The second field, in this case 20/00-25593-945A87F3, is the message ID.
You can grep those two error messages on the mainlog and it will give you the message ID for those messages. With that, you can grep the message ID and you will find all the logs pertaining to that message alone aiding on the investigation.

articles.subject: Unable to locate bindings conf in configuration search path
articles.keywords: conf, error, config path, reconfigure, failed, unable, locate
articles.body:
Unable to locate any config in configuration search path


If a client receives an error similar to the following while using Momentum 4:

Unable to locate bindings.conf in configuration search path /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf/default:/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc:/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf/global:/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf/{NODENAME}:/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf/default
fetch_roots_by_name failed while applying configuration. Consult your vendor.
Reconfigure failed.

This is more than likely due to improper folder names, or missing folders. Since Momentum 4 requires you to set up potential future nodes at installation, the most common issue may be that they simply don't have a "bindings.conf" file for a node that technically doesn't exist yet. Momentum 4 does require that there is a "bindings.conf" file exists for each node, even if there is nothing in it. If you are seeing this error, ensure the following steps have been taken:

- Is there a directory for each node in the "/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf/" directory?
- Is there a bindings.conf file in each of those directories?
- Do the folder names match the names listed for each node in msgc_server.conf?

If these steps have been followed, the errors should no longer occur.

articles.subject: UUID Mismatch errors when performing eccfg operations.
articles.keywords: eccfg, uuid, mismatch, EOF, global, repository, repo, svn, update, pull, auto
articles.body:
UUID Mismatch errors when performing eccfg operations.
 
Symptoms
 
The system throws UUID Mismatch errors for just about any operation, and may fail to properly sync configuration changes to the nodes. This results when the customer creates a "global" directory within the conf checkout separate from the actual "global" external that already exists, and it presents with this error:
svn: UUID mismatch: existing directory 'global' was checked out from a different repository
 
If you try to commit or do an "eccfg pull --auto", you get an error that looks like:
 
ERROR: premature EOF in "svn update '--config-dir'  '/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/.eccfg' '--username' 'ecuser' '--no-auth-cache'  '--non-interactive' '--trust-server-cert' '.'" svn: UUID mismatch: existing directory 'global' was checked out from a different repository 
 
at /opt/msys/lib/perl5/vendor_perl/5.10.0/Expect.pm line 870
 

This will often present at upgrade time like this:
 
Pulling latest config files from repo ERROR: premature EOF in "svn  update '--config-dir' '/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/.eccfg' '--username'  'ecuser' '--no-auth-cache' '--non-interactive' '--trust-server-cert'  '.'"
A    default/returnpath.conf
A    default/sieve-scripts
A    default/sieve-scripts/honey.siv
A    default/bindings.conf
U    default/webui-common.conf
A    default/lua-scripts
A    default/lua-scripts/binding.lua
A    default/lua-scripts/write_jlog.lua
U    default/ecelerity-cluster.conf
A    default/honey.php
U    default/ecelerity.conf
U    default/eccluster.conf
A    dkim
svn: UUID mismatch: existing directory 'global' was checked out from a different repository  
 
at /opt/msys/lib/perl5/vendor_perl/5.10.0/Expect.pm line 870
Running startup includes (if any)
Starting Ecelerity: 9401
 
If you try to bootstrap a node, you'll get an error like this:
 
 root@node2 etc]# eccfg bootstrap --clustername=default manager:2027 Username: admin Password for 'admin': 
A    /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf/default
A    /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf/default/messagescope.conf
A    /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf/default/messagescope_remediation.conf
A    /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf/default/webui-common.conf
A    /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf/default/ecelerity-cluster.conf
A    /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf/default/ecelerity.conf
A    /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf/default/mobile.conf
A    /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf/default/eccluster.conf 
U   /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf  Fetching external item into '/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf/global'
A    /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf/global/msgc_server.conf Checked out external at revision 1. 
 
Checked out revision 2.
ERROR: 
premature EOF in "svn update '--config-dir'  '/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/.eccfg' '--username' 'admin' '--no-auth-cache'  '--non-interactive' '--trust-server-cert'  '/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf'"
A    /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf/node1
A    /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf/dk
A    /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf/dk/netlog.pub
A    /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf/dk/netlog.key
A    /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf/dk/dkim.netlog.private
A    /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf/dk/dkim.twoo.private
A    /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf/dk/ecelerity.conf
A    /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf/node2
A    /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf/node3
svn: UUID mismatch: existing directory '/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf/global' was checked out from a different repository  
 
at /opt/msys/lib/perl5/vendor_perl/5.10.0/Expect.pm line 870
Identification

There are two things you can do to confirm this is the same problem.  First, you can check svn info output within the global directory. A valid config checkout should look like this:
 
[msys@node1 global]$ /opt/msys/3rdParty/bin/svn info .
Path: .
URL: https://manager:2027/config/global
Repository Root: https://manager:2027/config/global
Repository UUID: 3ff98d25-a22a-4dd3-942f-05f5fb9cce7c
Revision: 1
Node Kind: directory
Schedule: normal
Last Changed Author: ecuser
Last Changed Rev: 1 Last Changed Date: 2012-07-31 17:02:31 -0700 (Tue, 31 Jul 2012)


But if instead the global directory came from the local checkout it will look like so:
 
[msysuser@node1 global]$ /opt/msys/3rdParty/bin/svn info .
Path: .
URL: https://manager:2027/config/default/boot/global
Repository Root: https://manager:2027/config/default
Repository UUID: a24e8d04-beae-11e1-a5b3-0350646490c5
Revision: 99 Node Kind: directory Schedule: normal Last Changed Author: ecuser Last Changed Rev: 7 Last Changed Date: 2012-09-27 07:50:57 +0000 (Thu, 27 Sep 2012)
 
However, the more accurate way to verify, is to use svn ls to view the contents of the repository directly:
 
msysuser@mail09 conf]$ svn ls https://manager:2027/config/default/boot/ --username ecuser Error validating server certificate for 'https://manager:2027': 
- The certificate is not issued by a trusted authority. Use the    fingerprint to validate the certificate manually!
Certificate information: 
- Hostname: manager 
- Valid: from Wed, 19 Sep 2012 19:13:10 GMT until Thu, 19 Sep 2013 19:13:10 GMT 
- Issuer: ecconfigd server 
- Fingerprint: 8e:30:88:2d:c8:61:74:63:61:7f:41:72:a1:09:40:15:c5:e7:60:c5
(R)eject, accept (t)emporarily or accept (p)ermanently? t Authentication realm: <https://manager:2027> Ecelerity Console Password for 'ecuser': 
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
ATTENTION!  Your password for authentication realm:    <https://manager:2027> Ecelerity Console can only be stored to disk unencrypted!  You are advised to configure your system so that Subversion can store passwords encrypted, if possible.  See the documentation for details. You can avoid future appearances of this warning by setting the value of the 'store-plaintext-passwords' option to either 'yes' or 'no' in '/home/msysuser/.subversion/servers'.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Store password unencrypted (yes/no)? nop
Please type 'yes' or 'no': no
default/
dk/
dkim global/
node1/
node2/
node3/

As you can see, there is a global directory within the "boot/default" path, which is blocking the external.  If you want to see who/what/when/where you can use svn log to find out about that path like so:
 
[msysuser@mail09 conf]$ svn log https://manager:2027/config/default/boot/global  --username ecuser Authentication realm: <https://manager:2027> Ecelerity Console Password for 'ecuser': 
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
ATTENTION!  Your password for authentication realm:    <https://manager:2027> Ecelerity Console can only be stored to disk unencrypted!  You are advised to configure your system so that Subversion can store passwords encrypted, if possible.  See the documentation for details. You can avoid future appearances of this warning by setting the value of the 'store-plaintext-passwords' option to either 'yes' or 'no' in '/home/msysuser/.subversion/servers'.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Store password unencrypted (yes/no)? no
------------------------------------------------------------------------
r7 | ecuser | 2012-09-27 07:50:57 +0000 (Thu, 27 Sep 2012) | 1 line adde msgc_server.comf
------------------------------------------------------------------------

In this case we can see only one commit was done with this path which is the one that created it.  We can see who committed the change, when, etc.  
For many if not most environments, the username will probably be "admin" or "ecuser".
 
Cause

ECCFG actually consists of two repositories, the "cluster" repository and the "global" repository.  The global repository is the same across all subclusters in a given implementation, while the "cluster" level repositories are not.  (For most clients they only have the one cluster, named "default".)  When ECCFG does a checkout, it first grabs a copy of the relevant cluster's "default" node configuration along with any node-specific configs for that cluster into the conf directory, which might look something like:
 
default/ node1/ node2/ node3/

It then checks out a copy of the global repository as an external entity into this directory as well.  However, if there is a directory in the cluster config named "global" already, it wreaks all sorts of havoc on the configuration system and can make a real mess of things.  Not only do operations throw errors, but sometimes the configuration will not properly synchronize, and attempts to bootstrap the node to fix it can result in unexpected behavior.

Solution

The solution is to delete the offending directory, but this must be done by accessing the repository directly.  You cannot simply delete it from a conf checkout and commit.  Instead, first make a backup of the contents, and then delete the offending directory.
First, export the contents, replacing the URL below with the appropriate name of the manager.  This will make a copy of the directory in $HOME/global for you, just in case the client needs any of the contents.
# svn export https://manager:2027/config/default/boot/global ~/global --username ecuser
 
Second, delete this directory from the repository directly, like so:
# svn rm https://mail08.netnoc:2027/config/default/boot/global --username ecuser -m "This is blocking the global external" Authentication realm: <https://manager:2027> Ecelerity Console Password for 'ecuser':  
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
ATTENTION!  Your password for authentication realm:    <https://mail08.netnoc:2027> Ecelerity Console can only be stored to disk unencrypted!  You are advised to configure your system so that Subversion can store passwords encrypted, if possible.  See the documentation for details. You can avoid future appearances of this warning by setting the value of the 'store-plaintext-passwords' option to either 'yes' or 'no' in '/home/msysuser/.subversion/servers'.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Store password unencrypted (yes/no)? no Committed revision 100.

Then re-bootstrap the impacted mta nodes (but not the manager!).

articles.subject: Vertica error during Momentum 4x install - /var/db/vertica already exists
articles.keywords: vertica, vertica_dba, ownership, home, directory
articles.body:
Vertica error during Momentum 4x install - /var/db/vertica already exists

During a Momentum 4.x install, you receive an error. The first thing to do is check the Vertica install log. It should give you guidance towards fixing the error. It may also link to a documentation page at vertica.com which will give further information and instructions.
 

In this instance, you'll receive the following in the Vertica install log:

Fail : User's home directory is owned by some other user
Hint : Check ownership of /var/db/vertica
Help : https://my.vertica.com/docs/7.1.x/HTML/index.htm#cshid=S0270
useradd: warning: the home directory already exists.

To fix this issue, either remove the /var/db/vertica directory or set its group to vertica_dba and its user to vertica_dba. The commands do to the latter are:

groupadd verticadba
useradd -g verticadba vertica_dba
chown -R vertica_dba:verticadba /var/db/vertica
usermod -d /var/db/vertica vertica_dba

articles.subject: What do I do if I get "Too many open files. nropen too low" on the paniclog?
articles.body:
What do I do if I get "Too many open files. nropen too low" on the paniclog?

Momentum will automatically attempt to ensure that it can open enough file descriptors to handle all the socket connections and mail traffic it needs, but this ability is capped by an overall kernel parameter.

Recommended settings in /etc/sysctl.conf are to allocate 4 to 5 times as many file descriptors as you will allow Momentum to have open connections, and to raise the system wide file descriptor limit to twice that.

So, if you have Momentum's Server_Max_Outbound_Connections set to 50000, you would want the following tunings:
 
fs.file-max = 250000

also modify the default entry in ecelerity.conf for the following setting:

Server_Max_File_Descriptors = 80000

increase this to the similar number to the number that you made the fs.file-max value

articles.subject: Why does Momentum fail to start (jlog error in paniclog.ec)?
articles.keywords: Momentum, ecelerity, paniclog.ec, debug, mode,
articles.body:
Why does Momentum fail to start (jlog error in paniclog.ec)?

When starting momentum, if it fails you won't always get output to explain why.  It can look something like this:

# /etc/init.d/ecelerity start
Pulling latest config files from repo
Running startup includes (if any)
Starting Ecelerity: failed

The first place to look in this scenario is /var/log/ecelerity/paniclog.ec.  This should have some sort of error message to indicate why the system failed.  However, sometimes there is nothing there, it all depends on where in the startup process the failure happened.  

In those situations, we can gain some insight by running Ecelerity in debug mode like so:

sudo /opt/msys/ecelerity/sbin/run.ecelerity -d

The first part of the output will mostly be the configuration data as it gets parsed.  In some rare cases the error will show up here, but typically it will show up at the end of the output.  For example, you might see something like this:

[<timestamp>] JLOG-1073 error: 20 (JLOG_ERR_META_OPEN) errno: 17 (File exists)
[<timestamp>] cluster logger file error: jlog[jlog:///var/log/ecelerity/mainlog.rt=>ec_rt_stats] 20
[<timestamp>] Cannot open mainlog jlog:///var/log/ecelerity/mainlog.rt=>ec_rt_stats (File exists).  Check that the configured directory exists and is writable.
[<timestamp>] ec_logger: failed to open log files
[<timestamp>] Module 'ec_logger' instance 'ec_logger_rt' post-init failed. Consult your vendor.
[<timestamp>] ec_cluster: Shutting down all clustering.

Clearly the problem in this case is the mainlog.rt jlog - which either has a problem of incorrect permissions or has become corrupted and needs to be deleted so Momentum can recreate it.  The actual problem will vary, but if the output doesn't make sense to you, it will save you time when contacting support in getting to the answer if you can provide it to us in the initial ticket.

articles.subject: Basic Momentum Log Errors
articles.body:
List of Basic Log errors and their cause :


Entries in Mainlog.ec

  • 421 Command timeout, closing transmission channel  
    • Internal timeout.
  • 421 4.4.0 [internal] no MXs for this domain could be reached at this time
    • This could be due to invalid address or domain, or possibly that DNS has invalid information/or is not responding
  • 451 Timeout waiting for client input
    • This usually is caused by the client inputting information too slowly
  • 451 4.4.2 [internal] connection closed by remote host
    • Kind of self explanatory but this could be caused by such things as dynamic blocks.
    • This can also occur if we are sending too many messages per connection.
  • 451 Can't connect to <Domain> - psmtp
    • This message is pretty self explanatory.
  • 451 4.4.2 [internal] no RSET response
    • MTA got no response when was expecting an RSET. This can also be triggered if the number of mailings per connection are too high
  • 451 4.4.2 [internal] no BODY response
    • This is often a precursor for issues where the remote has not acknowledged the msg before we timeout.
  • 451 4.4.2 [internal] exceed allocated time for phase
    • That happens when the connection is terminated for some reason on the network or client end
  • 450 4.4.1 [internal] Connection Timed Out
    • Could be caused by attempting to send too many messages per connection to remote host, exceeding their expectations.
  • 450 4.1.8 <address@domain.com>: Sender address rejected: Domain not found
    • This is fairly self explanatory.
  • 450 4.7.1 <address@domain.comoc@sparkron.dk>: Recipient address rejected: Your email is not rejected, only delayed
    • This is a Transient Bounce telling us the server is busy.
  • 550 <Domain@MX>... User unknown to Lyris ListManager
    • Receiver is using Lyris and the user is unknown. - mailing that has injections from BOTH Milo AND Lyris ... the bounces are gateway'ed to Lyris therefore, all bounces with Lyris verps are accepted by Lyris all bounces with Milo verps are rejected by Lyris as (user Unknown)
  • 554 5.4.7 [internal] exceeded max time without delivery
    • Mail timed out without being accepted by the remote mta.
  • 552 5.3.4 message size limit exceeded - triggered by :
    • if either "MAIL FROM" or "RCPT TO" command line exceeds 4096 bytes, or
    • if the message body length exceeds configured max_message_size or 2 gigabytes.


Entries in Paniclog.ec

  • "(%Date%)[serious] failed to open:"
    • cause is an ec_log_file entry in ecelerity.conf that is trying to write to an empty filename ie "".
  • DKIM: Implicit domain configuration disabled since no global selector and/or key format is defined.
    • This is saying that there are multiple DKIM signatures being used on this MTA since there isn't a global setting.
  • domainkeys: Implicit domain configuration disabled since no global selector and/or key format is defined.
    • This is saying that there are multiple DKIM signatures being used on this MTA since there isn't a global setting.
  • System in safe mode and spooling contract not satisfied. 
    • Unsafe spool is instantiated and suppress spool is probably in place in the ecelerity.conf, we strongly do not recommend using this.
  • IO_System module didn't fulfill contract. 
    • Unsafe spool is instantiated and suppress spool is probably in place in the ecelerity.conf, we strongly do not recommend using this
  • ec_cluster: cannot open reader manager on /var/log/ecelerity/acctlog.cluster
    • This is usually related to missing cluster logging modules in the ecelerity-cluster.conf.
    • This often appears in the paniclog while starting Ecelerity, due a race condition that eventually clears. Unless it's being repeated constantly, it can be safely ignored.


Entries in Bouncelog.ec

  • 450 temporary failure - please try later [atac]
    • This message appears to be telling us that there was an issue with the connection.
  • 450 4.7.1 <address@domain.com>: Recipient address rejected: Your email is not rejected, only delayed
    • This is a Transient Bounce telling us the server is busy.
  • 550 [internal] [oob] The response text could not be identified.  
    • Usually indicative that the bounce message could not be identified by the bounce identifier.

articles.subject: How do I collect information for a performance-related issue?
articles.keywords: ecelerity, ec_ctl, ulimit -c, sysctl, gstack, iostat,  core dump, ec_console, debugging mode, cache list all, memory, events, threads, mailq, show, inbound, outbound
articles.body:
Collect information for a performance-related issue?

When escalating performance issues, it is often required to perform some metrics in your environment while the performance degradation is occurring. This data will allow our support and engineering teams to determine and pinpoint where a given problem stems from. In this article, we're going to discuss the tools we primarily use for troubleshooting performance issues.

1) gstack

We will often utilize 'gstacks' to take snapshots of what the threads under the ecelerity_send process are doing. This is especially helpful when determining the cause of general slowness, timeouts within Momentum, and other performance-related issues. To gather gstacks, you first need to make sure that the gdb package is installed, otherwise an error will be returned. To install the gdb package, you'll need to run:

# yum install gdb

Once that's finished, you'll want to run the following command:

# for i in `seq 1 10`; do ECPID=$(cat /var/run/ecelerity.pid.instance); echo "Taking snapshot #${i} of PID ${ECPID}"; gstack $ECPID > ecgstack.`date +"01-01-2014"`.$i.txt ; sleep 2; done

Just to keep track of when these are retrieved, please change the date from "01-01-2014" to the appropriate date. This command will dump 10 text files in your current working directory. Upon request, the support team will ask that you collect this information only while the problem is occurring, then create a tarball of these files and send them to us in your support case.

2) iostat

When determing disk input/output statistics, we may ask that you utilize the "iostat" command. This is part of the "sysstat" package for RHEL-based distributions. To install iostat, please run:

# yum install sysstat

To capture useful I/O statistics, please run:

# iostat -dxtk 5 10 | tee iostat.txt

This command will take 10 snapshots over 5-second intervals, and will redirect the output to a file in your current working directory. The flags for iostat will do the following:

-d – Show the device report
-x – Show extended statistics if available
-t – Print the time of each report for reference purposes when referring back to captured output
-k (or -m) – Print the stats in kb/sec (or mb/sec) rather than blocks/second.

3) Core dumps

Normally, Ecelerity will create trace files in /var/log/ecelerity/traces upon crashes and watchdog timeouts. However, there are occasions where a deep introspection is required that trace files do not provide. Our engineers and support team may request that you set up core dumping on a problematic MTA. To get started, please create or modify the file with the following parameters (/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/environment):

EC_TRACE_ON_CRASH=off
export EC_TRACE_ON_CRASH

Change your sysctl settings to allow the kernel in your environment to produce core dumps:

# sysctl -w fs.suid_dumpable=1
# sysctl -w kernel.core_pattern=/var/tmp/core.%t.%e.%p

Please note, core dumps can be quite large, so please be sure to set the path for "kernel.core_pattern" to a partition where there is enough disk space to account for the full amount of physical RAM to be dumped.

Verify that your sysctl settings have been set:

# sysctl -a | grep fs.suid_dumpable

Restart ecelerity with "ulimit -c" set to unlimited so that all of the addressable memory will be dumped into the core file:

# ulimit -c unlimited; /opt/msys/ecelerity/bin/ec_ctl restart

When a core dump is produced, please proceed with the following commands to produce a backtrace from the core dump. In the same directory where the core file is produced, create a file called "core.gdb," and set the following lines:

set $outer_ctr = 0
while $outer_ctr < 6
        printf "error level %d\n", $outer_ctr
        set $inner_ctr = 0
        print log_circ_queue[$outer_ctr]
        while $inner_ctr < 11
                print log_circ_queue[$outer_ctr].logs[$inner_ctr].buffer
                set $inner_ctr++
        end
        set $outer_ctr++
end
thread apply all bt full
info registers
quit

Once that's done, execute the following command, making sure to properly reference the filename of the core dump:

# gdb -x core.gdb /opt/msys/ecelerity/sbin/ecelerity_send /var/tmp/core.ecelerity_send.XXXXX 2>&1 | tee output.txt

Now, you should have a file called "output.txt." within your current working directory. Please send this information to us so that we can escalate this information to our engineering team. Additionally, please keep the core dump available while your case is ongoing. While the backtrace created from gdb is very useful, there are occasions that we'll need the full core file to inspect further.

4) Momentum-specific commands:

There are numerous commands within Momentum's ec_console that are very useful for debugging purposes. We ask that you run the following commands from ec_console in debugging mode. To do so, enter "debugging mode" within ec_console. From there, you'll need to run the following commands. It's often handy to have a text editor in another window to copy and paste the output from these commands:
cache list all
memory
summary (executed at least 5 times)
events fd
events time (executed at least 5 times)
threads stats
threads io queue
threads cpu queue
mailq
show inbound
show outbound

articles.subject: How can I troubleshoot DNS and network connectivity issues?
articles.keywords: dns, momentum, ifconfig, firewall, nat, resolv.conf, paniclog.ec
articles.body:
How can I troubleshoot DNS and network connectivity issues?

Every now then, we all run into misconfigurations, bugs, or unexpected behavior while administering any complex piece of software. When you consider the granularity of each configuration scope in the Momentum/Ecelerity architecture and how extendable it is in order to accommodate many different use cases, there is a possibility of running into-suboptimal performance, or even instability. When troubleshooting given issues, there are some useful places to start looking:
Logs - The most important and crucial piece of information you can use is your logs. If you a suspect a problem with Ecelerity, please look check your panic log on the affected MTA located at /var/log/ecelerity/paniclog.ec. Another place to search is /var/log/messages or "dmesg"
Network - Some issues can be due to network misconfigurations, starved connections, bad hardware, DNS configuration, etc. Here are some preliminary checks that can be done to spot issues quickly, starting inward then working your way outward to spot any issues:

1) Run 'ifconfig -a'. Can you see all of your interfaces and IP addresses you would normally expect to see? If not, try running 'ethtool eth0' and replace the interface name with the broken one you see in ifconfig. If you see that your network card is running at half-duplex, or if 'Link detected' is set to 'no,' then try renegotiating the connection by running "ethtool -r eth0". Afterwards, you should see some information appear in /var/log/messages and dmesg.

Firewall/NAT - Do you have iptables running on each MTA? Check that you don't have any rules using DROP or REJECT preventing a particular port being listening by running 'iptables -L'. If there's a particular port that you can't reach, verify its status by running netstat -lntpu. Be sure to send this output to support when raising a ticket for a network issue. Also, ping, traceroute, mtr (My Traceroute), etc can be helpful as well.

DNS - Generally, you'll recognize DNS issues when receiving internal bounces containing "454 4.4.4 [internal] no MX or A for domain". In short, the DNS subsystem is not able to retrieve responses for DNS queries. Momentum is capable of executing several hundreds to thousands of DNS queries per second and responses should be received within milliseconds, so it is incredibly important for your DNS subsystem to be working optimally. For the most part, it's best to troubleshoot starting inward then moving outward.

Check /etc/resolv.conf (or the resolv_conf parameter if configured in ecelerity.conf). This will provide the nameservers that your MTA is currently using. Can you ping the nameservers? Can you dig for a domain specifically from that nameserver (i.e., dig @ns.mynameserver.com mx google.com). If you have any trouble getting a response from any of these machines you target while using 'dig,' then you will need to troubleshoot said nameserver/resolver.

WARNING: Do you not run your nameservers locally on each MTA. This may cause resource contention as the server has to now both forward queries and answer them. Additonally, do not use a public resolver such as Google's 8.8.8.8 and 8.8.4.4. A public DNS resolver will likely rate-limit your responses if not block them altogether.

If not, we'll need to find out who's reponsible for providing DNS and fix it. Find your current nameservers by checking /etc/resolv.conf on the problematic MTA. (Also, there is option in ecelerity.conf where you can specify your own nameservers. This option is called "resolv_conf" https://support.messagesystems.com/docs/web-ref/conf.ref.resolv_conf.php).

articles.subject: How do I add a node to an isolated riak ring?
articles.keywords: riak, cluster, ecelerity, msys-riak, riak-admin
articles.body:
How do I add a node to an isolated riak ring?
 

When adding a node to an environment that has had the Riak ring partitioned its recommended to follow these steps when prompted.  Since there is various configurations depending on where the node is at time of install in relation to the cluster you could be prompted for different questions.  Here is the recommended steps depending on configurations:

If you are installing Momentum in a cluster configuration with only the default subcluster, when you install one of the cluster MTA nodes, you are asked the following question:

Would you like this node to join the following riak cluster?

Type an existing riak node (name or IP) or 'no' to not join at this time. (ip_address)

Type no

If no Riak instance has been created and you are not in the same subcluster as the cluster manager, you will be asked:

Is this the first riak instance in the 'cluster_name' subcluster?

Type no

When you answer "no", you will then be asked to join the Riak cluster:

Type an existing riak node (name or IP) or 'no' to not join at this time.

Type no

If you run into any other issues perform the following:

  1. Stop ecelerity
  2. Leave the Riak ring:
    /opt/msys/3rdParty/riak/bin/riak-admin leave 
  3. Stop msys-riak
  4. Run rm -rf /var/db/riak/* 
  5. Restart msys-riak
  6. Restart ecelerity

If msys-riak will not start for any reason, check the app.config in /opt/msys/3rdParty/riak/etc for any duplicate ring members then perform the following steps:

  1. Run rm -rf /var/db/riak/* 
  2. Start msys-riak
  3. Restart ecelerity

articles.subject: How do I add a recipient on a message to a specific email address?
articles.keywords: lua, example, envelope2, rcptto, add, recipient
articles.body:
How do I add a recipient on a message to a specific email address?

This is an example lua script, which come as is, showing how to achieve that:

<snip>

require("msys.core");
require("msys.dumper");
require("msys.extended.message");
require("msys.extended.vctx");local mod = {};

function mod:validate_data(str, accept, vctx)
  local rcluser = msys.core.string_new();
  local rcdom= msys.core.string_new();
  local mc = msys.core.accept_construct_get_message_construct(accept);
  local msg = mc.message;
  msg:get_envelope2(msys.core.EC_MSG_ENV_TO, rcluser, rcdom);
  local myLocalpart = tostring(rcluser);
--  print ("RCUser :",myLocalpart,":");
--  print ("RCDom : ",rcdom.buffer);
  if (myLocalpart == "user") then       vctx:add_recipient("user@example.com");
    print ("Added the additional recipient to the oob");
  end    local addrs = vctx:recipient_list();
  print ("Recipient list : ",msys.dumper.Dumper(addrs));
  return msys.core.VALIDATE_CONT;
end

msys.registerModule("validate_data", mod);

</snip>

articles.subject: How do I add an Analytics node to an existing cluster (Momentum 4.1)?
articles.keywords: setrepodir, add, analytics, vertica, node
articles.body:
How do I add an Analytics node to an existing cluster (Momentum 4.1)?

Set up the initial repo:

1) Unpack the same tarball that was used for the original installation

2) Activate the local yum repo:

# cd momentum-4.1.0.46072
# ./setrepodir

3) Install the msys-role-analytics metapackage

# yum install -y --config=$PWD/momentum.repo --enablerepo=momentum msys-role-analytics

Add node to Vertica cluster and database:

1) From the first Analytics node, add the new node to the cluster:

# cd /var/tmp/momentum-4.1.0.46072
# export NEWNODE=new.host.fully.qualified.name
# /opt/vertica/sbin/install_vertica --add-hosts $NEWNODE -z silent_install

You can find the silent_install file in the working directory of the initial installation, or you can create a new one with the following contents:

accept_eula = True
data_dir = /var/db/vertica
direct_only = True
failure_threshold = FAIL
license_file = /opt/vertica/config/licensing/Message_Systems_vertica.license.key
rpm_file_name = packages/msys-vertica-7.1.0-3.rhel6.x86_64.rpm
spread_subnet = default
vertica_dba_group = verticadba
vertica_dba_user = vertica_dba
vertica_dba_user_dir = /var/db/vertica
vertica_dba_user_password_disabled = True

You will need the root password for the new node or have configured password-less ssh login or be running ssh-agent.

2) Change to the vertica_dba user and add the new host to the msys database:

# su - vertica_dba
$ export NEWNODE=new.host.fully.qualified.name
$ adminTools --tool db_add_node --database msys --add=$NEWNODE
$ adminTools --tool rebalance_data -k 1 -d msys

NOTE: that last two steps may take an extended period of time, depending on how long the database has been up and how much data is present and should be run inside a screen or tmux session.

3) Add the storage locations for the new node, using the following script:

#!/bin/bash
 
# Setup storage location grants across all hosts
for ARG in "api/webhooks/WEBHOOK_BATCHES" "etl/etl/ETL"
do
 IFS='/' ARGS=($ARG)
 USER="vertica_${ARGS[0]}"
 LOCATION="/opt/vertica/log/${ARGS[1]}"
 LABEL=${ARGS[2]}
 IFS=$'\n ' NODES=`/opt/vertica/bin/vsql -c "select node_name from v_catalog.nodes where node_name not in (select node_name from v_monitor.disk_storage where storage_path='$LOCATION') group by node_name;" -t`
 for NODE in $NODES
 do
 echo "Adding storage location $LOCATION for $NODE"
 /opt/vertica/bin/vsql -c "CREATE LOCATION '$LOCATION' NODE '$NODE' USAGE 'USER' LABEL '$LABEL';"
 /opt/vertica/bin/vsql -c "GRANT ALL ON LOCATION '$LOCATION' ON $NODE TO $USER;"
 done
done

Update config files and distribute to Analytics nodes:

1) On the first Analytics node, update the following config files with the new node:

/opt/msys/3rdParty/nginx/conf.d/api_webhooks_upstream.conf
/opt/msys/3rdParty/nginx/conf.d/api_users_upstream.conf
/opt/msys/3rdParty/nginx/conf.d/api_metrics_upstream.conf
/opt/msys/3rdParty/nginx/conf.d/webui_upstream.conf
/opt/msys/app/webhooks-api/config/production.json
/opt/msys/app/cron/config/production.json
/opt/msys/app/metrics-api/config/production.json

2) Update the nginx/conf.d files by duplicating one of the existing lines and changing it to the new hostname.

3) Update the production.json files using the following script fragment:

export PATH=/opt/msys/3rdParty/bin/:$PATH
for f in \
 /opt/msys/app/webhooks-api/config/production.json \
 /opt/msys/app/metrics-api/config/production.json \
 ; do
 tmpf=$(mktemp --tmpdir=$(dirname $f) -t)
 jq ".application.vertica.hosts = .application.vertica.hosts + [\"$NEWNODE\"]" -a -M $f > $tmpf
 if [ $? = 0 ]; then
 mv -f $tmpf $f
 fi
done
for f in \
 /opt/msys/app/cron/config/production.json \
 ; do
 tmpf=$(mktemp --tmpdir=$(dirname $f) -t)
 jq ".vertica.hosts = .vertica.hosts + [\"$NEWNODE\"]" -a -M $f > $tmpf
 if [ $? = 0 ]; then
 mv -f $tmpf $f
 fi
done

4) Update the webui json file to make it more robust:

for f in \
 /opt/msys/app/webui/scripts/config/production.json \
 ; do
 tmpf=$(mktemp --tmpdir=$(dirname $f) -t)
 jq '.auth.apiPort=false | .auth.apiHost=false' $f > $tmpf
 if [ $? = 0 ]; then
 mv -f $tmpf $f
 fi
done

5) Copy the modified config files to all original Analytics nodes:

for f in \
 /opt/msys/3rdParty/nginx/conf.d/api_webhooks_upstream.conf \
 /opt/msys/3rdParty/nginx/conf.d/api_users_upstream.conf \
 /opt/msys/3rdParty/nginx/conf.d/api_metrics_upstream.conf \
 /opt/msys/3rdParty/nginx/conf.d/webui_upstream.conf \
 /opt/msys/app/webhooks-api/config/production.json \
 /opt/msys/app/cron/config/production.json \
 /opt/msys/app/metrics-api/config/production.json \
 /opt/msys/app/webui/scripts/config/production.json \
 ; do
 scp $f $NODE2:$f
 scp $f $NODE3:$f
done

6) Restart the services on all existing Analytics nodes:

# service msys-app-metrics-api restart
# service msys-app-users-api restart
# service msys-app-webhooks-api restart
# service msys-nginx reload

7) Copy all of the config files to the new Analytics node:

for f in $(find /opt/msys/app/ -name production.json) ; do
 scp $f $NEWNODE:$f
done
scp /opt/msys/3rdParty/nginx/conf.d/* $NEWNODE:/opt/msys/3rdParty/nginx/conf.d/

8) Start all services on the new Analytics node:

# service msys-app-metrics-api start
# service msys-app-users-api start
# service msys-app-webhooks-api start
# service msys-nginx start

Update all Platform/MTA nodes (not Manager or Log Aggregator):

1) The following files must be edited on all MTA nodes:

/opt/msys/3rdParty/nginx/conf.d/api_webhooks_upstream.conf
/opt/msys/app/webhooks-transmitter/config/production.json
/opt/msys/app/metrics-etl/config/production.json
/opt/msys/app/webhooks-batch/config/production.json

2) Update the nginx/conf.d files by duplicating one of the existing lines and changing it to the new hostname

3) Use the following scriptlet to update the production.json files:

export PATH=/opt/msys/3rdParty/bin/:$PATH
for f in \
 /opt/msys/app/metrics-etl/config/production.json \
 /opt/msys/app/webhooks-batch/config/production.json \
 /opt/msys/app/webhooks-transmitter/config/production.json \
 ; do
 tmpf=$(mktemp --tmpdir=$(dirname $f) -t)
 jq ".vertica.hosts = .vertica.hosts + [\"$NEWNODE\"]" -a -M $f > $tmpf
 if [ $? = 0 ]; then
 mv -f $tmpf $f
 fi
done

4) Restart all affected services:

# service msys-app-metrics-etl restart
# service msys-app-webhooks-batch restart
# service msys-app-webhooks-transmitter restart
# service msys-nginx reload

articles.subject: How do I add multiple subscribers to a Momentum jlog?
