articles.keywords: journaled log, JLog, delivery_logfile, subscriber, Momentum, master
articles.body:
What is jlog?

JLog is short for "journaled log" and this package is really an API and implementation that is libjlog. What is libjlog? libjlog is a pure C, very simple durable message queue with multiple subscribers and publishers (both thread and multi-process safe). The basic concept is that publishers can open a log and write messages to it while subscribers open the log and consume messages from it. libjlog abstracts away the need to perform log rotation or maintenance by publishing into fixed size log buffers and eliminating old log buffers when there are no more consumers pending.

The jlog will collect data in multiple files called "segments". Each segment can grow to 4MB in size. Segments remain on disk until all known subscribers have consumed the data from that segment and issued a checkpoint against the jlog.

How do I add another subscriber to a Momentum jlog?

To have multiple subscribers read from the same jlog, you should alter the subscriber list in your logger configuration so that it includes both subscribers, comma separated:
For example, to have both a "master" subscriber and an "other" subscriber:

delivery_logfile = "jlog:///var/log/ecelerity/delivery.queue=>master,other"

Because jlogs are writing data to segments, it means that if you have a high volume of data going to the jlog and one of the subscribers is not running for some time, that you will see increased disk space usage. If you decide to decommission one of the subscribers, you will need to stop all writers and readers, adjust the logger configuration to remove the redundant subscriber, and then use the jlogctl tool to remove the subscriber from the log.

delivery_logfile = "jlog:///var/log/ecelerity/delivery.queue=>master"
/opt/msys/jlog/bin/jlogctl -e other /var/log/ecelerity/delivery.queue

articles.subject: How do I add new users in Momentum 4.1?
articles.keywords: users-api, users, Node.js, NODE_ENV, users-api, Momentum, 4.x, nodejs, username, password
articles.body:
How do I add new users in Momentum 4.1?

With Momentum 4.1, all user management tasks are handled by multiple Node.js scripts. First, you'll need to log into the Platform node that hosts the Web UI. Afterwards, you'll want to run the commands below; please be sure to to update username and password, and remove the preceding comment (#). The 'customer' field will almost always be 1.

# cd /opt/msys/app/users-api
# NODE_ENV=production /opt/msys/3rdParty/bin/node etc/add_user.js --customer 1 --username <username> --password <password>

You will be able to log into the Web UI with your new user immediately after these steps are completed.

articles.subject: How do I advertise SIZE from Momentum?
articles.keywords: ​RFC 1870, esmtp_capability_add, local mod, SIZE, Momentum
articles.body:
How do I advertise SIZE from Momentum?

RFC 1870 ( http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1870  ) describes a mechanism for a mail server to advertise the maximum message size it will accept in the EHLO response. Momentum does not advertise size by default.

To advertise SIZE, you add ac:esmtp_capability_add to your default policy ( https://support.messagesystems.com/docs/web-momo4/lua.ref.ac_esmtp_capability_add.php  ). That will advertise the maximum size of message that you will accept, in bytes. For example: 
require("msys.core");
require("msys.extended.message");
require("msys.extended.ac");

local mod = {};
function mod:validate_connect(ac, vctx)
  ac:esmtp_capability_add("SIZE 104857600");
  return msys.core.VALIDATE_CONT;
end
msys.registerModule("validate_connect", mod);
Advertising SIZE will not take action on a message which is too large. To take action, after the DATA phase you could check the size of the message using the message size function ( https://support.messagesystems.com/docs/web-momo4/lua.ref.msg_get_message_size.php  ); if it is too large, reject it using set_code ( https://support.messagesystems.com/docs/web-momo4/lua.ref.vctx_set_code.php  ). For example:

local mod = {};
function mod:validate_data (msg, accept, vctx)
  if msg:get_message_size() > 104857600 then
    vctx:set_code(550, "552 Message size exceeds fixed maximum message size");
  end;
 return msys.core.VALIDATE_DONE;
end
msys.registerModule("data", mod);

articles.subject: How do I alter the Unsubscribe/ViewInBrowser links in Message Central?
articles.keywords: Unsubscribe, A HREF, SPAN, link, css, unsub, message, central
articles.body:
How do I alter the Unsubscribe/ViewInBrowser links in Message Central?
 

The Unsubscribe and View-in-browser links are auto-generated by macros. To alter the look and feel of these macros requires some additional work.

Changing link text

This is a simple fix. Instead of [%= :unsubscribe %] or [%= :viewinbrowser %] you use:

[%= UNSUBSCRIBE(click here to unsubscribe) %]
[%= VIEWINBROWSER(view it as a webpage) %]

Changing style of link (color, size, background)

This requires the use of style sheets. The idea is that you can wrap the A HREF in a SPAN tag, then apply the style to just the A element within the SPAN class specified:

span.unsub a {
 color: green;
 background: yellow;
 }
span.unsub a:hover {
 color: red
 }

....
 
<span class="unsub">
 [%= UNSUBSCRIBE(click here to unsubscribe) %]
</span>

Using a button of image instead of the text

This is a little more "hacky", but CSS text replacement isn't totally uncommon. You will want to test this solution in different web browsers, and different email clients. The idea is to basically make the entire element clickable (even the background), then set a margin on the element so that it is essentially pushed "outside the box" or "off the page" so that it becomes invisible. You can then use a background image, which is still clickable, turning it into a "button" of sorts. The text remains, and is still readable for text based email readers and accessible readers.

<style type="text/css">
span.unsub a {
 display: inline-block;
 width: 256px;
 height: 256px;
 background: url("http://icons.iconarchive.com/icons/hopstarter/button/256/Button-Close-icon.png") repeat 0 0;
 text-indent: -9999px;
 }
</style>
 
....
 
<span class="unsub">
 [%= :unsubscribe %]
</span>

articles.subject: How do I backup and restore the PostgreSQL database?
articles.keywords: PostgreSQL, SQL-dump, Backup, pg-dump, psql, backup, restore
articles.body:
How do I backup and restore the PostgreSQL database?

The purpose of this document is to provide generic steps on how to basically take a backup of a Postgres DB / Table. The provided example commands do not refer to any specific table or database.

It was assumed that the person who would be actually using this article, would have a fair idea of what he/she is trying to backup, and if he/she chooses to backup a specific table it will be his/her responsibility to actually backup the other tables which refer the original tables. Postgres being a relational database, there will always be references between a number of tables.

This is a 'how to' article which only gives example commands, how it is done actually is solely dependent on the person doing it. It will be their responsibility to maintain the integrity of the data they are trying to backup and also will depend on the specific use case.

Backing up the entire DB is always a safe option, but when backing up specific tables, one needs to be careful.


SQL-dump/pg_dump:

The idea behind the SQL-dump method is to generate a text file with SQL commands that, when fed back to the server, will recreate the database in the same state as it was at the time of the dump. PostgreSQL provides the utility program pg_dump for this purpose.

pg_dump is an effective and comprehensive tool to take Postgres database backups and use the backups to restore the postgres database. However, it is not restricted to database only. We can use pg_dump to take backups of the tables and then use that to restore individual tables as well. Using pg_dump, you can take a backup of the local database and restore it on a remote database.


How to Backup Postgres Database:

  1. Backup a Postgres Table:

    $ /opt/msys/3rdParty/bin/pg_dump --table maincontrol.orgs -U ecuser pe -f ms_table.sql

    The above command is an example of how to backup a specific table from a Postgres database. Using the above command, we are backing up table "orgs" in schema "maincontrol" from database "pe" to ms_table.sql file. To backup a specific table, use the "–table TABLENAME" option in the pg_dump command. If there are same table names in different schema, then use the "–schema SCHEMANAME" option.

  2. Backup a specific Postgres database:

    $ /opt/msys/3rdParty/bin/pg_dump -U ecuser pe -f pe_dump.sql

    This is an example of backing up a specific Postgres database. Using the above command we are backing up the database for Message Central "pe" to file pe_dump.sql. The backup file has the create table, alter table and copy commands for all the tables in the "pe" database.

  3. Backup all Postgres databases:

    $ /opt/msys/3rdParty/bin/pg_dumpall -U ecuser> all_dump.sql

    You can backup all the databases using pg_dumpall command. The above command will create a dump of all the databases that reside on the Postgres instance running on a particular server. To list all the database that have been backed up use the command: grep "^[\]connect" all.sql


How to Restore Postgres Database:

  1. Restore a Postgres table:

    $ /opt/msys/3rdParty/bin/psql -U ecuser -f ms_table.sql pe

    The above command will install the table that was backed up in ms_table.sql file to the "pe" database. Ensure that this table does not already exist, or you will see a bunch of "already exists" errors. This command creates and the table and exports all the data to the newly created table.

  2. Restore a Postgres database:   

    $ /opt/msys/3rdParty/bin/psql -U ecuser -d pe -f pe_dump.sql

    Similar to the restore of the table we can use the above command to restore the complete database. Here we are restoring the "pe" database using the file pe_dump.sql which we had created while backing up the DB in the Backup section above.

  3. Restore all databases:

    $  /opt/msys/3rdParty/bin/psql -u ecuser -f all_dump.sql

    Restore all the databases using the above command. The "all_dump.sql" file was created using pg_dumpall. The above command will give us all the Postgres databases in the exact state that they were in when a dump was taken from the original DB server.

articles.subject: Backup and re-installation instructions for Momentum 3.x on the same Operating System, hardware or Virtual Machine instance.
articles.keywords: Backup, ecelerity, ecelerity.conf, license, uninstall, reinstall, rm, rf, rsync, 3.x
articles.body:
Backup and re-installation instructions for Momentum 3.x on the same Operating System, hardware or Virtual Machine instance.
 
  1. Copy or rsync /opt/msys/* /root/oldmsys/
     
  2. Copy or rsync /opt/msys /var/ecconfigd /var/eccluster /var/db/msyspg /var/log/ec* /var/spool/ecelerity /var/log/msyspg /var/log/spread /var/tmp/webconsole /var/db/riak to /root/oldmsys
     
  3. Keep the ecelerity.conf file from the original installation in the root directory for use in the new install.  
# cp /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf/default/ecelerity.conf /root/

        4. Keep the licence file from the original installation in the root directory for use in the new install.  

  # cp /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/licence /root/

        5. Proceed with the standard uninstall procedure shown below:

  # ./installer --uninstall

        6. Then to remove all other remaining components, like the riak database etc do the following:

  # rm -Rf /opt/msys /var/ecconfigd /var/eccluster /var/db/msyspg /var/log/ec* /var/spool/ecelerity /var/log/msyspg /var/log/spread /var/tmp/webconsole /var/db/riak

       7. Move the licence and ecelerity.conf files back into the new installation in their relevant locations:

The ecelerity.conf file goes here : /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf/default/
The licence file goes here : /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc

articles.subject: How do I bootstrap a clean version of the repository in Momentum 3.x?
articles.keywords: bootstrap, lastinstall, singlenode, clean version, Momentum, 3.x, cluster, manager, svcpasswd
articles.body:
How do I bootstrap a clean version of the repository in Momentum 3.x?

Please use the following steps to get a new version of the repository on your singlenode and/or cluster.
  • Move the /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf directory
mv /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/oldconf
Assuming that this directory does not exist.
Followed by
Singlenode
/opt/msys/ecelerity/bin/eccfg bootstrap --username <username> --password <password> --singlenode
Cluster
/opt/msys/ecelerity/bin/eccfg bootstrap --username <username> --password <password> --clustername <clustername> <clustermanager>
Where <username> and <password> are what you have set them to, these can be found in the lastinstall file. Clustername <clustername> should be the name of your cluster, usually default, and <clustermanager> is the hostname of your clustermanager. If you need verification of the password cat /opt/msys/etc/.svcpasswd and this should be the password for ecuser.
You should run the command on each node you need to bootstrap. It will pull the last saved config from the repo onto the node. The command will NOT reload the config but the node will do an automatic reload 1x/minute as well as a pull from the manager. You can also run a config reload manually from the ec_console.

articles.subject: How do I Bring up Nodes or Collect Diagnostics for Vertica Issues?
articles.keywords: Nodes, Diagnostics, Vertica, vertica_db, admintools, diag_dump, tar, gzip, Node0
articles.body:
How do I Bring up Nodes or Collect Diagnostics for Vertica Issues?
 

All the following instructions should be executed on Node0. This is in the instant that the Vertica service goes offline, these are the steps that you should follow:

1. On the linux command line execute: su vertica_dba
     This will log you in as the vertica_dba user. This is important as the next step will not work otherwise.

2. On the command line enter the following “/opt/vertica/bin/admintools” - This will then bring up an ascii menu.

     a. Select the first option “View Database Cluster State” and check to see if any nodes are down, this should be referenced in the small table that will display. If this display looks like the following, your cluster is up and running:

       Msys_|  ALL_|  UP____

3. If any of the nodes are listed as being down you should attempt to do the following:

     a. In Admintools select the third option: Start Database (this does not have to be run on the machine that is down)

     b. If this returns that all databases have been started then your cluster is up and running.

     c. If this returns that the database could not be started, determine how many how many nodes you have left up and if that is quorum. (51% or more is considered quorum- if you have less than that you will have data loss.)

4. If this does not bring up all your nodes, we will need to collect more information. These still need to be executed as the vertica_dba user.

     a. On the command line enter the following: cd /opt/vertica/log

     b. On the command line enter the following:  /opt/vertica/bin/diagnostics

     c. On the command line enter the following:   /opt/vertica/scripts/collect_diag_dump.sh  (if it prompts for a password, please press enter)

     d. On the command line in the /opt/vertica/log directory list out the files using the command:  ls

     e. Copy the names of the two files with following prefixes into a text editor.

          i. Diag_dump

          ii. VerticaDiagnostics

5. Once both of these have executed, you can email the files to us or upload it to our SFTP site:

     a. On the command line enter the following: sftp <yoursftpaccount>@msupload.messagesystems.com

     b. Enter your sftp password (please email us if you do not remember or want it reset)

     c. Once you are logged in, from the command line prefixed by sftp> enter: 

          i. “put diag_dump_#########.tar.gz diag_dump_#########.tar.gz”

        ii. “put VerticaDiagnostics.########.tgz VerticaDiagnostics.########.tgz”

6. At this point if the database is up and running, please log a case using the Support@messagesystems.com email address, including the details of when where and what happened and also the fact that you uploaded those files.

articles.subject: How do I change an Adaptive Suspension defaulf configuration using the adaptive_override.lua?
articles.keywords: Adaptive Suspension, adaptive_override.lua, configuration, custom, rules
articles.body:
How do I change an Adaptive Suspension defaulf configuration using the adaptive_override.lua?
 

You can change the duration for the AD suspension from the default configuration.Let's take yahoo.com as an example: according to the adaptive_rules.lua file, it is a 2 hours suspension and you want to change it to 45 minutes.

You have to copy what is on the yahoo.com on the adaptive_rules.lua file, place on the adaptive_override lua ( https://support.messagesystems.com/docs/web-ad/ad.custom.rules.php ) file and change it.

 

This is how it is on the adaptive_rules.lua file:

 

["yahoo.com"] = {

       rules = { 

code = "^554 Message not allowed",
trigger = "1",
action = {"suspend", "2 hours"},
message = "IP blocked, remediation with Yahoo.com required",
 },

}

 

And you add this on the adaptive_override.lua file:

 

require("msys.adaptive");

local custom_rules = {

["yahoo.com"] = {

       rules = {

code = "^554 Message not allowed",
trigger = "1",
action = {"suspend", "45 minutes"},
message = "IP blocked, remediation with Yahoo.com required",                   

},

},

   configuration = {
  },
}

msys.adaptive.registerRules(rules, "augment");

Then you will need to ensure that the lua file that has been created is listed in the scriptlets stanza 

Note the change on the action line from 2 hours to 45 minutes.

articles.subject: How do I change the Web UI admin account password on Momentum 4.1 ?
articles.keywords: admin, password, X-MSYS-CUSTOMER: 1, 4.x, web ui, account, username, users
articles.body:
How do I change the Web UI admin account password on Momentum 4.1 ?
 

Replace the "abc1234" with the new desired password.

Replace the "mom4.1" with the hostname of the current machine.

 $ curl -XPUT -H "X-MSYS-CUSTOMER: 1" -H "Content-Type: application/json" -d '{ "password": "abc1234" }' http://mom4.1:2085/api/v1/users/admin


The same methodology can be used for all other users of the webui

 $ curl -XPUT -H "X-MSYS-CUSTOMER: 1" -H "Content-Type: application/json" -d '{ "password": "<new password>" }' http://mom4.1:2085/api/v1/users/<username>

articles.subject: How Do I Check for Global Variables in a Lua Script?
articles.keywords: Variables, Lua, GETGLOBAL, string, lua, bad, performance, slow, memory consumption, cpu, high
articles.body:
How Do I Check for Global Variables in a Lua Script?

 

Lua is very permissive when it comes to undefined variables. Any variable that is not defined is implicitly considered global. This is almost never what you want, and yet it's really easy to do by just typo'ing a variable name (or for example, declaring a variable as evalBind but referencing it as evalBinding). This can result in strange unexpected behavior, where the logic of the script fails, values are missing, Nil errors crop up where they shouldn't, values get swapped between different messages, etc.

To avoid this, it's simple. You define your variables as local:

local var;

If you don't do local var, it's global. There is a way to call the command-line Lua parser to deal with this:

[root@localhost ~]# /opt/msys/3rdParty/bin/rcluac -p -l setbinding.lua |grep -i ETGLOBAL
1 [1] GETGLOBAL 0 -1 ; require
4 [2] GETGLOBAL 0 -1 ; require
7 [3] GETGLOBAL 0 -1 ; require
10 [4] GETGLOBAL 0 -1 ; require
13 [5] GETGLOBAL 0 -1 ; require
38 [148] GETGLOBAL 4 -29 ; msys
16 [59] GETGLOBAL 10 -8 ; msys
23 [65] GETGLOBAL 11 -8 ; msys
31 [66] GETGLOBAL 11 -8 ; msys
38 [67] GETGLOBAL 11 -17 ; string
48 [69] SETGLOBAL 11 -22 ; midSiteid
50 [70] GETGLOBAL 13 -8 ; msys
60 [74] GETGLOBAL 13 -8 ; msys
94 [96] GETGLOBAL 17 -8 ; msys
100 [100] GETGLOBAL 15 -8 ; msys
10 [118] GETGLOBAL 8 -3 ; msys
18 [125] GETGLOBAL 6 -3 ; msys
24 [127] GETGLOBAL 6 -3 ; msys
29 [127] SETGLOBAL 6 -9 ; evalBindingGrp
36 [132] GETGLOBAL 6 -9 ; evalBindingGrp
50 [143] GETGLOBAL 6 -3 ; msys
[root@localhost ~]#


You can ignore the msys, string and require statements (you'll also see things like 'table' and other proper external components), and you can exclude those items from the output using "grep -v msys" for example, but you will want to ensure you do not have any variables that include the word "msys" in the name). However, what jumps out here is midSiteid and evalBindingGrp. Both of those are unintentional globals. The issue is that the global variable is accessed by multiple threads at a time, so it's a classic race condition. The thread might get expected results, but it might have its value overwritten by another thread in the mean time, thus causing major problems. 

Note that sometimes global variables are fine, but that accounts for a very, very small minority of cases. They should at least be commented in the code as explicitly global and initialized as such just to make sure.

articles.subject: How do I classify out of band bounce messages based on certain phrases read from a text file?
articles.keywords: bounce_classifer_override, oob, user_mdn_classification.ovr, message,disposition, notification.
articles.body:
How do I classify out of band bounce messages based on certain phrases read from a text file?

This is basically how the bounce classification works anyway: it searches the first 400kb of the message for a specific string and classifies it appropriately. You can instantiate the bounce_classifer_override module to allow you to set up custom strings. Therefore, you can set up your own classification overrides to search for whatever string you want and classify it.

The documentation for the bounce_classifier_override module can be found at:

https://support.messagesystems.com/docs/web-ref/modules.bounce_classifier_override.php

Example overrides in the user_mdn_classification.ovr may look something like:

60,|out of office
60,|out of the office
60,|absent
60,|out of touch
40,|recipients failed
41,|sender not pre-approved
22,|mailbox unavailable
55,|accepting mail with embedded images
22,|4.2.2 (Over quota)

Therefore, you could create a new classification with a bounce code of 50 based on "custom string":

50,|custom string

articles.subject: How do I clear data from /var/log/eccluster/?
articles.keywords: /var/log/eccluster/, eccmgr, cluster, root
articles.body:
How do I clear data from /var/log/eccluster/?
 

There are two common reasons why the /var/log/eccluster directory can fill up with space, or appear full (even though it's not). Each reason has been separated out to its own section.

No rotation in place

The cluster manager logs are not rotated automatically out of the box, because this is your data, and what you want to do with it is a business decision. These are merely centralized logs that are aggregated from each of the MTAs.

The quickest way to clear up space is by simply removing the directories themselves and restarting the eccmgr service on the manager. However, this is not a good long-term solution because it will be easy to forget about this and run into this issue again. A more ideal solution would be to automate this process. The following Code Block will automatically rotate and delete the logs older than 30 days.

# This will create a tarball of yesterday's cluster logs.
0 1 * * * root tar -cvjf /var/log/eccluster/`date +\%Y\/\%m\/\%d -d "yesterday"`.tar.bz2 /var/log/eccluster/`date +\%Y\/\%m\/\%d -d "yesterday"`/ > /dev/null 2>&1
# This will delete yesterday's raw cluster log files.
0 2 * * * root rm -rf /var/log/eccluster/`date +\%Y\/\%m\/\%d -d "yesterday"`/ > /dev/null 2>&1
# This will execute the find command and remove logs older than 30 days. If you want to alter this, then change the "-mtime" parameter.
0 0 * * 0 root find /var/log/eccluster/`date +\%Y` -mtime +30 -exec rm -f {} \; > /dev/null 2>&1

Additional Resources:  Wikipedia on Cron

Open File Handles

The output of the df command shows that the /var/log/eccluster partition is full. However, the total number of actual files does not add up to this sum. Although this doesn't happen all the time, it can happen when actions (such as a cron job that performs compression, or deletion) take place on the file that is actively being accessed by the eccmgr service. This results in eccmgr being unable to properly relinquish its file handles.

Before we can resolve the issue, we must first gather some information.

Manual Method:

# We will need to first get the PID of the service. We're looking for the "eccmgr" service running as "ecuser".
ps aux | grep eccmgr | grep -v grep
root      4323  0.0  0.0  10736   344 ?        S    14:42   0:00 /opt/msys/ecelerity/sbin/eccmgr: monitoring child 4324
ecuser    4324  0.0  1.1 979512 11936 ?        Ssl  14:42   0:00 /opt/msys/ecelerity/sbin/eccmgr
# We will then use the PID (4324 in this case) to check on the open file handles.
ls -l /proc/4324/fd/
lrwx------ 1 root root 64 Jul 17 14:42 0 -> /dev/null
lrwx------ 1 root root 64 Jul 17 14:42 1 -> /dev/null
lrwx------ 1 root root 64 Jul 17 14:42 10 -> socket:[34661327]
lrwx------ 1 root root 64 Jul 17 14:42 11 -> /var/log/eccluster/control.cache
l-wx------ 1 root root 64 Jul 17 14:42 12 -> /var/log/eccluster/mainlog.ec
l-wx------ 1 root root 64 Jul 17 14:42 13 -> /var/log/eccluster/rejectlog.ec
l-wx------ 1 root root 64 Jul 17 14:42 14 -> /var/log/eccluster/paniclog.ec
...


Automated Method:

This will pull the PID for this service and show you the open file handles for it.

ps h -C eccmgr | ls -l /proc/`awk '{ print $1; }'`/fd
Once we've confirmed that it is eccmgr that is not relinquishing file handles, we can then restart it using the provided init scripts.
 
/etc/init.d/eccmgr restart
Shutting down eccmgr: done.
Starting eccmgr: Pulling latest config files from repo
started
 
Should this fail, we'll then use the kill command on the PID with the SIGTERM (-15) signal. If the process is still running even after the first kill command, then we'll send the SIGKILL (-9) signal.
kill -15 4324
kill -9 4324
 

Alternate Methods:

The methods provided above are to be used during the time of a problem occurring. To take more preventative measures, the client could add the max_open option to the eccluster.conf. You would add the following to the Logs {} stanza:

max_open = 5

Note: The default value for max_open is 128.

articles.subject: How do I clear old data from my Momentum database?
articles.keywords: data, delete, Momentum, database, vacuum, rtlogs, psql, verbose, analyze, pg_size, postgres, size, 6 hr, 15 min, 1 hr, 1 day
articles.body:
How do I clear old data from my Momentum database?

After a while, the Momentum database can grow to a point where it's necessary to delete older data to free up disk space. These steps will walk you through checking the most commonly bloated tables, deleting older data from them, then reclaiming the freed space.

NOTE: In order for the vacuum in the final step to successfully run, your DB partition will need to at least have 10% of the total disk available.

First, log in to the database via:

/opt/msys/3rdParty/bin/psql ecelerity ecuser
Welcome to psql 8.3.5, the PostgreSQL interactive terminal.
 
Type: \copyright for distribution terms
 \h for help with SQL commands
 \? for help with psql commands
 \g or terminate with semicolon to execute query
 \q to quit
 
ecelerity=>

Next, run the following query to get the sizes of the rtlog tables:

select schemaname||'.'||tablename, pg_size_pretty(pg_relation_size(schemaname||'.'||tablename)) from pg_tables where schemaname like 'rtlog%';
 
           ?column?            | pg_size_pretty
-------------------------------+----------------
 rtlogs.run_history            | 8192 bytes
 rtlogs.bounce_summary         | 24 kB
 rtlogs.domain_bounces         | 32 kB
 rtlogs.domain_transfail       | 8192 bytes
 rtlogs.domain_details         | 224 kB
 rtlogs.message_sizes          | 24 kB
 rtlogs.rejection_details      | 24 kB
 rtlogs.binding_stats          | 304 kB
 rtlogs.pathway_stats          | 128 kB
 rtlogs.reasons                | 8192 bytes
 rtlogs.nodes                  | 8192 bytes
 rtlog_15min.run_history       | 8192 bytes
 rtlog_15min.bounce_summary    | 32 kB
 rtlog_15min.domain_bounces    | 40 kB
 rtlog_15min.domain_transfail  | 8192 bytes
 rtlog_15min.domain_details    | 56 kB
 rtlog_15min.message_sizes     | 32 kB
 rtlog_15min.rejection_details | 24 kB
 rtlog_15min.binding_stats     | 56 kB
 rtlog_15min.pathway_stats     | 32 kB
 rtlog_15min.reasons           | 0 bytes
 rtlog_15min.nodes             | 0 bytes
 rtlog_1hr.run_history         | 8192 bytes
 rtlog_1hr.bounce_summary      | 16 kB
 rtlog_1hr.domain_bounces      | 16 kB
 rtlog_1hr.domain_transfail    | 8192 bytes
 rtlog_1hr.domain_details      | 24 kB
 rtlog_1hr.message_sizes       | 16 kB
 rtlog_1hr.rejection_details   | 8192 bytes
 rtlog_1hr.binding_stats       | 16 kB
 rtlog_1hr.pathway_stats       | 8192 bytes
 rtlog_1hr.reasons             | 0 bytes
 rtlog_1hr.nodes               | 0 bytes
 rtlog_6hr.run_history         | 8192 bytes
 rtlog_6hr.bounce_summary      | 8192 bytes
 rtlog_6hr.domain_bounces      | 8192 bytes
 rtlog_6hr.domain_transfail    | 8192 bytes
 rtlog_6hr.domain_details      | 8192 bytes
 rtlog_6hr.message_sizes       | 8192 bytes
 rtlog_6hr.rejection_details   | 8192 bytes
 rtlog_6hr.binding_stats       | 16 kB
 rtlog_6hr.pathway_stats       | 8192 bytes
 rtlog_6hr.reasons             | 0 bytes
 rtlog_6hr.nodes               | 0 bytes
 rtlog_1day.run_history        | 0 bytes
 rtlog_1day.bounce_summary     | 8192 bytes
 rtlog_1day.domain_bounces     | 8192 bytes
 rtlog_1day.domain_transfail   | 8192 bytes
 rtlog_1day.domain_details     | 8192 bytes
 rtlog_1day.message_sizes      | 8192 bytes
 rtlog_1day.rejection_details  | 8192 bytes
 rtlog_1day.binding_stats      | 8192 bytes
 rtlog_1day.pathway_stats      | 8192 bytes
 rtlog_1day.reasons            | 0 bytes
 rtlog_1day.nodes              | 0 bytes
(55 rows)

 

While it isn't illustrated in the above sample output, the most common offenders are the domain_details tables. The next step is to delete data older than a specified date. You will need to decide how far back you want to keep, then use the following command format:

delete from rtlogs.domain_details where time < '2011-03-01 00:00:00';
delete from rtlog_15min.domain_details where time < '2011-03-01 00:00:00';
delete from rtlog_1hr.domain_details where time < '2011-03-01 00:00:00';
delete from rtlog_6hr.domain_details where time < '2011-03-01 00:00:00';
delete from rtlog_1day.domain_details where time < '2011-03-01 00:00:00';

This will delete data older than the date specified. Also, depending on the size of the table(s), this can take an extended period of time to complete. You may want to consider running this in a screen session, so as to prevent interruption.

After running the delete, you'll need to run a vacuum on the DB in order to actually recover the space freed:

vacuum full verbose analyze;

When this completes, you should be able to see a larger portion of available disk on the DB partition.

To simplify the above, you can automate the above by adding cron jobs for the delete command(s) along with the vacuum:

echo "delete from rtlogs.domain_details where time < CURRENT_DATE - INTERVAL '15 DAYS';" | /opt/msys/3rdParty/bin/psql ecelerity ecuser
echo "delete from rtlog_15min.domain_details where time < CURRENT_DATE - INTERVAL '15 DAYS';" | /opt/msys/3rdParty/bin/psql ecelerity ecuser
echo "delete from rtlog_1hr.domain_details where time < CURRENT_DATE - INTERVAL '15 DAYS';" | /opt/msys/3rdParty/bin/psql ecelerity ecuser
echo "delete from rtlog_6hr.domain_details where time < CURRENT_DATE - INTERVAL '15 DAYS';" | /opt/msys/3rdParty/bin/psql ecelerity ecuser
echo "delete from rtlog_1day.domain_details where time < CURRENT_DATE - INTERVAL '15 DAYS';" | /opt/msys/3rdParty/bin/psql ecelerity ecuser
echo "vacuum full verbose analyze;" | /opt/msys/3rdParty/bin/psql ecelerity ecuser

Just modify the interval amount to the number desired, and set your cron to run on the desired schedule.

articles.subject: How do I completely uninstall Momentum 3.x?
articles.keywords: uninstall, ./installer --uninstall, ecelerity, rpm, rm -rf
articles.body:
How do I completely uninstall Momentum 3.x?
 
When uninstalling Momentum, after running the uninstall you'll need to ensure removal of any resident directories. In order to do so, you'll want to perform the following steps any time you're attempting an uninstall:
  • Run the uninstaller:
    • ./installer --uninstall
  • Verify all packages have been removed: 
    • rpm -qa | grep msys
  • Remove any resident packages:
    • rpm -e PACKAGE
  • Remove any resident directories:
    • rm -Rf /opt/msys /var/ecconfigd /var/eccluster /var/db/msyspg /var/log/ec* /var/spool/ecelerity /var/log/msyspg /var/log/spread /var/tmp/webconsole /var/db/riak
After performing the above, you can be ensured that the system is completely cleaned of any previous installation attempt.

articles.subject: How do I configure the Unbound DNS caching resolver?
articles.keywords: DNS, Setup, client.lan, caching, Unbound
articles.body:
How do I configure the Unbound DNS caching resolver?
 

How Do I Configure the "unbound" DNS Caching Resolver?

Many of our clients do not understand the volume of DNS queries that a high volume mailserver can generate.  While most have sysadmins that understand DNS sufficiently to be able to recognize when they need local DNS caching infrastructure and how to do that, many do not.  Those that do sometimes choose the wrong solutions as well - such as DNSmasq.  We have historically recommended BIND - mostly because it's a perceived "standard" – but bind has some notable security and reliability issues.  It is also more oriented towards a full DNS setup doing authorative resolution.  When all we need is a local caching resolver, a tool like "unbound" or DJBDNS's "dnscache" make more sense.  This document details how to configure unbound as a high performance caching resolver.

 

Installing Unbound

One of the reasons for choosing Unbound, aside from its greater security and performance, is that it's available via YUM – though sadly only through the EPEL repository (EL6).  Thankfully it's already built against a relatively current libvent in RHEL6 (and derivatives),  however this version is NOT recommended for RHEL5.  If you are using this older platform, BIND is the recommended resolver to use.

First install the EPEL repository if it isn't already:

# wget http://mirrors.servercentral.net/fedora/epel/6/i386/epel-release-6-8.noarch.rpm
# rpm -i epel-release-6-8.noarch.rpm

Then install unbound:

yum install -y unbound

 

Configuring Unbound

The configuration for Unbound is fairly straightforward for a basic install - but we want to make sure we configure it to be able to perform adequately for most customer loads.  This configuration will do that:

/etc/unbound/unbound.conf:

server:
    verbosity: 1

    # If the client is doing monitoring they may want to turn these on,
    # however they can have an impact on performance, so wait until you
    # have demonstrated a baseline performance expectation
    statistics-interval: 0
    statistics-cumulative: no
    extended-statistics: no

    # Number of threads to create.  Should be a max
    # of the number of cores present in the system.  
    # Other configuration options will vary based on 
    # how this is set!
    num-threads: 4

    # By default we listen only on the localhost interface.  If needed
    # add more interface lines.
    interface-automatic: no
        interface: 127.0.0.1
    outgoing-port-permit: 32768-65535
    outgoing-port-avoid: 0-32767

    # This should be sufficient, but if necessary you can increase this to 8m.
    # Make sure that /etc/sysctl.conf is set appropriately:
    # net.core.rmem_max = 4194304
    # net.core.wmem_max = 4194304
    so-rcvbuf: 4m
    so-sndbuf: 4m

    max-udp-size: 3072
    msg-cache-size: 50m
    num-queries-per-thread: 4096

    # rrset-cache size should be twice what msg-cache-size is
    rrset-cache-size: 100m

    # These must be set in powers of two, and should be as 
    # close as possible to the num-threads value.
    msg-cache-slabs: 4
    rrset-cache-slabs: 4
    infra-cache-slabs: 4
    key-cache-slabs: 4

    do-tcp: yes
    access-control: 127.0.0.0/8 allow
    chroot: ""
    username: "unbound"
    directory: "/etc/unbound"
    log-time-ascii: yes
    pidfile: "/var/run/unbound/unbound.pid"
    root-hints: "root.hints"
    hide-identity: yes
    hide-version: yes
    harden-glue: yes
    harden-dnssec-stripped: yes
    harden-below-nxdomain: yes
    harden-referral-path: yes
    use-caps-for-id: no
    unwanted-reply-threshold: 10000000
    do-not-query-localhost: yes
    prefetch: yes
    prefetch-key: yes
    rrset-roundrobin: yes
    minimal-responses: yes
    dlv-anchor-file: "/etc/unbound/dlv.isc.org.key"
    trusted-keys-file: /etc/unbound/keys.d/*.key
    auto-trust-anchor-file: "/var/lib/unbound/root.anchor"
    val-clean-additional: yes
    val-permissive-mode: no
    val-log-level: 1
    include: /etc/unbound/local.d/*.conf
remote-control:
    control-enable: yes
    server-key-file: "/etc/unbound/unbound_server.key"
    server-cert-file: "/etc/unbound/unbound_server.pem"
    control-key-file: "/etc/unbound/unbound_control.key"
    control-cert-file: "/etc/unbound/unbound_control.pem"
include: /etc/unbound/conf.d/*.conf

 

 

Configure Sysctl.conf

The socket memory sizing options require an increase in the sysctl.conf beyond what we typically configure for just Momentum. Adjust the rmem_max and wmem_max lines like so for a 4 MB size:

net.core.rmem_max = 4194304
net.core.wmem_max = 4194304


Don't forget to apply the changes:

# sysctl -p

 

Setup ulimit

It's a good idea to make sure that the unbound user can adjust ulimits appropriately.  So adjust /etc/security/limits.conf like so:

unbound          soft    nofiles         16518
unbound          hard    nofiles         20000

 

Obtain the current root.hints

# wget ftp://FTP.INTERNIC.NET/domain/named.cache -O /etc/unbound/root.hints

 

Configure any local zones

Some clients have locally resolvable domains for handling their private networks.  These can be easily configured in a delegated fashion within unbound.  Just create a conf file in /etc/unbound/conf.d for them.  In this case, we'll say we have a 10.10.10.x network, with the domain name client.lan.  We would set that up in the file /etc/unbound/conf.d/client.lan.conf like so:

stub-zone:
        name: "client.lan"
        stub-addr: 10.10.10.5

stub-zone:
        name: "10.in-addr.arpa."
        stub-addr: 10.0.0.111


To make sure they can serve the local IP space, add a local zone entry into /etc/unbound/local.d/client.conf like this:

local-zone: "10.in-addr.arpa." nodefault


It's possible the client many later want to add the RFC1918 domains to the list of invalid results, so make sure you set up their domain as a "private-domain".  Further, any such local destinations are not likely to have DNSSEC configured for them, and since that is enable for the root zone, we have to exclude it from such queries.  To do that, make sure you set the insecure-domain option in /etc/unbound/unbound.conf like so:

...
    interface-automatic: no
        interface: 127.0.0.1

    private-domain: "client.lan"
    domain-insecure: "client.lan"
...

 

Wrapping up

Start the unbound DNS service:

# /sbin/service unbound start
Starting unbound: Dec 10 20:07:23 unbound[13583:0] warning: increased limit(open files) from 1024 to 16518
                                                           [  OK  ]

 

The "error" message you get here shows up because of the nature of the order of startup events in conjunction with giving up privileges.  It is not a problem and can be safely ignored.

Now we just need to test it.  Do a query against it and make sure it returns the value you expect:

$ dig -t a messagesystems.com @127.0.0.1 +short
199.15.226.55

$ sudo netstat -lnvpe | grep ':53'
netstat: no support for `AF INET (sctp)' on this system.
tcp        0      0 127.0.0.1:53                0.0.0.0:*                   LISTEN      0          17510722   13584/unbound
udp        0      0 127.0.0.1:53                0.0.0.0:*                               0          17510720   13584/unbound
...

 

Don't forget to put this line into /etc/resolv.conf:

nameserver 127.0.0.1

Otherwise you won't be using this nameserver.  Ideally it should be the ONLY nameserver in the list.  Don't forget to restart Momentum once you've made this change, as it only reads in the resolv.conf at startup.

articles.subject: How do I create an MDN (Message Disposition Notification) in Lua?
articles.keywords: MDN, local mod, Disposition, Lua, custom, rfc 3464, ec_rfc3464
articles.body:
How do I create an MDN (Message Disposition Notification) in Lua?

A Message Disposition Notification is a message which is sent back to the e-mail's originating MTA telling the sender whether the mail was delivered, read, discarded, etc. It also can report the reason for the disposition, especially in the cases of bounces or other discard actions. The short snippet of Lua below could be used as a framework to create MDNs.

 
require('msys.extended.message');
require('msys.rfc3464');
 
local mod = {};
 
function mod:core_log_permanent_failure_v1 (msg, dr, now, str)
 
-- We will assign these two variables using the msg struct passed to this function. see: https://support.messagesystems.com/docs/web-c-api/structs.ec_message.php
 
--$failed_addr = envelope :all "to";
local failed_addr = msg:rcptto();
--$to = envelope :all "from";
local to = msg:mailfrom();
--$from = "postmaster@abuse.domain.com";
local from = "postmaster@abuse.domain.com";
 
--# Don't bounce to the null sender or ourselves.
--if ec_test :is ["", $from] $to {
--stop;
--}
 
if to == "" or to == from then
  return 0;
end
 
--$report = ec_rfc3464_delivery_status;
 
-- generate an MDN message for the permfail:
local report = msys.rfc3464.create_mdn(msg,msys.core.FAILED);
 
--save the localized text you want to include in this MDN to a variable:
local boilerplate = "An e-mail sent from your e-mail address could not be delivered.";
 
-- Inspect the MIME tree to find the part with the "here's why your message failed":
local p =  report:mime(1);
  while p != nil do
    local type = p:content_type();
    if type.mimetype == "text/plain" then
            -- nil check to avoid stack traces from concatenating nil string
            if p:text() != nil then
                --if we have this string in the text of the current MIME part, then it's the one we want to change
                if string.match(p:text(), "This message was created automatically by the mail system") then
                    --save the current text to a variable
                    local ndn_textpart = p:text();
                    --prepend the text of this part with your boilerplate text
                    p:text(boilerplate .. ndn_textpart);
                end
            end
        end
    p = p.thread -- to move on to the next part
  end
  
print(report:body()); -- for debugging purposes
 
report:inject(from, to); --send it!
 
end
 
msys.registerModule("custom_mdn", mod);

articles.subject: How do I disable the generation of the *.rt jlogs (mainlog.rt, statp.rt, etc) in Momentum 3.x?
articles.keywords: .rt jlogs, mainlog.rt, disable
articles.body:
How do I disable the generation of the *.rt jlogs (mainlog.rt, statp.rt, etc) in Momentum 3.x?
 

Symptoms

By default, Momentum 3.x tracks information about its activity in four jlogs:

  • /var/log/ecelerity/bouncelog.rt 
  • /var/log/ecelerity/mainlog.rt 
  • /var/log/ecelerity/rejectlog.rt 
  • /var/log/ecelerity/statp.rt

(If adaptive is enabled, adaptive.rt will also exist.)

These logs are then processed by the included ec_rt_stats2 tool via a cronjob.  This tool summarizes that data, and pushes it into the database to be used by the cluster manager's Web Interface for reporting and analytics.  For those customers who opt not to use the Web Interface for this purpose, some IO overhead can be saved by disabling these logs.

 

Resolution

Disable the logging

1. Disable Statp

In your ecelerity.conf file on the manager node, locate the following line starting with "statp" shown in this excerpt:

# Statistics producer for the web console graphs (both single instance and 
# cluster. 
# Required for the webconsole reporting to function 
statp "statp" {} 

Comment out the "statp" module, by inserting a hash mark (#) at the beginning of the line.

2. Disable ec_logger_rt

Still in ecelerity.conf, locate the "ec_logger_rt" stanza which should be nearby, and should look similar to this excerpt:


# Journals information on deliveries, rejections for
# consumption by ec_rt_stats2.
# Required for the webconsole reporting to function
ec_logger "ec_logger_rt" {
   mainlog = "jlog:///var/log/ecelerity/mainlog.rt=>ec_rt_stats"
   rejectlog = "jlog:///var/log/ecelerity/rejectlog.rt=>ec_rt_stats"
   log_errors = "false"
}
 

Comment out the entire stanza by inserting a hash mark (#) before each line.

3. Disable bounce_logger_rt

Comment out the bounce_logger_rt stanzas the same as the others.  In a stock configuration it should look like so:


# Journals information on bounces for consumption by ec_rt_stats2 
# Required for the webconsole reporting to function 
bounce_logger "bounce_logger_rt" { 
bouncelog = "jlog:///var/log/ecelerity/bouncelog.rt=>ec_rt_stats" 
} 

 

4. Disable adaptive.rt

If you're using adaptive, locate your adaptive stanza, and add this line to it:

enable_jlog = false

So that it looks something like this:


adaptive { 
   enable_jlog = false
} 


5. Commit

To finalize this you need to commit the change to the manager so that it can propagate to the nodes, like so (as root):

 

/opt/msys/ecelerity/bin/eccfg commit --username ecuser --password <password> -m "Disable rtlogs"

Note: replace <password> with the ecuser password.  If you're not using encrypted passwords you can find this in /opt/msys/etc/.svcpasswd

 

Empty the JLogs

The quickest way to do this is just to delete them (directory and all).  If you don't care about the data, this is definitely easiest.  Otherwise, you can wait for them to catch up (if necessary). 


Disable the Cron Job

On each of the MTA nodes, edit /etc/cron.d/msys-ecelerity and comment out the following line, but inserting a hash mark (#) at the beginning of the line:

* * * * * root /opt/msys/ecelerity/bin/ec_rt_stats2 >/dev/null 2>&1 


Then on the manager node, edit /etc/cron.d/msys-ecelerity-webui and comment out this line in the same manner:

* * * * * ecuser /opt/msys/ecwebui/scripts/rollup >/dev/null 2>&1

With all of these steps completed, the nodes should no longer be writing to the *.rt jlogs, and no jobs should execute to attempt aggregating or rolling up that data.

articles.subject: How do I dump the entire svn repo in 3.x/4.x?
articles.keywords: dump, svnadmin, ecconfigd, configuration
articles.body:
How do I dump the entire svn repo in 3.x/4.x?

In order to backup the svn on a 3.x and 4.x cluster do the following steps
  • Backing up the configuration repository with history, this requires two commands since there are actually two repos under the covers here (if you are doing node specific configs there will be additional repos for each directory under /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf) :

    svnadmin dump repositorypath | gzip > backupname.svn.gz

    Example of a full backup:

    /opt/msys/3rdParty/bin/svnadmin dump /var/ecconfigd/repo/default/ | gzip > mydefaultbackup.svn.gz
    /opt/msys/3rdParty/bin/svnadmin dump /var/ecconfigd/repo/global/ | gzip > myglobalbackup.svn.gz
     
  • Backing up the configuration repository with no history, this should only require one command as all directories under your current configuration should be output to the new path:

    Example:

    /opt/msys/3rdparty/bin/svn export /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf /path/to/my-export

articles.subject: How do I enable jemalloc memory debugging?
articles.keywords: jemalloc, debugging, ECELERITY_MEMORY, debug, debugging
articles.body:
How do I enable jemalloc memory debugging?

Implementing jemalloc

Implementing jemalloc requires an /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/enviornment be present.  If there is not one there please create it.  

1. First step, edit your /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/environment and add the lines:  
# memory settings
ECELERITY_MEMORY=jemalloc
export ECELERITY_MEMORY
2. Since we are making a change to the way Momentum handles memory, a restart of the ecelerity process is required. 
3. Open up /opt/msys/ecelerity/bin/ec_console and run the command memory to verify the jemalloc allocator has been successfully implemented.

Jemalloc memory debugging

When using jemalloc (which is the default for ecelerity in 3.6) you can turn on 'junk' and allocator sanity checks by exposing this environment variable: 
MALLOC_CONF="abort:true,junk:true"
# in the environment file make sure to do this:
export MALLOC_CONF
To verify that the above settings are being respected by Momentum, you need to look in the 'memory' command in /opt/msys/ecelerity/bin/ec_console to check the state of the runtime options. An easy way to do this is to run: 
echo "memory" | ec_console | grep opt
that should produce output something like this: 
Run-time option settings:
  opt.abort: true
  opt.lg_chunk: 22
  opt.dss: "secondary"
  opt.narenas: 1
  opt.lg_dirty_mult: 3
  opt.stats_print: false
  opt.junk: true
  opt.quarantine: 0
  opt.redzone: false
  opt.zero: false
  opt.tcache: true
  opt.lg_tcache_max: 15
Note that opt.junk and opt.abort are both "true" - that indicates that the MALLOC_CONF settings are being used.

articles.subject: How Do I Enable Log Rotation for Vertica?
articles.keywords: Vertica, admintools, rotation
articles.body:
How Do I Enable Log Rotation for Vertica?

Currently, Vertica log rotation is not enabled during installation or by default in Momentum. This is more critical with combined nodes but is beneficial in the event Vertica has issues and logs have to be sent to HP support. 

On each Vertica node, execute:
touch /opt/vertica/config/logrotate/msys
chmod a+rw /opt/vertica/config/logrotate/msys

Then on any Vertica node, execute:
su vertica_dba
admintools -t logrotate -d msys -r weekly -k 12

Where -r sets the rotation schedule and -k sets how many logs are kept (1 log is generated per week, so 12 logs keeps 3 months worth of log data). 

For more information, please visit the HP Vertica Support Documentation pages, specifically https://my.vertica.com/docs/7.1.x/HTML/Content/Authoring/AdministratorsGuide/Monitoring/Vertica/RotatingLogFiles.htm

articles.subject: How do I enable log rotation with Momentum 4?
articles.keywords: rotation, ec_rotate.conf, logfiles, Log, retention, 7 days, ec_rotate
articles.body:
How do I enable log rotation with Momentum 4?
 

To ensure log rotation is set up and working.
Check that ec_rotate.conf exists in /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc and that enabled=yes is set.
An example of which is below:
 

# If enabled=yes, then ec_rotate will perform logfile rotation
# on the set of logfiles listed below.
# If you prefer to disable the default action without modifying
# the crontab entry installed by the package, you should do it here
# by setting enabled=no
#################################
# the options are as follows:
# enabled - yes/no - enables ec_rotate to be run
# logfiles - list of log files to rotate
# retention - the number of old log files to retain
# control_socket - the path to the eelerity Control_Listener socket
# path_to_bzip - where to find the bzip2 binary on your system

enabled=yes

# The list of logfiles to rotate
logfiles =/var/log/ecelerity/mainlog.ec             
              /var/log/ecelerity/paniclog.ec            
              /var/log/ecelerity/rejectlog.ec           
              /var/log/ecelerity/bouncelog.ec            
              /var/log/ecelerity/acctlog.ec             
              /var/log/ecelerity/smpplog.ec             
              /var/log/ecelerity/ecconfigd.log             
              /var/log/ecelerity/httplog.ec            
              /var/ecconfigd/apache/access.log             
              /var/ecconfigd/apache/error.log
logdirs = /var/log/ecelerity/adaptive

retention = 7

More information about the file can be found here:  https://support.messagesystems.com/docs/web-momo4/log_rotating.php#conf.ref.ec_rotate.conf.default

Next, please check that a cronjob exists to run the /opt/msys/ecelerity/bin/ec_rotate utility daily.  
The contents of /etc/cron.d/msys-ecelerity-core should be the following:

0 0 * * * root /opt/msys/ecelerity/bin/ec_rotate -d >/dev/null 2>&1

 

More information about that can be found here:  https://support.messagesystems.com/docs/web-momo4/log_rotating.php#conf.ref.ec_rotate.conf.default

Next, check that the cron jobs are in fact being run as expected and that crond is running.  

[root@mom4 default]# ps afx | grep crond
32270 pts/0    D+     0:00          \_ grep crond
 2388 ?        Ss     0:14 crond

 

Then, please manually run ec_rotate as root by issuing the following command:


$  /opt/msys/ecelerity/bin/ec_rotate

articles.subject: How Do I Enable Outbound SMTP Authentication
articles.keywords: SMTP, Authentication, outbound_smtp_auth { }, keep, dicts, message, memory, PLAIN, LOGIN
articles.body:
How Do I Enable Outbound SMTP Authentication

Outbound SMTP authentication was introduced in Momentum version 3.6.13 and 4.3. Below is an example of the configuration options needed to enable this module. As of version 3.6.13 and 4.3, the only supported Outbound_SMTP_AUTH_Type options are PLAIN and LOGIN.

outbound_smtp_auth { }
Keep_Message_Dicts_In_Memory = true

# Example of use . Here with a domain:
Domain "messagesystems.com" {
 Outbound_SMTP_AUTH_Type = "LOGIN"
 Outbound_SMTP_AUTH_User = "myuser"
 Outbound_SMTP_AUTH_Pass = "mypass"
}

articles.subject: How Do I enable SSL or HTTPs in the Momentum 4.1 Web UI and APIs?
articles.keywords: SSL, HTTP, ui nodes, installation, https, openssl, certificate, cipher, nginx
articles.body:
How Do I enable SSL or HTTPs in the Momentum 4.1 Web UI and APIs?

How Do I enable SSL or HTTPs in the Momentum 4.1 Web UI and APIs?

DISCLAIMER: This only applies if connections are being made directly to nginx on the ui nodes. If a load balancer is in use, https connections (and certs) should be handled at that level.

HTTPS

Once certificates have been generated or purchased, this can be set up in nginx: /opt/msys/3rdParty/nginx/conf.d/web_proxy.conf

Here's how to generate a self-signed certificate for testing purposes, or for people with absolutely no budget:

#!/bin/sh
HN=`hostname`
openssl req -batch -new -x509 -nodes -out server.crt -keyout server.key -subj '/OU=Momentum4 server/CN='$HN -days 3650
openssl x509 -noout -fingerprint -text < ./server.crt > server.info

Here's an example of a certificate installation script:

#!/bin/sh
CERTS=/opt/msys/3rdParty/nginx/certs
sudo mkdir $CERTS
sudo cp server.* $CERTS
sudo chmod 644 $CERTS/server.*

And here is a config block that can be added to /opt/msys/3rdParty/nginx/conf.d/web_proxy.conf

server {
  listen 127.0.0.1:80;
 
  listen 443 ssl;
  ssl_certificate     ../certs/server.crt;
  ssl_certificate_key ../certs/server.key;
  ssl_protocols  TLSv1 TLSv1.1 TLSv1.2;
  ssl_ciphers "AES128+EECDH:AES128+EDH";
  ssl_prefer_server_ciphers on;
  ssl_session_cache shared:SSL:10m;
  add_header Strict-Transport-Security "max-age=63072000; includeSubDomains";
  add_header X-Frame-Options DENY;
  add_header X-Content-Type-Options nosniff;

In order to support older/difficult client-side code (ran into this at American Airlines, who uses .NET), it's necessary to change ssl_ciphers to a more permissive setting, as detailed on the raymii.org link below:

ssl_ciphers "ECDHE-RSA-AES256-GCM-SHA384:ECDHE-RSA-AES128-GCM-SHA256:DHE-RSA-AES256-GCM-SHA384:DHE-RSA-AES128-GCM-SHA256:ECDHE-RSA-AES256-SHA384:ECDHE-RSA-AES128-SHA256:ECDHE-RSA-AES256-SHA:ECDHE-RSA-AES128-SHA:DHE-RSA-AES256-SHA256:DHE-RSA-AES128-SHA256:DHE-RSA-AES256-SHA:DHE-RSA-AES128-SHA:ECDHE-RSA-DES-CBC3-SHA:EDH-RSA-DES-CBC3-SHA:AES256-GCM-SHA384:AES128-GCM-SHA256:AES256-SHA256:AES128-SHA256:AES256-SHA:AES128-SHA:DES-CBC3-SHA:HIGH:!aNULL:!eNULL:!EXPORT:!DES:!MD5:!PSK:!RC4";

 

 

REFERENCES

https://raymii.org/s/tutorials/Strong_SSL_Security_On_nginx.html

http://nginx.org/en/docs/http/configuring_https_servers.html#single_http_https_server

https://wiki.mozilla.org/Security/Server_Side_TLS

articles.subject: How do I extend the watchdog timeout for Message Central processes?
articles.keywords: Pe2clicktracker, watchdog, timeout, pe2sched, pe2mgr, pe2thumbq, gimli, watchdog, timeout
articles.body:
How do I extend the watchdog timeout for Message Central processes?

The default watchdog timeout for all MC components is 60 seconds. In some environments, where load or performance is an issue, a query or generation could take over 60 seconds to complete a task, causing the process to watchdog restart and generate a trace file. In these instances, where there isn't an actual error occurring, extending the timeout is a quick workaround (and in some cases a permanent fix).

There isn’t a config parameter to do this for MC components such as pe2sched or pe2mgr, like there is for ecelerity/Momentum. So in order to adjust this, we have to modify the corresponding init script for the service which we want to extend the timeout interval. The valid init scripts/services which can be modified are in /etc/init.d/. Those are: 
Pe2clicktracker
Pe2mgr
Pe2sched
Pe2thumbq
Open the desired init script in a text editor, and find the following line: 
GIMLI_TRACE_DIR=/var/log/pe2/traces
BELOW that line, add the following 4 lines where XXX is the desired interval: 
GIMLI_WATCHDOG_INTERVAL=XXX
export GIMLI_WATCHDOG_INTERVAL
GIMLI_WATCHDOG_START_INTERVAL=XXX
export GIMLI_WATCHDOG_START_INTERVAL
 After saving the change, the final step is simply to restart the desired service. The watchdog timeout interval will now reflect the value defined.

articles.subject: How do I fail/pause messages that were sent as part of an external mailing or campaign?
articles.keywords: fail/pause, ec_console, lua, campaign, custom, header, context, variable
articles.body:
How do I fail/pause messages that were sent as part of an external mailing or campaign?
 

Momentum doesn't track campaign information on its own so unfortunately that is not a feature that comes out of the box. This feature is on the roadmap but no ETA is available. However the components exist for you to build out your own policy and scripts that would allow one to fail/pause a campaign currently. The first step would be to add the campaign ID to each message via a custom header at the time of injection. This gets the necessary piece of data in to Momentum, so that we can actually work with it and differentiate what messages belong to what campaign. The next step is to convert the custom header value to a context variable via lua policy. Then, you'd instantiate a custom log, where the message ID and the campaign ID are logged, thus tying the two critical pieces of data together in one location. The final component would be to write a script that would then parse the log for all message ID's associated with a supplied campaign ID, then pipe the resulting message ID's in to ec_console to be cancelled individually.

An alternative method would be to use separate bindings for each individual mailing. For this use case, the number of bindings would need to equal the max number of concurrent campaigns you run at any one point in time. You would then include a custom header for each campaign, where you designate the desired binding to be used. That is then implemented in to your binding assignment policy. At this point you will know what campaigns are assigned to what individual bindings. You can use ec_console to fail all messages assigned to a given binding, all at once.

Either option would require a separate Professional Services engagement to complete. If you are interested in either of these options, feel free to contact support and we will have a representative contact you with further details.

articles.subject: How do I force messages into the delayed queue?
articles.keywords: local function delay_domain(cc), force , delay, manual, delay
articles.body:
How do I force messages into the delayed queue with Lua?

Sometimes clients may need to force email messages into the delayed queue.  A good example of this can be a customer who has a destination that was heavily throttled, and wouldn't throw back errors but rather just threw away messages that were over the limit.  If the throttles are heavy, and the target userbase is extremely large, this can cause heavy flooding of the active queues.  By pushing emails for these domains into the delayed queue this could be avoided.

 

Delay Emails for a Domain

require("msys.core");
 
local mod = {};
 
msys.registerControl("delay_domain", delay_domain);
 
local function delay_domain(cc)
  local domain = cc.argv[1];
  local dr = msys.core.dns_get_domain(domain);
 
   if dr ~= nil then
        print ("Domain delayed as requested");
        msys.core.mail_queue_delay_domain(dr, "451 4.4.1 [internal] manually delayed domain]");
  end
end
 
function mod:init()
  return true
end
 
msys.registerModule("delaydom", mod);

 

In order for this to work, you will need to instantiate this and then inside the ec_console you can then execute the following command:

delay_domain <domain>

As seen in the above script the print statement will respond with "Domain delayed as requested" and in the mainlog.ec there will be entries that look as follows:

1377461737@40/00-10755-1AB5A125@40/00-10755-1AB5A125@40/00-10755-89B5A125@T@messagesystems.com@0@default@default@22@1@2631.00@@451 4.4.1 [internal] manually delayed domain]

articles.subject: How do I generate a new self-signed SSL certificate for ecconfigd?
articles.keywords: SVN, ecconfigd, premature EOF, valid, certificate, apache, eccmgr
articles.body:
How do I generate a new self-signed SSL certificate for ecconfigd?
 

Introduction

Momentum relies on SVN for configuration management. Before Momentum 3.5.8 and 3.6.1, these SSL certificates had an expiration date of one year. In order to prevent any interruption with your ability to commit or pull your configuration, we've laid out some steps for you to check when your certificate will expire, how to increase the validity period and finally how to regenerate your certificate.

The Error

ERROR: premature EOF in "svn update '-config-dir' '/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/.eccfg' 'username' 'ecuser' 'no-auth-cache' 'non-interactive' '-trust-server-cert' '.'"
svn: OPTIONS of 'https://mail35.prod:2027/config/default/boot': Server certificate verification failed: certificate has expired, issuer is not trusted (https://mail35.prod:2027)
at /opt/msys/lib/perl5/vendor_perl/5.10.0/Expect.pm line 870

The error listed above is one of several that you may encounter depending on the situation. Each of these errors will indicate that the 'certificate has expired'.

Verifying Your Validity Period

Running the following command will allow you to see information regarding your certificate. One of these bits of information is the 'Validity' field, which tells you when the certificate was generated and when it expires.

openssl x509 -noout -text -in /var/ecconfigd/apache/server.crt

An example of the output that you will see is included below:

Validity
Not Before: Jun 13 00:03:40 2013 GMT
Not After : Jun 13 00:03:40 2014 GMT

Extending the Validity Period

If you are running an older version of Momentum (pre-3.5.8 and pre-3.6.1) then you have a Validity period of one year. If you'd like to extend this, then please open the following file:

/opt/msys/ecelerity/bin/create_ssl_cert

Towards the bottom of the file you will find the following line:

qx|$openssl req -new -x509 -nodes -config $CONF -out ${PREFIX}/server.crt -keyout ${PREFIX}/server.key -days 365|;

You will want to modify the '-days' value to a higher value. An example has been provided below:

qx|$openssl req -new -x509 -nodes -config $CONF -out ${PREFIX}/server.crt -keyout ${PREFIX}/server.key -days 11499|;

Note: Please keep in mind that you are limited to a maximum of 11499 days if you are running Momentum in a 32bit environment.

Regenerating Your Certificate

In order to regenerate your SSL certificate, please run through the following commands:

cd /var/ecconfigd/apache
mv server.crt server.crt.old
mv server.key server.key.old
/opt/msys/ecelerity/bin/create_ssl_cert ecconfigd $(hostname) /var/ecconfigd/apache
chmod 700 server.crt server.key
chown ecuser:ecuser server.crt server.key

Note: Do not replace the word 'hostname'. This is actually a Linux command that will automatically fetch your hostname.

These commands will move you into the appropriate directory, rename the current certificate and key files, regenerate the certificate and ensure that the ownership and permissions are set correctly.

You will also have to restart eccmgr and ecconfigd after the new certificate has been generated. 

Conclusion

Please feel free to contact Support if you have any further questions regarding this.

articles.subject: How do I hard-plumb an IP?
articles.keywords: plumb, DuraVIP, ifcfg, hard, bound, NIC, network
articles.body:
How do I hard-plumb an IP?

If you are not using DuraVIPs, you might be hard-plumbing IPs to your machine for use in your bindings. In order to do so, please make sure you have an interface configuration file created for every IP you wish to attach to your NIC. Each ifcfg file must have a colon and a number after the name of the interface you are attaching the IP to. If you are plumbing multiple IPs to the same NIC, make sure the numbers after the colon are sequential. Your ifcfg-ethX file might look something like this:

ifcfg-eth0:1

DEVICE=eth0:1
BOOTPROTO=static
BROADCAST=X.X.X.X
HWADDR=XX:XX:XX:XX:XX:XX
IPADDR=X.X.X.X
NETMASK=X.X.X.X
NETWORK=X.X.X.X
ONBOOT=yes

where the IPADDR is a free IP in your network. In most cases you can copy and paste the ifcfg file from your actual NIC and change the IP address accordingly. 

**Please note, Ecelerity will need to be restarted for all IP-related changes to take effect. A 'config reload' will not suffice.

For information on DuraVIPs, please look here: https://support.messagesystems.com/docs/web-ref/cluster.config.duravip.php (access to support.messagesystems.com required)

articles.subject: How do I implement DMARC (Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting and Conformance) with Momentum?
articles.keywords: DMARC, DKIM,  Lua, SPF, Momentum
articles.body:
How do I implement DMARC (Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting and Conformance) with Momentum?

DMARC is a method of e-mail authentication. It uses SPF and DKIM, along with header values, to verify the source and authenticity of an e-mail. More information about DMARC can be found at:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DMARC

Message Systems doesn't have specific best practices concerning DMARC. Of course, you have to have SPF and DKIM installed and already working in Momentum. The Momentum manual describes how to configure these two items:

https://support.messagesystems.com/docs/web-momo4/modules.spf.php  (SPF for 4.x)
https://support.messagesystems.com/docs/web-ref/modules.spf.php  (SPF for 3.x)
https://support.messagesystems.com/docs/web-momo4/using_dkim.php  (DKIM for 4.x)
https://support.messagesystems.com/docs/web-mc/mc-post-dkim.php  (DKIM for 3.x)

Since DMARC is a set of policies concerning the interpretation of and actions on things like SPF and DKIM results, Lua is used to implement such a policy. Franck Martin from LinkedIn shared with the Message Systems community some Lua which he wrote that implements DMARC. You can find it at:

https://github.com/linkedin/dmarc-msys

articles.subject: How do I inject push (MCMT emails) with payload encoded in base64?
articles.keywords: MCMT, base64, push, injection, json, push
articles.body:
How do I inject push (MCMT emails) with payload encoded in base64?
 

Does Momentum support the injection of push (MCMT emails) with payload encoded in base64?

Not currently no.  A work around was put in place to allow the injection of "Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit" MCMT emails instead of base64 encoded email.


Example: When injecting the following email Momentum accepts it, but it doesn't convert the email into a push message (error: invalid json format):

Message-ID: <152642564.140.1421664496090.JavaMail.jboss@jrhel63so-tw-hc2.labtest.test>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/vnd.msys.mcmt;

boundary="----=_Part_139_313436665.1421664496089"

------=_Part_139_313436665.1421664496089
Content-Type: message/rfc822

Return-Path: 8289394.112117.3000116@push.feedback.labtest.lan
Message-ID: <1368098630.141.1421664496090.JavaMail.jboss@jrhel63so-tw-hc2.labtest.test>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Clab-Policy-v1: erp=0; srp=0; erx=; srx=; acc=3000116; fam=3000115; grp=7267; tst=0
X-Clab-Push-Recipient: APA91bEme-bKemhPberuJhjT25Z0EAd8kkwmoUblTlYk4pSwA98Wj31ki-uv3kMcghaN9U0KlyQDvh-_7Wy8VliolTONwNkW6njRqjMhQnCv4K5wsPgm5KGF5Elp2y8_sEoKRNAJToEBGLIo0HMND9aj7QFQtHsrmg
X-Clab-Push-Endpoint: GCM
X-Clab-Push-Certificate: GCM_CLAB-15_3000116
X-Clab-Push-Certificate-Owner: 3000116
X-Clab-Push-Application: CLAB-15

rfc822 text

------=_Part_139_313436665.1421664496089
Content-Type: message/vnd.msys.gcm
Content-Transfer-Encoding: base64
 
X-Registration-ID: APA91bEme-bKemhPberuJhjT25Z0EAd8kkwmoUblTlYk4pSwA98Wj31ki-uv3kMcghaN9U0KlyQDvh-_7Wy8VliolTONwNkW6njRqjMhQnCv4K5wsPgm5KGF5Elp2y8_sEoKRNAJToEBGLIo0HMND9aj7QFQtHsrmg
 
eyJtZXNzYWdlIjoiQ2nDoG8gWmFuem8iLCJjbGFiTXNnVHJhY2siOiJodHRwOi8vMTcyLjE2Ljgu
MjU0OjgwODAvZW1haWwtdmlldy8zMDAwMTE2LzExMjExNy84Mjg5Mzk0IiwidGltZSI6IjIwMTUt
MDEtMTZUMTU6NDQ6MzQrMDEwMCJ9
------=_Part_139_313436665.1421664496089—

Log extract: Debug (paniclog.ec):

1421426746:GCM-00340: gcm_build_request: construct notification to send!
1421426746:GCM-00356: gcm_build_request: MCMT X-Registration-ID: APA91bEme-bKemhPberuJhjT25Z0EAd8kkwmoUblTlYk4pSwA98Wj31ki-uv3kMcghaN9U0KlyQDvh-_7Wy8VliolTONwNkW6njRqjMhQnCv4K5wsPgm5KGF5Elp2y8_sEoKRNAJToEBGLIo0HMND9aj7QFQtHsrmg
 
Content-Transfer-Encoding: base64
 
eyJtZXNzYWdlIjoiQ2nDoG8gWmFuem8iLCJjbGFiTXNnVHJhY2siOiJodHRwOi8vMTcyLjE2Ljgu
MjU0OjgwODAvZW1haWwtdmlldy8zMDAwMTE2LzExMjExNy84Mjg5Mzk0IiwidGltZSI6IjIwMTUt
MDEtMTZUMTU6NDQ6MzQrMDEwMCJ9
 
 
1421426746:GCM-00790: gcm_build_request_from_mcmt:
Invalid json format
1421426746:GCM-00378: gcm_build_request:
Invalid MCMT JSON payload (null)
 
Here we are using base64 to send LATIN-1 accented characters and symbols inside the text.


The work around is as follows:

1. Change the default behavior of the gcm_request_eval hook
2. Add the encoded text in the rfc822 message followed by two empty lines
3. Use an empty json


Example:

Message-ID: <mailto:152642564.140.1421664496090.JavaMail.jboss@jrhel63so-tw-hc2.labtest.test>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/vnd.msys.mcmt;
 boundary="----=_Part_139_313436665.1421664496089"
------=_Part_139_313436665.1421664496089
Content-Type: message/rfc822
 
Return-Path: mailto:8289394.112117.3000116@push.feedback.labtest.lan
Message-ID: <mailto:1368098630.141.1421664496090.JavaMail.jboss@jrhel63so-tw-hc2.labtest.test>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: base64
X-Clab-Policy-v1: erp=0; srp=0; erx=; srx=; acc=3000116; fam=3000115; grp=7267; tst=0
X-Clab-Push-Recipient: APA91bEme-bKemhPberuJhjT25Z0EAd8kkwmoUblTlYk4pSwA98Wj31ki-uv3kMcghaN9U0KlyQDvh-_7Wy8VliolTONwNkW6njRqjMhQnCv4K5wsPgm5KGF5Elp2y8_sEoKRNAJToEBGLIo0HMND9aj7QFQtHsrmg
X-Clab-Push-Endpoint: GCM
X-Clab-Push-Certificate: GCM_CLAB-15_3000116
X-Clab-Push-Certificate-Owner: 3000116
X-Clab-Push-Application: CLAB-15
eyJtZXNzYWdlIjoiQ2nDoG8gWmFuem8iLCJjbGFiTXNnVHJhY2siOiJodHRwOi8vMTcyLjE2Ljgu
MjU0OjgwODAvZW1haWwtdmlldy8zMDAwMTE2LzExMjExNy84Mjg5Mzk0IiwidGltZSI6IjIwMTUt
MDEtMTZUMTU6NDQ6MzQrMDEwMCJ9
------=_Part_139_313436665.1421664496089
Content-Type: message/vnd.msys.gcm
X-Registration-ID: APA91bEme-bKemhPberuJhjT25Z0EAd8kkwmoUblTlYk4pSwA98Wj31ki-uv3kMcghaN9U0KlyQDvh-_7Wy8VliolTONwNkW6njRqjMhQnCv4K5wsPgm5KGF5Elp2y8_sEoKRNAJToEBGLIo0HMND9aj7QFQtHsrmg
{}
------=_Part_139_313436665.1421664496089--

 

HOOK:

 

function mod:gcm_request_eval(req, msg)
 local encoding = msg:header("Content-Transfer-Encoding")
 if (string.lower(encoding[1]) == "base64") then
 local data = tostring(msys.base64.decode(string.gsub(msg:raw(), "[^\n]*:[^\n]*\n", ""), "UTF-8"))
 -- local data = tostring(msys.base64.decode(string.gsub(msg:raw(), "[^\n]*:[^\n]*\n", ""), "Latin-1"))
 local obj, code, err = json.decode(data)
 if not obj then
 error(err)
 end
 req.json.data = obj
 end
end


This work around method will be addressed in a future maintenance release.

articles.subject: How do I install Momentum 3 as standalone MTA with no clusters, webUI, or SVN?
articles.keywords: MTA, clusters, install, standalone, 3.x, standalone mta, no cluster, no webui, no svn
articles.body:
How do I install Momentum 3 as standalone MTA with no clusters, webUI, or SVN?

In some cases, it may make more sense to just have a simple barebones MTA, without adding clustering, webUI, SVN, jlogging, or any of the additional overhead that those features add. These instructions have been tested on Momentum version 3.3 and 3.6.5.
INSTALLER SCRIPT:
Run the installer ensuring that there is no current installation present and that the remaining directories have been removed if there was a previous installation.
Removal (If needed. do the following):
# ./installer --uninstall # rm -Rf /opt/msys /var/ecconfigd /var/eccluster /var/db/msyspg /var/log/ec* /var/spool/ecelerity /var/log/msyspg /var/log/spread /var/tmp/webconsole /var/db/riak
 
Run the installer:
# ./installer
The installer will present the roles available, select "mta", hit enter
database data store (max 1 per deployment) manager cluster service manager for a cluster of mtas mta for sending/receiving email singlenode standalone server (includes mta, database and web roles) web browser driven control panel
Please enter a role (hit enter when finished): mta
Selected: mta
Please enter a role (hit enter when finished):
Selection complete
Not part of a cluster, enter "n"
Is this MTA part of a cluster? (y,n) n Standalone MTA requires webui, enabling...
Hit enter to skip the IP address of the webUI, as this will be disabled later.
Please enter the hostname or IP address of the Momentum Sending Edition database machine: ()
Enter service password:
Please enter the service account password: () password
No need for SSL here, enter "n"
Do you want to require the use of SSL for accessing the webui? (y,n) n
No need for encryption here, enter "n"
Momentum Sending Edition now supports reversible encryption support to store passwords in an encrypted form on disk. Please see documentation for complete details.
No need for encrypted password support here, enter "n"
Do you want to enable encrypted password support? (y,n) n
Enter "y" if you want to have Live Bounce Updates:
Live Bounce Updates ===================
Message Systems Live Bounce Updates ensures you automatically receive the latest bounce classification rules as quickly as possible. The Live Bounce Update rule set works in conjunction with any existing user bounce override rules, with user rules taking precedence. Message Systems' support offering for the Momentum product includes the Live Bounce Updates service at no additional cost.
Live Bounce Updates is enabled by default when installing Momentum 3.1 or higher when bounce_logger is enabled in ecelerity.conf.
To help improve the effectiveness of the Live Bounce Update classification rules, you can automatically upload your anonymized bounce data to Message Systems. That data will be analyzed and used to update and improve our classification rules. For additional information on this service, or to change options at any time in the future, please see the online support documentation.
Do you want to enable LBU uploading of anonymized bounce data (Requires outbound TCP to support.messagesystems.com on port 443)? (y,n) y
Enter "y" if you plan to use Adaptive Delivery:
Adaptive Delivery Rules Update ============================== If you have Adaptive Delivery licensed and a current support contract, Momentum can be configured to automatically download and install new Adaptive Delivery rules as part of the Live Update Service. Do you want to enable automatic download of Adaptive Delivery Rules (Requires outbound TCP connections to support.messagesystems.com on port 443)? (y,n) y
Would you like to install the Ecelerity developer tools? This is only used if you compile your own extensions (y,n) n
Installing Momentum Sending Edition components... |
Enter "y" when prompted about the RIAK database being in the same data center:
Is this the first riak instance in this datacenter? (y,n) y
Enter "y" to start the services.
 
MODIFICATIONS and CONFIGURATION:
Disabling .rt Jlogs from MTA only role.
By default, Momentum 3.x tracks information about its activity in four jlogs:
/var/log/ecelerity/bouncelog.rt
/var/log/ecelerity/mainlog.rt
/var/log/ecelerity/rejectlog.rt
/var/log/ecelerity/statp.rt
(If adaptive is enabled, adaptive.rt will also exist.)
 
Disable the logging:
1. Disable Statp
In your /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf/default/ecelerity.conf file locate the following line starting with "statp" shown in this excerpt:
# Statistics producer for the web console graphs (both single instance and # cluster. # Required for the webconsole reporting to function #statp "statp" {}
Comment out the "statp" module, by inserting a hash mark (#) at the beginning of the line, as shown above.
2. Disable ec_logger_rt
Still in ecelerity.conf, locate the "ec_logger_rt" stanza which should be nearby, and should look similar to this excerpt:
# Journals information on deliveries, rejections for # consumption by ec_rt_stats2. # Required for the webconsole reporting to function #ec_logger "ec_logger_rt" { # mainlog = "jlog:///var/log/ecelerity/mainlog.rt=>ec_rt_stats" # rejectlog = "jlog:///var/log/ecelerity/rejectlog.rt=>ec_rt_stats" # log_errors = "false" #}
Comment out the entire stanza by inserting a hash mark (#) before each line, as shown above.
3. Disable bounce_logger_rt
Comment out the bounce_logger_rt stanzas in the same way as the others:
# Journals information on bounces for consumption by ec_rt_stats2 # Required for the webconsole reporting to function #bounce_logger "bounce_logger_rt" { # bouncelog = "jlog:///var/log/ecelerity/bouncelog.rt=>ec_rt_stats" #}

4. Disable adaptive.rt
If you're using adaptive, locate your adaptive stanza, and add this line to it. Add the stanza if it's not present:
adaptive { enable_jlog = false }

5. Locate the line: include "webui-common.conf", comment that out by adding a # in front of it, shown below:
#include "webui-common.conf"
