6. Commit
To finalize this you need to commit the change, like so done as root:
# /opt/msys/ecelerity/bin/eccfg commit --username ecuser --password <password> -m "Disable rtlogs and webUI related config"
Note: replace <password> with the ecuser password. If you're not using encrypted passwords you can find this in /opt/msys/etc/.svcpasswd
The -m appends a message to the committed config, so include something meaningful.

7. Disable the Cron Job
On each of the MTA nodes, edit /etc/cron.d/msys-ecelerity and comment out the following line, as shown below:
#* * * * * root /opt/msys/ecelerity/bin/ec_rt_stats2 >/dev/null 2>&1
With all of these steps completed, the nodes should no longer be writing to the *.rt jlogs, and no jobs should execute to attempt aggregating or rolling up that data.
 
8. Stop the web UI
 # /etc/init.d/ecwebconsole stop
 
9. Disable the web UI
 # chkconfig ecwebconsole off
 
10. Disable SVN
 # chkconfig ecconfigd off
 
11. Restart the server:
 # service ecelerity restart

articles.subject: How do I install Momentum 4.x in a virtual environment?
articles.keywords: virtual, Redhat64, installation, IP tables, momentum, 4.x, vm
articles.body:
How do I install Momentum 4.x in a virtual environment?
 

Note: To be used as a guide to installing Momentum 4.x in a staging or testing environment only, to familiarize yourself with the installer and the procedure only. VM installation is not recommended in a production environment.


Momentum 4 VM installation.

VM specification:

- Redhat64
- 2GB memory
- 16GB Drive space
- 2 network interfaces,1st is NAT the 2nd is "host only adapter"


OS installation:

- Basic Storage Devices
- Which type of installation would you like?
select "custom layout".
- Select the device, then click "Create a standard partition"
- Create a partition with / as the mount point, ext4 as the file system type and 12000MB as the size.
- Create a swap partition:
- Select the Free space, click create, select swap as the file system type, fill to maximum allowable size, click next, click Format.
- Install bootloader on /dev/sda
- Install as a "basic server"


OS Customizations:

- Switch off IP tables,
# chkconfig iptables off

- Switch off Postfix, 
# chkconfig postfix off

- Switch on ntpd,
# chkconfig ntpd on

- Switch off SELinux by setting it to disabled.
# vi /etc/selinux/config 

SELINUX=disabled

- Check that eth0 is set to "ONBOOT=yes" in /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-eth0

- Create new eth1 interface so ssh access is allowed from the host to the vm instance.
# vi /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-eth1
DEVICE=eth1
BOOTPROTO=static
IPADDR=192.168.56.202
NETMASK=255.255.255.0

Note:  IPADDR=192.168.xxx.yyy (this corresponds to the vboxnet0 network, mine is 192.169.56.100, so an IP from 101 and onwards)
NETMASK=255.255.255.0

- Add the IP address and hostname to /etc/hosts
# vi /etc/hosts
<IP_ADDRESS> <$hostname>

- Restart the network making sure both eth0 and eth1 come up
#  /etc/init.d/networking restart

- ping an internet address to check external connectivity

Add the following to /etc/rc.local

# Momo 4.0 - Vertica
echo deadline > /sys/block/sda/queue/scheduler
/sbin/blockdev --setra 2048 /dev/sda
/sbin/blockdev --setra 2048 /dev/sda1
/sbin/blockdev --setra 2048 /dev/sda2
# Disable transparent_hugepage
if test -f /sys/kernel/mm/transparent_hugepage/enabled; then
 echo never > /sys/kernel/mm/transparent_hugepage/enabled
fi

Add the following to /etc/sysctl.conf

# Momentum 4 specific
net.ipv4.tcp_tw_reuse = 1
net.ipv4.tcp_tw_recycle = 1
net.core.somaxconn = 1024
net.core.rmem_max = 262144
vm.max_map_count = 768000
net.core.wmem_max = 262144

Important:  REBOOT the system.

The instance should be accessible via ssh

- Remove openjdk
- Confirm if any openjdk packages are installed by running;
# rpm -qa | grep openjdk

- To remove them, execute the following command, repeating it until all the openjdk packages are removed.
# yum remove $package_name 


- Installing the Java Runtime Enviromment (JRE)
- Download the rpm from the Oracle downloads page: http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/downloads/index.html

To install Oracle's Java go to Downloads and download version 7 the JRE RPM for 64 bit Linux.  

- Download the .rpm JRE file: jre-7-linux-x64.rpm
- Install it as follows:
# sudo rpm -Uvh jre-$version-linux-x64.rpm


Momentum Installation:

 # cd /root

- Unpack the archive:
# tar zxvf momentum-4$

- Change into the newly created directory:
 # cd momentum-4$

- Change the validate_vertica_node script's permissions to executable:
 # chmod +x validate_vertica_node

- Run the script, if given the "all clear" proceed to install momentum: 

 # ./validate_vertica_node, 

- Run the installer:

 # ./installer

Enter prompted for information:

Multiple servers? n
Enable Message Generation support (requires additional license)? n (this is for Message Central)
Do you want to enable secure credentials? n
Enter passwords
Confirm services
Confirm reporting UI and REST end points

Open a new shell session and copy licence file to /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/ before starting the services.

- Add paths to /etc/init.d/msys-cassandra for the java_home variable if issues arise starting Cassandra:
 
Add the following line: PATH=/bin:/usr/bin:/sbin:/usr/sbin:/usr/java/jre1.7.0/bin/  just below the line:

CASS_PID=/var/run/cassandra/cassandra.pid

then start the Cassandra process:
 
# /etc/init.d/msys-cassandra start

If all went well you should see something like;

riak: starting
Starting ecconfigd: done.
Starting Vertica: [ OK ]
Starting API Process: [ OK ]
Starting nginx: [ OK ]
Starting rabbitmq-server: [ OK ]
Starting ETL Process: [ OK ]
Starting cassandra: ........ [ OK ]
Pulling latest config files from repo
Running startup includes (if any)
Starting Ecelerity: 31371


Welcome to Momentum!
You have made the following selections:
Single node install: mom4-test

Services:
Reporting UI: http://mom4-test
REST endpoints: http://mom4-test:8081

Note:  "mom4-test" is the hostname I chose when setting up Linux.

- Install telnet for testing, yum install -y telnet

articles.subject: How Do I Install Unbound?
articles.keywords: Unbound, systemctl, installation, 3.x, Momentum, 4.x, dns, resolver
articles.body:
How Do I Install Unbound?
 

How Do I Install “unbound” in Momentum 3.x?

The Unbound package can be installed via yum as shown below:

yum install unbound -y

Once installation has completed, enable the service so that it starts on boot, and start the service up now as shown.

[root@centos ~]# systemctl enable unbound
ln -s '/usr/lib/systemd/system/unbound.service' '/etc/systemd/system/multi-user.target.wants/unbound.service'
[root@centos ~]# systemctl start unbound


By default Unbound will only be listening for requests on localhost. This can be demonstrated using the netstat command. As you can see below, unbound is listening on localhost for IPv4 and IPv6 on TCP and UDP using port 53.

[root@centos ~]# netstat -antpu | grep unbound
tcp        0      0 127.0.0.1:53            0.0.0.0:*               LISTEN      21026/unbound
tcp6       0      0 ::1:53                  :::*                    LISTEN      21026/unbound
udp        0      0 127.0.0.1:53            0.0.0.0:*                           21026/unbound
udp6       0      0 ::1:53                  :::*                                21026/unbound

Since this is not very useful, we will need to make changes to the unbound.conf file. You can find unbound.con at “/etc/unbound/unbound.conf”. Inside your unbound.conf file, you will want to add the following line:

interface: 0.0.0.0

This line will configure Unbound to listen on all available network interfaces. It is suggested that you go through the unbound.conf file to get familiar with the options available within. The document is very well documented and does a good job at providing further information you might need that is not covered in this article.

By default, Unbound will deny all recursive queries from any client unless we specifically allow an IP address or range of IP addresses. To do this, you will want to add an ACL entry within the unbound.conf file as shown below:

access-control: 192.168.0.0/24 allow

This will allow remote hosts in the 192.168.0.0/24 network to make recursive queries to this server, specify your IP address range here.

Next we need to create a forward zone which will specify the external DNS server to send the queries to. For this example, we will use Google’s public DNS resolver (8.8.8.8). Forward zones are again created in the /etc/unbound/unbound.conf file as shown:

forward-zone:
  name: "."
  forward-addr: 8.8.8.8

By naming the forward-zone “.” we are saying to forward all queries. This can be changed to a specific domain name to only forward queries for that specific domain to the address set.

Save all of these changes that have been made and then restart the unbound service to apply them.

systemctl restart unbound

At this point you can optionally run netstat again to confirm that Unbound is correctly listening on 0.0.0.0:53 rather than localhost.

The last step is to set up your resolv.conf file to point locally. To do this, simply open resolv.conf (located in your /etc/ directory) and add a line at the top that says:

nameserver 127.0.0.1

Unbound should now be properly set up and you should now all set.

 

How Do I Use “unbound” in Momentum 4.x?

In order to use unbound as the underlying resolved in Momentum 4.x is a lot easier than using it in Momentum 3.x. In order to achieve this lease review the following page from the Messagesystems support documentation: https://support.messagesystems.com/docs/web-momo4/environment_file.php

Please note if you are using 4.2 hf11 or earlier, then it is recommend that you upgrade to 4.2 hf12 see the DNAME issue mentioned in the changelog for 4.2 hf12 here : https://support.messagesystems.com/start.php?show=changelog&v=4

articles.subject: How do I list users for the Web UI in Momentum 4?
articles.keywords: list, update_user.js, Cassandra
articles.body:
How do I list users for the Web UI in Momentum 4?

 

In order to retrieve a list of users for the Momentum 4 WebUI, you will need to query the Cassandra database on the node that is hosting the Web UI. You will need to run the following commands: 

# cd /opt/msys/3rdparty/bin

# ./cqlsh

From the Cassandra CQL shell, please run:

# use authentication;

# select * from users;

Please note, this will not allow you to retrieve the password for the users listed, as the passwords are hashed with a salt. In order to provide access to a user with a lost password, you will need to use reset their password with the update_user.js.

articles.subject: How do I lock down SMTP AUTH to be available just on encrypted connections?
articles.keywords: SMTP, AUTH, scriptlet, tls_before_auth.lua, encrypted connections,
articles.body:
How do I lock down SMTP AUTH to be available just on encrypted connections?

To apply the patch to the Lua module msys.extended.ac (required): 
# Back up:
cp /opt/msys/ecelerity/libexec/scriptlets/msys/extended/ac.lua   /opt/msys/ecelerity/libexec/scriptlets/msys/extended/ac.lua.bak

patch -i /path/to/msys-extended-ac-tls-before-auth.patch   /opt/msys/ecelerity/libexec/scriptlets/msys/extended/ac.lua

Then put tls_before_auth.lua in /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf/default and update ecelerity.conf to load it:

scriptlet "scriptlet" {
  script "tls_before_auth" {
    source = "tls_before_auth"
  }
}

and then run:

/opt/msys/ecelerity/bin/ec_console /tmp/2025 config reload

or restart the ecelerity service, to pick up the changes. (A reload should be enough.)

Some things to note:

  • When this is enabled, AUTH will not be advertised in the initial EHLO response.
  • When this is enabled, AUTH will be advertised in the response to EHLO after the STARTTLS command has completed.
  • The customer should warn its customers about this change. Since they did not require TLS beforehand, customers may have been using AUTH without TLS. Those customers will find that their mail is no longer accepted by the system, until they update their SMTP clients to use TLS.

To back out the change:

1. Remove scriptlet configuration that loads tls_before_auth.
2. Revert patch to msys.extended.ac:

cp /opt/msys/ecelerity/libexec/scriptlets/msys/extended/ac.lua.bak   /opt/msys/ecelerity/libexec/scriptlets/msys/extended/ac.lua
</snip>


msys-extended-ac-tls-before-auth.patch content:

<snip>

diff --git a/modules/scriptlets/msys/extended/ac.lua b/modules/scriptlets/msys/extended/ac.lua
--- a/modules/scriptlets/msys/extended/ac.lua
+++ b/modules/scriptlets/msys/extended/ac.lua
@@ -1,4 +1,4 @@
--- Copyright (c) 2009-2011 Message Systems, Inc. All rights reserved
+-- Copyright (c) 2009-2015 Message Systems, Inc. All rights reserved
 --
 -- THIS IS UNPUBLISHED PROPRIETARY SOURCE CODE OF MESSAGE SYSTEMS
 -- The copyright notice above does not evidence any
@@ -14,9 +14,9 @@

 local ipv6_pcre = "^(((?=(?>.*?::)(?!.*::)))(::)?([0-9A-Fa-f]{1,4}::?){0,5}|([0-9A-Fa-f]{1,4}:){6})(\\2([0-9A-Fa-f]{1,4}(::?|$)){0,2}|((25[0-5]|(2[0-4]|1[0-9]|[1-9])?[0-9])(\\.|$)){4}|[0-9A-Fa-f]{1,4}:[0-9A-Fa-f]{1,4})(?<![^:]:)(?<!\\.)\\z";

-function ac:esmtp_capability_add(name)
+function ac:esmtp_capability_get(name)
   if (type(name) != "string") then
-    error("esmtp_capability_add requires one string argument");
+    error("esmtp_capability_get requires one string argument");
   end

   local mstruct = msys.core.accept_construct_get_message_construct(self);
@@ -24,7 +24,27 @@
     error("message construct is not found within the accept construct.");
   end
   local caps = mstruct.smtp_capabilities;
-  msys.core.dict_add_key_value(caps, name, "");
+  local _, val = msys.core.dict_key_exists_and_fetch(caps, name);
+  return val;
+end
+
+function ac:esmtp_capability_add(name, val)
+  if (type(name) != "string") then
+    error("esmtp_capability_add requires a string argument");
+  end
+  if val ~= nil and type(val) ~= "string" then
+    error("esmtp_capability_add requires a string argument for the value");
+  end
+  if val == nil then
+    val = ""
+  end
+
+  local mstruct = msys.core.accept_construct_get_message_construct(self);
+  if (mstruct == nil) then
+    error("message construct is not found within the accept construct.");
+  end
+  local caps = mstruct.smtp_capabilities;
+  msys.core.dict_add_key_value(caps, name, val);
   return 1;
 end

</snip>


tls_before_auth.lua contents:


 

<snip>

-- Copyright (c) 2015 Message Systems, Inc. All rights reserved
--
-- THIS IS UNPUBLISHED PROPRIETARY SOURCE CODE OF MESSAGE SYSTEMS
-- The copyright notice above does not evidence any
-- actual or intended publication of such source code.
--
-- Redistribution of this material is strictly prohibited.

-- Require TLS for SMTP traffic before accepting SMTP AUTH commands.
-- TLS is expected to be started with STARTTLS.

local core = require("msys.core")
local ext_ac = require("msys.extended.ac")

local vctx_key = "#old_esmtp_capabilities"

local mod = {}

function mod:validate_connect(ac, vctx)
  local oldval = ac:esmtp_capability_get("AUTH")
  if oldval ~= nil then
    vctx:set(core.VCTX_CONN, vctx_key, oldval)
  end

  -- NOTE: ac:esmtp_capability_remove() does not provide a way of removing
  -- a capability with an argument, so we remove all AUTH commands,
  -- and restore them later.
  ac:esmtp_capability_remove("AUTH")
end

function mod:validate_ehlo(ehlo_str, ac, vctx)
  local e = vctx.session
  local _, oldval = vctx:exists_and_get(core.VCTX_CONN, vctx_key)

  if e == nil or oldval == nil then
    return
  end
  if core.ec_ssl_is_event_ssl(e) == 1 then
    ac:esmtp_capability_add("AUTH", oldval)
  end
end

function mod:validate_data_spool_each_rcpt(msg, ac, vctx)
  msg:context_delete(core.ECMESS_CTX_CONN, vctx_key)
end

msys.registerModule("tls_before_auth", mod)

</snip>

articles.subject: How do I log headers to a custom log via sieve?
articles.keywords: sieve, X-SendingIP, headers,
articles.body:
How do I log headers to a custom log via sieve?

When using the custom_logger module, the option exists to use %h{header} to log headers to your custom log. However, using this method is very resource intensive, and in high volume environments, can cause watchdog restarts with the ecelerity process. So how do we get around this? By setting context variables via sieve, then using the %vctx_mess{variable} option to log that variable. This is exponentially more efficient, while logging the same data.

In these examples, we'll assume messages are being injected with an X header called X-SendingIP.

In order to perform this using sieve, use the following format to set the context variable based on the header you want to log. This can be implemented in any phase, though each_rcpt is most commonly used.

$hdr1 = ec_header_get "X-SendingIP";
vctx_mess_set "X-SendingIP" "${hdr1}";

In this bit of code, the local variable is $hdr1 who's value is pulled by the ec_header_get function. In this case the X-SendingIP header from the actual message. Next, the vctx_mess_set creates a context variable named "X-SendingIP", who's value is the local variable $hdr1.

Then, in your custom logger stanza, instead of using %h{X-SendingIP}, you would use %vctx_mess{X-SendingIP}:

custom_logger "custom_logger1" {
  delivery_logfile = "/var/log/ecelerity/delivery_log"
  delivery_format = "%t %r@%R@%vctx_mess{X-SendingIP}"
}

At this point you're all set. The above can be implemented in any environment, and for any header, simply by replacing name of the header called by ec_header_get.

articles.subject: How do I manually consume Jlogs?
articles.keywords: Jlog, /var/log/ecelerity, backlog
articles.body:
How do I manually consume Jlogs?
 

Symptoms:

/var/log/ecelerity is continuously expanding. Jlogs are not being consumed and a large backlog is being created.

Cause:

Jlogs are not being consumed as normal, for what ever reason.
Jlogs, by their design and nature are somewhat prone to corruption and inconsistencies and need a bit of manual intervention occasionally to help them along when they stop functioning as  intended.  
We've developed and included tools to analyse and repair them, the jlog_sanity_check and jlogctl.  In some cases we needed to manually process the file by forcing X amount (100000 in this example) passes which will consume the file as expected.  The "p 100000" switch indicates the amount of passes to be done.
 

Steps to remedy the situation:

First, run the sanity check to inspect contents and report any inconsistencies or errors it finds.  If there is no terminal output the log is ok.  If not, the log is in need of repair.

 # /opt/msys/jlog/bin/jlog_sanity_check le /var/log/ecelerity/mainlog.rt/

Next, run the repair on the affected log.  You will need to stop the ecelerity process before repairing the jlog. The results of this are a mixed bag, some times the repair process works, some times not.   The -r switch repairs and the -v displays verbose information while doing so.

 

# /etc/init.d/ecelerity stop
# /opt/msys/jlog/bin/jlogctl -r -v /var/log/ecelerity/mainlog.rt/
# /etc/init.d/ecelerity start

 

To manually consume a jlog, we use the ec_rt_stats2 process.


 
 # /opt/msys/ecelerity/bin/ec_rt_stats2 /var/log/ecelerity/mainlog.rt/

 

Before manually running the ec_rt_stats2 command we need to disable the cron job that controls it and check that it is not already running, do the following:

1. Disable the cron job:

 # vi /etc/cron.d/msys-ecelerity

Place a hash # in front of the line as follows:  

 # * * * * * root /opt/msys/ecelerity/bin/ec_rt_stats2 >/dev/null 2>&1


2. Save and exit the file

 

3. Check that it is not currently running:

 # ps afx | grep ec_rt_stats2

4.  If the process is running, it should appear in the list.  To kill it do:

 #  kill -9 <process ID>


5.  To be sure it is not running, again do:  


 
 # ps afx | grep ec_rt_stats2 

 

6.  To manually consume the jlog file by doing multiple passes if the default value is not consuming the data fast enough, the following command can be used to consume the backlog.  The cron job must be disabled while this is process is running:

 # /opt/msys/ecelerity/bin/ec_rt_stats2 -v -p 100000 /var/log/ecelerity/mainlog.rt

 

As mentioned above under the Cause heading,  in some cases we needed to manually process the file by forcing X amount (100000 in this example) passes which will consume the file as expected.  The "p 100000" switch indicates the amount of passes to be done.

Note:
Please allow a considerable amount of time for this process to complete. The larger the directory size the more time it will take. The value of 100000 was used on a directory of ~ 170GB. So a lower number of passes can be specified for a smaller amount of disk usage.

 

If something like the snippet below is displayed, the log is being processed at the default rate of 10 minutes of data per 10 minute window.

The manual page states:

ec_rt_stats2 will keep processing windows of data until either
it reaches an incomplete window, or has processed the number of
windows specified by this option. The default is 10, meaning
that it will try to consume 10 minutes of data on each run. This
should not normally need to be changed, but altering this value
can be useful if for some reason stats processing has fallen
behind; you might consider running it by hand with a high
--passes value.


 

[root@mta2 ecelerity]# /opt/msys/ecelerity/bin/ec_rt_stats2 -v /var/log/ecelerity/mainlog.rt/
Considering window starting at 2015-01-16 23:00:00
processed 1 lines from /var/log/ecelerity/mainlog.rt
processed 1 lines from /var/log/ecelerity/bouncelog.rt
processed 1 lines from /var/log/ecelerity/rejectlog.rt
processed 7 lines from /var/log/ecelerity/statp.rt
Checkpointing /var/log/ecelerity/mainlog.rt at 00000000:0000016b.
Checkpointing /var/log/ecelerity/bouncelog.rt at 00000000:00000483.
Checkpointing /var/log/ecelerity/rejectlog.rt at 00000000:00000483.
Checkpointing /var/log/ecelerity/statp.rt at 00000000:00001f3f.
Trying another pass.
Considering window starting at 2015-01-16 23:01:00
Not enough data in window for mainlog
System health updated.

 


7.  We need to re-enable the cron, if all is well.  To do that, just remove the # from the line in the cron:

 # vi /etc/cron.d/msys-ecelerity


 Remove the hash symbol # from the line so it is as follows :  

 * * * * * root /opt/msys/ecelerity/bin/ec_rt_stats2 >/dev/null 2>&1

8.  Save and exit the file.

 


As a final step, removing the broken directory / directories if repairing fails.
 

1. Stop ecelerity:

 # /etc/init.d/ecelerity stop

2. Remove mainlog.rt or any other .rt directory:

 # rm -rf /var/log/ecelerity/mainlog.rt/

3. Restart ececerity:

 # /etc/init.d/ecelerity start

articles.subject: How Do I Manually Pull a License for 3.x?
articles.keywords: License, /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/ , ecelerity
articles.body:
How Do I Manually Pull a License for 3.x?
 

Overview

There are several ways to go about pulling a license for Momentum/Message Central. Each method has been outlined below.

Using the Provided Utilities

Both Momentum and Message Central provide a utility named ec_lic (located in: /opt/msys/ecelerity/bin) that will attempt to pull a license for each MAC address on the system if a license is not already present. Once it does find a match, it will automatically name it "license" and place it in the /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/ directory. If a license is already on the server, then it will need to be renamed or (re)moved.

Renaming a License

The first step is to back-up the existing license and move it out of the way.

mv /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/license /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/license.saved

Fetching a License

The next command will attempt to match one of the available MAC addresses with a license and fetch it (over HTTP on TCP port 80, to licenses.messagesystems.com). It is not necessary to restart Momentum in order to use the new license once it is retrieved.

/opt/msys/ecelerity/bin/ec_lic -f

Note on Using ec_lic:

A recently updated license may not be immediately available to this utility. If a license change or renewal occurs, then please wait a few minutes before attempting to pull. 

Manually Pulling a License

Should the automated method fail, it is still possible to manually retrieve the license. There are two ways to go about doing this. However, you must first determine the appropriate license URL. 

Determining the License URL

  1. Manually converting the MAC address.
    1. Find out what the MAC address is. This will be listed in your current license, if you have one, or using "ifconfig". (e.g., E7:49:45:AC:0D:64)
    2. Convert all uppercase letters to lowercase. (e.g., e7:49:45:ac:0d:64)
    3. Remove the colons between each pair of hexadecimal digits. (e.g., e74945ac0d64)
    4. Append that string to the end of: http://licenses.messagesystems.com/all/<MAC>. (e.g., http://licenses.messagesystems.com/all/e74945ac0d64)

Manually Pulling a License

You are welcome to manually download the license using wget or curl. 

Using wget

If the customer prefers to use wget, then they can download and rename the file using a single command.

wget -O /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/license http://licenses.messagesystems.com/all/<MAC>
Using curl

If the customer prefers to use curl, then they can download and rename the file using a single command as well.

curl -o /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/license http://licenses.messagesystems.com/all/<MAC>

articles.subject: How do I migrate a cluster manager to new hardware?
articles.keywords: cluster, nodes, cron, riak, /etc/cron.d/msys-ecelerity, ip, eccfg, ecconfigd
articles.body:
How do I migrate a cluster manager to new hardware?
 
  1. On each of the MTA nodes in the cluster, disable the cron jobs that pull configuration from the manager
    • /etc/cron.d/msys-ecelerity
    • /opt/msys/ecelerity/bin/eccfg pull
    • /opt/msys/ecelerity/bin/lu_pull
  2. On the old manager, make a copy of /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/ and place it in a safe location.
  3. Remove .svn, and .eccfg subdirectories as well as the mbus.conf file from the configuration backup. (Check this next command without the -exec part first to verify what it will delete!)
    • [root@localhost /root/backup]# find /path/to/backup -type d -name .svn -exec rm -rf {} \;
  4. Copy the /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc directory over to the new manager (into /tmp for example)
  5. Leave the riak ring on the old manager:/opt/msys/3rdParty/riak/bin/riak-admin leave
  6. Stop services on the old manager:
    • /etc/init.d/cidr_server stop
    • /etc/init.d/ecwebconsole stop
    • /etc/init.d/eccmgr stop
    • /etc/init.d/ecconfigd stop
    • /etc/init.d/msyspg stop
    • /etc/init.d/ec_cmd stop
    • /etc/init.d/msys-riak stop
  7. Shutdown the old manager (or unplug from network, or otherwise make existing IPs available for the new manager)
  8. Add the old manager's IP to the new manager and ensure the new manager has the same hostname as the old manager
  9. Verify the hosts file on the new manager is correct and can resolve the names of all of the nodes in the cluster (localhost should not include hostname)
  10. Install Momentum on the new manager:
    • Install with database and manager roles, and all the same options as the original installation on the old manager (including passwords)
    • Include all of the nodes and manager in the node list
    • Do not start services
  11. Move the configuration files into place on the new manager
  12. Start Ecconfigd and commit
  13. Start the remaining services on the manager
  14. If you're using DuraVIPs, stop the ecelerity process on all of the nodes (at the same time)
  15. On each node, move the configuration files out of the way, bootstrap from the manager, and start the ecelerity process:
    • mv /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/oldconf
    • /opt/msys/ecelerity/bin/eccfg bootstrap --username <username> --password <password> --clustername <clustername> <clustermanager>
  16. Ensure the riak ring is functional using status command
  17. Ensure all nodes can see each other using the "cluster membership" and "show cluster membership" ec_console commands
  18. Uncomment the cron commands on the nodes (see step 1)

articles.subject: How do I Move Messages in Spool to a Different Instance of Momentum?
articles.keywords: Spool, Instance, Import, export, move, messages, var, ecelerity
articles.body:
How do I Move Messages in Spool to a Different Instance of Momentum?

If you have remaining messages in the spool during but are doing an upgrade, clean install, hardware migration, or a disaster happens, you will need to export the spool and import it to the new instance/cluster. To export, copy the existing spool, /var/spool/ecelerity/*, to a temporary directory of your choice on the new MTA. You can then use the Spool Import function to add the messages into the new spool. We also advise turning on the import log (importlog.ec). This will log the old message information along with the new message ID that will be assigned during import so it will be useful should you need to locate anything post-import. If the import is successful you will see entries in this log. If this is empty then your import has failed. 

For more information on Spool Import and the import log, please search 'spool import' and 'ec_logger import log' in our support documentation.

articles.subject: How do I rebuild the SVN repository?
articles.keywords: SVN, repository, ecelerity, eccfg, svn, repo, momentum, configuration, ecconfig, default, global
articles.body:
How do I rebuild the SVN repository?

1. Disable the cron jobs on all nodes (including manager) in /etc/cron.d/msys-ecelerity (/etc/cron.d/msys-ecelerity-cluster-mgr on the manager)
This prevents a node from accidentally pulling down an incomplete set of config files.

# /opt/msys/ecelerity/bin/eccfg pull --auto 
# /opt/msys/ecelerity/bin/eccfg put running 

2. Stop ecconfigd, remove the .eccfg directory under /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc and the cluster.boot file, and start ecconfigd (ecconfigd only applies to manager - on the nodes skip that part)

/etc/init.d/ecconfigd stop
rm -Rf /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/.eccfg /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/cluster.boot
/etc/init.d/ecconfigd start

3. Move the old conf directory out of the way so we can checkout a clean copy from the new repository.

mv /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf.old

4. Now we can bootstrap the manager so we have a checkout of the new repository. This will contain only the default files at this point. Replace "manager" with the correct manager name.

/opt/msys/ecelerity/bin/eccfg bootstrap --clustername=default manager

5. Copy the old config files into the new conf directory. The old conf directory is going to have .svn metadata directories that we do not want to copy. They will break the checkout directory so we must not copy them over. rsync will help us with this.

rsync -var --exclude='.svn' /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf.old/ /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf/

6. Make sure all the files were copied of successfully. Use the following command but you may need to drill down into subdirectories.

ls -la /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf/

7. Your conf directory should now have all your old config files. Commit the changes to the repository

/opt/msys/ecelerity/bin/eccfg -u admin commit

8. Re-enable cron jobs from step #1 on all nodes

/etc/cron.d/msys-ecelerity
/opt/msys/ecelerity/bin/eccfg pull --auto 
/opt/msys/ecelerity/bin/eccfg put running 

If all is working correctly you should now repeat steps 2 - 4 on each of the MTA nodes in the cluster. This will put the new repository in place on the nodes. The old repository will not be compatible with the new one and will prevent the nodes from pulling down config changes. Restart ecelerity on each node after confirming the checkout was successful.

articles.subject: How do I remove a node from a 3.x cluster?
articles.keywords: riak, msgc, ring_members, node, cluster, remove, leaving
articles.body:
How do I remove a node from a 3.x cluster?

There are 2 pieces to complete when wanting to remove an MTA node from a 3.x cluster:
  1. Removal from the riak ring
  2. Removal from the msgc cluster


Leaving the riak ring / Removing a node from the riak ring

For the first part, it is as easy as issuing a command from the node to be removed, to leave the riak ring: 
/opt/msys/3rdParty/riak/bin/riak-admin leave
At this point, the node has been removed and you can proceed to the configuration modification steps further down below.

If for some reason, the node to be removed is unavailable, perhaps due to hardware failure, you can run the following command from any of the other nodes in the cluster. First, you will need to run the following command to find the full name of the node as it exists in the riak ring: 
/opt/msys/3rdParty/riak/bin/riak-admin status
In the returned output, look for the line containing the ring_members like so: 
ring_members : ['riak-default@10.70.20.129','riak-default@10.70.20.131', ... ]
Once you have determined the 'name' of the node you want to remove, you can run the following command to removed said member from the ring: 
/opt/msys/3rdParty/riak/bin/riak-admin remove riak-default@10.40.20.131
At this point, the node has been successfully removed from the riak ring, and you can proceed to modifying your actual Momentum configuration to instantiate the removal.
 

Removing an MTA node from the Momentum configuration

After completing the riak portion, go ahead and shut down all services on the node to be removed. Assuming duravip'd bindings and/or listeners are in use, this will allow them to move to one of the active nodes in the cluster. At this point you will want to update any duravips that were preferenced to the node to be removed, changing them to an active node in the cluster.

Next, you will want to remove the node from the peer list in the msgc_server.conf located in /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf/global/: 
# NOTE: This file MUST live in the global portion of the repository, as it
# must be the same for all nodes in the cluster.

msgc_server {
   peers = [
        mta01 = "10.40.0.178"
        mta02 = "10.40.0.179"
        manager = "10.40.0.177"

   ]
}

MSGCServer_Listener {
   Listen ":4809" { }
}

# vim:ts=2:sw=2:et:ft=conf:
Once you have updated your duravips, and removed the node from the peers list, you can proceed to commit the change to the repository.

For this type of change, it is recommended that a restart of services on the remaining MTA nodes be performed, to ensure the changes are instantiated.

articles.subject: How do I remove a SMTP extension (PIPELINING, 8BITMIME, for example) from showing up after the EHLO?
articles.keywords: PIPELINING, 8BITMIME, EHLO, SMTP
articles.body:
How do I remove a SMTP extension (PIPELINING, 8BITMIME, for example) from showing up after the EHLO?

If you use Lua, you can use:

https://support.messagesystems.com/docs/web-ref/lua.ref.ac_esmtp_capability_remove.php

If you Sieve, you can use:

https://support.messagesystems.com/docs/web-ref/sieve.ref.disable_esmtp_capability.php

articles.subject: How do I replay RabbitMQ statistics files after downtime or a crash?
articles.keywords: RabbitMQ, downtime, ecelerity, crash, event, hose, failed, outage, vertica, metrics, etls, webhooks
articles.body:
How do I replay RabbitMQ statistics files after downtime or a crash?

Replaying / Injecting Jlogs into RabbitMQ after it was down or unavailable for what ever reason.

Affected versions: 4.0 and 4.1

On the affected node, we want to see a directory listing and word count of: /var/log/ecelerity/event_host_failed.rt

$ ls -lah /var/log/ecelerity/event_hose_failed.rt | wc -l

If there is output, then we know that there are rabbitMQ files that contain WebUI statistics that need to be replayed or injected into RabbitMQ.

If the output is : cannot access /var/log/ecelerity/event_hose_failed.rt: No such file or directory0
there is nothing to be replayed.

To replay, create a file called  /opt/msys/ecelerity/bin/replay_event_hose_failed with the following contents

Everything below this line:


#!/opt/msys/3rdParty/bin/perl
#
# Copyright (c) 2015 Message Systems, Inc. All rights reserved
#
# THIS IS UNPUBLISHED PROPRIETARY SOURCE CODE OF MESSAGE SYSTEMS
# The copyright notice above does not evidence any
# actual or intended publication of such source code.
#
# Redistribution of this material is strictly prohibited.
#
# vim:ts=2:sw=2:et:
#

use strict;
use warnings;
use Net::RabbitMQ;
use JLog::Reader;
use JSON;
use IO::File;
use Getopt::Std;

my $default_log = '/var/log/ecelerity/event_hose_failed.rt';

my %options=();
getopts("l:s:h", \%options);

if ($options{'h'}) {
    print "Usage: $0 [ -h ] [ -l logfileJlogOrFlatfile ] [ -s serverIp ]\n";
    print "      Where the default logfile is $default_log\n";
    print "      And the default serverIp is 127.0.0.1\n\n";
    print "      Or use -h to see this help message\n\n";
    exit 0;
}



my $log = $options{'l'} || $default_log;
my $rabbitpw = decrypt(')<#$M5FLP;%AY');
my $host = $options{'s'} || '127.0.0.1';



# Select a set of file I/O "methods" based upon the filetype of $log
my $methods = get_methods($log);

my $mq = Net::RabbitMQ->new();

$mq->connect($host, {
  user => 'rabbitmq',
  password => $rabbitpw
});

my $channel = 1;
$mq->channel_open($channel);
my $r = $methods->{_open}($log);
my $n = 0; # lines
my $n_inserted = 0;
my $aborted = 0;

while (my $line = $methods->{_read}($r)) {
  ++$n;
  $line =~ s/\n+//;
  next if ($line =~ /^\s*$/);

  my $obj;
  eval {
    $obj = decode_json($line);
  };
  if ($@) {
    next;
  } 
  my $msys = $obj->{msys};
  if (!defined $msys) {
    chomp($line);
    print STDERR "ABORTING at record/line $n: msys key not found in: $line\n";
    $aborted = 1;
    last;
  }

  my @ks = keys(%{ $msys });
  my $key = $ks[0];
  if (!defined $key) {
    chomp($line);
    print STDERR "ABORTING at record/line $n: Could not determine key in: $line\n";
    $aborted = 1;
    last;
  }

  my $event = $msys->{$key};
  my $customer_id = $event->{customer_id};
  if (!defined $customer_id) {
    chomp($line);
    print STDERR "ABORTING at record/line $n: Could not determine customer_id: $line\n";
    $aborted = 1;
    last;
  }
  my $event_type = $event->{type};
  if (!defined $event_type) {
    chomp($line);
    print STDERR "ABORTING at record/line $n: Could not determine event type: $line\n";
    $aborted = 1;
    last;
  }

  # Based on the C code in modules/logging/mo_logging/mo_write_rabbitmq.c
  # (the event_hose module).
  my $routing_key = get_routing_key($customer_id, $event_type);
  $mq->publish(
    $channel, $routing_key, $line,
    { exchange => 'momentum_metrics' },
    { content_type => 'application/json', delivery_mode => 2 },
  );
  #print STDERR "$routing_key\n";
  #print "$key " . substr($line, 0, 20) . "\n";

  # We checkpoint after every record. It might be more efficient
  # to checkpoint batches of events. But use a simple solution,
  # since RabbitMQ failures should be rare.
  $methods->{_checkpoint}($r);
  ++$n_inserted;

  if (($n_inserted % 500) == 0) {
    print STDERR "$n_inserted records inserted into RabbitMQ\n";

    # Sleep every so often, to avoid overwhelming the target server.
    my $delay = 1;
    print STDERR "Sleeping $delay seconds\n";
    sleep($delay);
  }
}

print STDERR "$n lines seen\n";
print STDERR "$n_inserted records inserted into RabbitMQ\n";
if (!$aborted) {
  print STDERR "COMPLETED\n";
}

$mq->disconnect();
undef $r;
if ($aborted) {
  exit 1;
}

#
# This routing key follows a convention observed for Platform->App
# communication via RabbitMQ
#
sub get_routing_key {
  my ($customer_id, $event_type) = @_;
  return sprintf("msys.%d.%s", $customer_id, $event_type);
}

sub open_jlog {
  my ($log) = @_;

  my $r = JLog::Reader->new($log);
  $r->open('event_consumer');
  # Make absolutely sure we don't auto-checkpoint.
  # We want to checkpoint after we've got the event into RabbitMQ.
  $r->auto_checkpoint(0);

  return $r;
}

sub read_jlog {
  my ($r) = @_;
  return $r->read();
}

sub checkpoint_jlog {
  my ($r) = @_;
  $r->checkpoint();
}

sub open_file {
  my ($log) = @_;

  my $fh = IO::File->new("<$log") or die "Failed to open $log: $!";
  return $fh;
}

sub read_file {
  my ($r) = @_;
  return $r->getline();
}

sub checkpoint_file {
}

#
# return a set of FILE I/O methods based upon log-file type
#
sub get_methods {
  my ($log) = @_;
  my $jlog_methods = {
    _open => \&open_jlog,
    _read => \&read_jlog,
    _checkpoint => \&checkpoint_jlog,
  };
  my $file_methods = {
    _open => \&open_file,
    _read => \&read_file,
    _checkpoint => \&checkpoint_file,
  };
  my $methods;

  if ($log =~ /\.rt/i or $log =~ /\.jlog/i or $log =~ /\.cluster/i) {
    $methods = $jlog_methods;
  } else {
    $methods = $file_methods;
  }
  return $methods;
}


# Copied from installer.pl
sub decrypt {
  return unpack(chr(ord('a') + 19 + print ''),shift);
}
Make the script executable:

$ chmod +x replay_event_hose_failed

To run the script execute the following:

$ /opt/msys/ecelerity/bin/replay_event_hose_failed /var/log/ecelerity/event_hose_failed.rt 

Please bear in mind that this process may take some time to complete.

articles.subject: How do I restart all Momentum services on a single node installation or on a manager / node in 3.x releases?
articles.keywords: restart, node, ecwebconsole, singlenode, stop, start, 3.x, 3
articles.body:
How do I restart all Momentum services on a single node installation or on a manager / node in 3.x releases?
 
Standalone Shutdown/Startup Order

Shutdown:

/etc/init.d/cidr_server stop
/etc/init.d/ecwebconsole stop
/etc/init.d/ecelerity stop
/etc/init.d/ecconfigd stop
/etc/init.d/msyspg stop
/etc/init.d/ec_cmd stop
/etc/init.d/msys-riak stop

Startup:

/etc/init.d/msys-riak start
/etc/init.d/ec_cmd start
/etc/init.d/msyspg start
/etc/init.d/ecconfigd start
/etc/init.d/ecelerity start
/etc/init.d/ecwebconsole start
/etc/init.d/cidr_server start
Cluster Manager Shutdown/Startup order

This includes the mbusd_monitor in order to allow for older 3.x (before 3.4) have the service restarted. This is a universal script that ensures all servers will stop and start correctly.

Shutdown:

/etc/init.d/cidr_server stop
/etc/init.d/ecwebconsole stop
/etc/init.d/eccmgr stop
/etc/init.d/ecconfigd stop
/etc/init.d/msyspg stop
/etc/init.d/ec_cmd stop
/etc/init.d/msys-riak stop

/etc/init.d/mbusd_monitor stop (just on older 3.x installs / mbus)

Startup:

/etc/init.d/msys-riak start
/etc/init.d/ec_cmd start
/etc/init.d/msyspg start
/etc/init.d/ecconfigd start
/etc/init.d/eccmgr start
/etc/init.d/ecwebconsole start
/etc/init.d/cidr_server start

/etc/init.d/mbusd_monitor start (just on older 3.x installs / mbus)
Cluster Node Shutdown/Startup order

This includes the mbusd_monitor in order to allow for older 3.x (before 3.4) have the service restarted. This is a universal script that ensures all servers will stop and start correctly.

 

Shutdown:

/etc/init.d/ecelerity stop
/etc/init.d/ec_cmd stop
/etc/init.d/msys-riak stop

 
/etc/init.d/mbusd_monitor stop (just on older 3.x installs / mbus)

Startup:

/etc/init.d/msys-riak start
/etc/init.d/ec_cmd start
/etc/init.d/ecelerity start

 
/etc/init.d/mbusd_monitor start (just on older 3.x installs / mbus)

articles.subject: How do I run Momentum in debug mode?
articles.keywords: debug, ecelerity, configuration, config_shim_wrapper, ecconfigd, eccmgr
articles.body:
How do I run Momentum in debug mode?
 

Sometimes when there are issues preventing Momentum from starting up properly, or with a configuration change, the output you get from a failed startup or from running "config_shim_wrapper" are insufficient to understand the problem.  In these cases it can be helpful to run Momentum in "debug" mode to help get additional context.

Note that this is never a viable option for running Momentum.  It behaves differently in this mode than when started normally, and will not perform well.  This approach is specifically only useful for troubleshooting problems at startup.

To start Momentum in debug mode in current releases, use the following command (as root):

 

# /opt/msys/ecelerity/sbin/run.ecelerity -d

 

This will produce copious output, showing you the configuration as it is processed, and then information about other steps taking during initialization until you come to the point of the error where it fails.  Sometimes important information can hide further up in the stream as well, so the most important data is not always right at the end.  If you need help evaluating the output, please include the entire debug output in a ticket and support will be happy to assist.

If it completes the startup process it will enter the normal processing loop.  At that point you will need to use the "CTRL-C" combination to "break" out of the application and return to the prompt.

This same methodology can be used for ecconfigd and eccmgr (on the manager/log aggregator)

articles.subject: How do I see a list of open files related to a specific process?
articles.keywords: open, msys-rabbitmq, nginx, msys-nginx, lsof, files
articles.body:
How do I see a list of open files related to a specific process?

A useful command that gets an lsof (list of open files) of the current master nginx or any process which will show us the currently open files.  

This command can be used against other processes too, example usage below:


ps hf -opid -C nginx | awk '{ print $1; exit }' | xargs sh -c 'lsof -p $1' sh

The msys-nginx process:

root@mom4 ~]# ps hf -opid -C nginx | awk '{ print $1; exit }' | xargs sh -c 'lsof -p $1' sh
