      2048         25    1.22%      30451      30426         25         25          0          0          0          0   99.92%  99.92%         7         0 retry_state

34 caches listed.

Tuning

Adaptive Delivery

Under heavy workloads (particularly clients with broad destinations and poor deliverability) Adaptive Delivery may begin to cause performance issues. When we see this, the first thing we want to look at is "cache stats'. Lets pull out two specific adaptive caches that are indicative of the larger problem, as can be seen in the output for the other adaptive caches above:

cache name                            lookups %                  deletions %
                             elts hit  miss  pend    total  inserts    man ttl lru  total
---------------------- ---------- ------------------------ -------- ---------------------
adaptive_lookup:blackhole
                            11038  54   46    0   4756052  1104696     0 100   0  1093658
adaptive_lookup:suspend_delivery
                            63276  82   18    0  35292283  3098034     0 100   0  3034758

The key columns we want to look at here are hit/miss. Looking at suspend_delivery for example, we see that 18% of the requests against this cache had no entry. Taken against the 35 million in the total, that means that over six million calls against this cache failed to hit the cache. This is extremely inefficient. The percentage itself is really pretty high, but the problem becomes particularly serious in light of the volume of attempts, as pulling this without the cache can be an extremely costly process.

Once we've identified caching as a potential (or contributing) source of the problem, we need to figure out why. Doing a 'cache list all' can help to nail this down. Looking at the above example, we can see several key pain points in this environment under the adaptive subsystem, but we'll stick with the two we're already dealing with.

  CAPACITY    ENTRIES     USED      LOADS       HITS     STORES     MISSES     FORCED    EXPIRED        LRU   REPLACED    HT/TL   RD/WR       Q/S       TTL CACHE
     16384      16384  100.00%    7082251    3267707    1907272    3814544         17      68517    1822354          0   46.14%  78.78%      2075       300 adaptive_lookup:blackhole
     16384      16384  100.00%   46002015   34329844    5835580   11672171         18      13967    5805211          0   74.63%  88.74%     11966       300 adaptive_lookup:suspend_delivery

What we see here is that the problem appears to be focused in LRU (Least Recently Used). The high number here indicates that the cache is way too small, causing nearly every lookup to expire something off the cache to make room for a new entry. 16384 is a decent default, but for this particular customer it is clearly not sufficient for their workload. Bumping this up to more accurately reflect the number of entries being used in these caches will dramatically improve the performance of the cache and thus of the system. In this case, we need to increase adaptive_cache_size.

Increasing Adaptive_Cache_Size

There is no magic formula for finding the right number for this setting. Generally speaking, you can just set Adaptive_Cache_Size to 102400 or 1536000 (in the adaptive{} stanza) and that should do it. The latter will push it up over the line for essentially "infinite" cache size. In cache list all you'll see the value go to 4294967295.

Note: This is no longer true as of Momentum 3.6.0.

Regular Expression Cache

In addition to the Adaptive Delivery issue, we can see that there is a similar problem with config:match:

cache name                            lookups %                  deletions %
                             elts hit  miss  pend    total  inserts    man ttl lru  total
---------------------- ---------- ------------------------ -------- ---------------------
config:match
                            16384  99    1    0  45671603   354317     0   0 100   337933

And from cache list:

  CAPACITY    ENTRIES     USED      LOADS       HITS     STORES     MISSES     FORCED    EXPIRED        LRU   REPLACED    HT/TL   RD/WR       Q/S       TTL CACHE
     16384      16384  100.00%  144482217  143277965    1204252    1204252          0          0    1187868          0   99.17%  99.17%     33630         0 config:match

Once again we see that while only 1% missed, that's still 1% of 45 million, which is still almost 500,000 times. This is a single global cache (Match_Cache_Size) that is used by the regular expression subsystem, and caches matching data for any scopes that uses regular expressions. Set this value high enough to cover the number of unique queries.

articles.subject: How do I use Ephemeral Storage in Momentum 4.x?
articles.keywords: Ephemeral storage
articles.body:
Using Ephemeral Storage in Momentum 4.x

Table of Contents
  • Introduction
  • Ephemeral Disk: Pros and Cons


Introduction
Ephemeral storage is a special block device that is included with certain types of AWS instances.  Ephemeral storage is directly attached to the host of your AWS instances, run on and provide high performance storage to your instance.  As the name suggest, data stored on ephemeral storage is lost when your instances is restarted.  The amount of ephemeral storage, is dependent on the instance type.  Moreover, it is important to note that Ephemeral storage must be enabled when you provision your AWS instance for the first time.


If you are installing Momentum in AWS, do not use ephemeral disks in your production environment as this can potentially cause a loss of messages.

Ephemeral Disk: Pros and Cons

Pros:
“Highly available” AWS claims to provide redundancy and a lower failure rate than physical disks.   Additional pros that support the use of Ephemeral Disk include the fact that they are:
  • Free (included in cost of EC2 instance)
  • Stable, predictable performance on par with a standard physical hard disk
  • Provides abundant storage (up to 1.7TB on a c1.xlarge)
Cons:
  • If the instance shuts down, all data is lost
  • Has a maximum throughput of 1Gbit/s
Introduction Next Article

articles.subject: Handy queries for the Message Central database
articles.keywords: virtualxid, queries, indexrelname, schema, RUNNING.sql, PostgreSQL, Unix/Linux, message, central, psql, large, size, database, idle
articles.body:
Handy queries for the Message Central database

Overview
This document contains queries that answer some of the questions you might like to ask your database. A basic understanding of SSH and the Unix/Linux command line is assumed.

How to Run These Queries

There are several GUI options for connecting to PostgreSQL and running queries. The specifics of those various options are out of the scope of this document. With SSH access to the PostgreSQL server role installed as part of Message Central or Momentum, all of the tools you need to run these queries are already available. The tool used to connect to PostgreSQL from the command line is named psql. The following command will connect to the Message Central database and give you an interactive prompt:
 
$ /opt/msys/3rdParty/bin/psql -U ecuser -d pe

There are two options specified on the command line, -U (user) and -d (database). Quite a few other options are available, but for the purposes of this document, only one other option is required, -f (file):
 
$ /opt/msys/3rdParty/bin/psql -U ecuser -d pe -f ~/sql/RUNNING.sql

What this command instructs the system to do is: a) connect to the database, b) execute the contents of the file RUNNING.sql, and c) then disconnect from the database. This option is relevant since you can copy and paste these queries into a file on the database server, and then quickly ask PostgreSQL complicated questions without a lot of typing involved. This is also very useful for monitoring when combined with the watch command, which tells the system to execute a command line every N seconds. So, to automatically execute RUNNING.sql every 5 seconds and display the output:
 
$ watch -n 5 /opt/msys/3rdParty/bin/psql -U ecuser -d pe -f ~/sql/RUNNING.sql

This command will continue running until stopped by hitting Ctrl-c. This method can be used with any of the queries shown below.

Settings and Defaults

There are lots of options that can be set in your psql options file, ~/.psqlrc so you don't have to type them every time, and so they are also picked up when queries are run using the -f option. My personal favorite is \timing which prints the duration of each command run in psql.
What's Running Right Now?
Running the following query will tell you what the various users connected to your database are running right now:
SELECT current_query as query, procpid as pid, usename as user,        
client_addr||':'||client_port as client,        
now()-query_start as elapsed, waiting   
FROM pg_stat_activity 
WHERE current_query NOT LIKE '%<IDLE>%' 
ORDER BY 5 DESC;
Let's run through the various columns of data that are coming back from this query.
  1. The text of the query that was run. This will tell you roughly what's happening, although it doesn't include specific information like placeholder values for prepared statements.
  2. The id of the PostgreSQL process that's running the query above. This is useful when taking drastic measures like canceling queries, or when measuring resource usage.
  3. The username used when connecting to the database.
  4. The source of the connection (blank when local). This helps to identify which system component (or workstation) is responsible for which queries.
  5. The total time this query has been running. The results are ordered using this column so that the longest running queries appear at the top of the list.
  6. Whether this query is waiting for a lock. This is a huge can of worms, and this will be discussed in more detail later on in this document.
How Large Are My Tables?
Running the following query will display size information about each table in the system:
SELECT table_name,        
                      pg_size_pretty(total_size) total,        
                      total_size as bytes,        
                      pg_size_pretty(table_size) size,        
                      pg_size_pretty(idx_size) idx,        
                      rows   
FROM (SELECT table_name,                
                     pg_total_relation_size(table_name) as total_size,                
                     pg_table_size(table_name) as table_size,                
                     pg_indexes_size(table_name) as idx_size,                
                     rows           
FROM (SELECT t.schemaname::text ||'.'|| t.tablename::text as table_name,                        
                            c.reltuples::int as rows                   
                            FROM pg_tables t                   
                           JOIN pg_namespace n ON t.schemaname = n.nspname                   
                           JOIN pg_class c ON n.oid = c.relnamespace AND t.tablename = c.relname                 ) q1          ) q2  ORDER BY total_size DESC;
 
 
Let's run through the columns returned from this query:
  1. The name of the table in question, including the schema name.
  2. A human-readable expression of the total size of the table, including indexes.
  3. The raw size of the table, in bytes.
  4. The size of the table, without indexes.
  5. The size of the indexes themselves.
  6. The approximate number of rows in the table.
This query is useful if a client is running into disk space issues and would like a breakdown of where the space is being used. Also particularly useful for clients with large volumes of replicated data.

How Large Is My Dynamic Mailing Data?

In many cases, MC will use a large volume of disk space without any one table being very large, besides perhaps the OrgN.Contacts and OrgN.ContactDetails tables when large recipient lists are in use. This is due to the way in which PostgreSQL implements table partitioning, which is used in Message Central to store Mailing statistics. Each partition of a virtual table (that can be queried to search all partitions, see Constraint Exclusion in the table partitioning link) is created itself as a separate table. The query below, or a version of this query modified for your specific needs, can be used to find the aggregate size of Mailing partitions.
 
SELECT month, mailings,        
               pg_size_pretty(am) as am,
               pg_size_pretty(amg) as amg,        
               pg_size_pretty(amd) as amd, pg_size_pretty(amb) as amb,        
               pg_size_pretty(cl) as cl, pg_size_pretty(op) as op,        
               pg_size_pretty(am + amg + amd + amb + cl + op) as total   
FROM (SELECT date_trunc('month', timestamp)::date as month, count(*) as mailings,        
              sum(CASE WHEN am.tablename IS NULL THEN 0                 
              ELSE pg_total_relation_size(am.schemaname::text ||'.'||
am.tablename::text) END)::bigint as am,        
            sum(CASE WHEN amg.tablename IS NULL THEN 0                 
            ELSE pg_total_relation_size(amg.schemaname::text ||'.'|| amg.tablename::text) END)::bigint as amg,        
            sum(CASE WHEN amd.tablename IS NULL THEN 0                 
            ELSE pg_total_relation_size(amd.schemaname::text ||'.'|| amd.tablename::text) END)::bigint as amd,        
            sum(CASE WHEN amb.tablename IS NULL THEN 0                 
           ELSE pg_total_relation_size(amb.schemaname::text ||'.'|| amb.tablename::text) END)::bigint as amb,        
           sum(CASE WHEN cl.tablename IS NULL THEN 0                 
           ELSE pg_total_relation_size(cl.schemaname::text ||'.'|| cl.tablename::text) END)::bigint as cl,    
           sum(CASE WHEN op.tablename IS NULL THEN 0                 
            ELSE pg_total_relation_size(op.schemaname::text ||'.'|| op.tablename::text) END)::bigint as op   
                     FROM maincontrol.mailingregistry mr   
                     LEFT JOIN pg_tables am ON am.tablename = 'activemailings_'|| lpad(mr.mailingid::text, 7, '0')                AND am.schemaname = 'org'|| lpad(mr.orgid::text, 7, '0')    
                    LEFT JOIN pg_tables amg ON amg.tablename = 'activemailingsgenerated_'|| lpad(mr.mailingid::text, 7, '0')                                    
                   AND amg.schemaname = 'org'|| lpad(mr.orgid::text, 7, '0')   
                   LEFT JOIN pg_tables amd ON amd.tablename = 'activemailingsdelivered_'|| lpad(mr.mailingid::text, 7, '0')     
                  AND amd.schemaname = 'org'|| lpad(mr.orgid::text, 7, '0')   
                  LEFT JOIN pg_tables amb ON amb.tablename = 'activemailingsbounced_'|| lpad(mr.mailingid::text, 7, '0')     
                  AND amb.schemaname = 'org'|| lpad(mr.orgid::text, 7, '0')   
                  LEFT JOIN pg_tables op ON op.tablename = 'opens_'|| lpad(mr.mailingid::text, 7, '0')     
                 AND op.schemaname = 'org'|| lpad(mr.orgid::text, 7, '0')   
                 LEFT JOIN pg_tables cl ON cl.tablename = 'clicks_'|| lpad(mr.mailingid::text, 7, '0')     
                AND cl.schemaname = 'org'|| lpad(mr.orgid::text, 7, '0')
                WHERE am.tablename IS NOT NULL    
                AND mr.orgid = 1
GROUP BY 1   ) as t  ORDER BY 1 DESC;
Note line 32, where there is a line specifying the desired org. And here's what the output of the query above looks like for a client who sent a lot of Mailings in December 2012:
   month    | mailings |   am    |   amg   |   amd   |   amb   |   cl    |   op    |  total  ------------+----------+---------+---------+---------+---------+---------+---------+---------   2013-01-01 |       52 | 9045 MB | 8921 MB | 7429 MB | 22 MB   | 2080 kB | 2592 kB | 25 GB   2012-12-01 |      251 | 37 GB   | 37 GB   | 30 GB   | 596 MB  | 8032 kB | 8384 kB | 105 GB   2012-11-01 |       97 | 5570 MB | 5468 MB | 2948 MB | 1872 MB | 3872 kB | 3616 kB | 15 GB   2012-10-01 |      108 | 2251 MB | 2246 MB | 1438 MB | 765 MB  | 3648 kB | 3584 kB | 6708 MB   2012-09-01 |       31 | 206 MB  | 211 MB  | 744 kB  | 324 MB  | 992 kB  | 992 kB  | 744 MB   2012-08-01 |        8 | 1000 kB | 936 kB  | 408 kB  | 1200 kB | 256 kB  | 256 kB  | 4056 kB  2012-07-01 |        4 | 8232 kB | 8448 kB | 8984 kB | 13 MB   | 128 kB  | 128 kB  | 39 MB  2012-06-01 |       35 | 4168 kB | 3928 kB | 3448 kB | 4360 kB | 2464 kB | 2464 kB | 20 MB  2012-05-01 |      101 | 26 MB   | 25 MB   | 31 MB   | 37 MB   | 3936 kB | 3232 kB | 125 MB  2012-04-01 |       93 | 116 MB  | 61 MB   | 22 MB   | 47 MB   | 2976 kB | 3168 kB | 253 MB  2012-03-01 |       19 | 4728 kB | 1704 kB | 712 kB  | 1952 kB | 608 kB  | 608 kB  | 10 MB  2011-11-01 |        2 | 192 kB  | 176 kB  | 32 kB   | 136 kB  | 64 kB   | 64 kB   | 664 kB 
 
Are My Tables Indexed Effectively?
Running the following query will display statistics about index size and usage. Source
 
SELECT idstat.relname AS table_name,        
               indexrelname AS index_name,        
               idstat.idx_scan AS times_used,        
               pg_size_pretty(pg_relation_size(t.schemaname::text ||'.'|| idstat.relname::text)) AS table_size,                
               pg_size_pretty(pg_relation_size(t.schemaname::text ||'.'|| indexrelname::text)) AS index_size,         n_tup_upd + n_tup_ins + n_tup_del as num_writes,         indexdef AS definition   
              FROM pg_stat_user_indexes AS idstat   
             JOIN pg_indexes ON indexrelname = indexname    
             JOIN pg_stat_user_tables AS tabstat ON idstat.relname = tabstat.relname   
             JOIN pg_tables AS t ON tabstat.relname = t.tablename WHERE idstat.idx_scan < 200 -- scan limit          
             AND indexdef !~* 'unique'    
             AND pg_relation_size(t.schemaname::text ||'.'|| idstat.relname::text)         > (1024 * 1024 * 100) -- size limit 
            ORDER BY pg_relation_size(t.schemaname::text ||'.'|| indexrelname::text) * idstat.idx_scan ASC, 
            pg_relation_size(t.schemaname::text ||'.'|| indexrelname::text) DESC;
This is an ugly query, but it gets the job done. As written, this query will ignore all indexes on small (less than 100MB) tables, indexes with more than 200 scans, and indexes that are required to enforce unique constraints. It's ordered by multiplying the size of the index by the number of scans to attempt to provide a guide as to which indexes are currently the most useless. Indexes closer to the top of the results are most likely more useless.
Why Are My Queries Waiting?
The "why" of database locking is an advanced topic with some required reading:
ACID (Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability)
MVCC (Multi Version Concurrency Control, general)
MVCC (Multi Version Concurrency Control, PostgreSQL-specific)
Specific Types of Locking in PostgreSQL
This query will display information about locks held by currently-running transactions Source
SELECT pid, vxid, lock_type, lock_mode,  granted, xid_lock, relname 
FROM (   
      SELECT pid, virtualtransaction AS vxid, locktype AS lock_type,           mode AS lock_mode, granted,  
            CASE          
            WHEN virtualxid IS NOT NULL AND transactionid IS NOT NULL          
            THEN virtualxid || ' ' || transactionid          
            WHEN virtualxid::text IS NOT NULL          
            THEN virtualxid          
            ELSE transactionid::text          
           END AS xid_lock, relname,           page, tuple, classid, objid, objsubid     
FROM pg_locks     
LEFT OUTER JOIN pg_class ON (pg_locks.relation = pg_class.oid)     
WHERE -- do not show our view’s locks           
pid != pg_backend_pid() AND           
-- no need to show self-vxid locks           
virtualtransaction IS DISTINCT FROM virtualxid
) 1
-- granted is ordered earlier ORDER BY 1, 2, 5 DESC, 6, 3, 4, 7;

Following along with the presentation linked above is instructive.  The author chooses to create Views instead of running queries; either approach will work just as well. Using the watch command described above with two windows side-by-side is particularly interesting, with this lock info query on one side, and the What's Running Right Now? query on the other.

articles.subject: Does Momentum support special characters in e-mail addresses?
articles.keywords: rfc2822, special, characters
articles.body:
Does Momentum support special characters in e-mail addresses?

According to RFC 2822, the local portion of an email address (i.e. the part before the @), can contain certain non-alphanumeric characters: !, #, $, %, &, ', *, +,-,/,=,?,^,_,`,{,|, } and ~. For example, you could have an e-mail address such as fred/john%!2@domain.com. These characters are extremely rare in e-mail addresses; many e-mail providers don't even allow them. Momentum, though, allows these characters in e-mail addresses and should send such e-mails with no problems.

articles.subject: If TLS negotiation fails am I able to send the message with no encryption?
articles.keywords: tls, opportunistic, fallback, smtp, 3.5.10, 3.6, 4.x
articles.body:
If TLS negotiation fails am I able to send the message with no encryption?

From Momentum 3.5.10/3.6.4, we now have Opportunistic TLS meaning Momentum will try to send the message as plain-text if the remote mail exchange supports TLS but the negotiation fails.
More information on this available on: https://support.messagesystems.com/docs/web-ref/conf.ref.tls_ifavailable_fallback.php

articles.subject: Momentum 4 Shutdown/Startup Order
articles.keywords: momentum, 4, 4.1, 4.2, startup, shutdown,
articles.body:
Momentum 4 Shutdown/Startup Order
 

Controlled Shutdown of Momentum 4

To shut down all processes associated with the Momentum application suite, issue the following commands in this order:

  • /etc/init.d/msys-nginx stop
  • /etc/init.d/ecelerity stop  (if the node will be down for a while, allow the rabbitmq queues to drain before proceeding)
  • /etc/init.d/msys-app-webhooks-api stop
  • /etc/init.d/msys-app-users-api stop
  • /etc/init.d/msys-app-metrics-api stop
  • /etc/init.d/msys-app-adaptive-delivery-api stop
  • /opt/msys/3rdParty/cassandra/bin/nodetool drain
  • /etc/init.d/msys-cassandra stop
  • /etc/init.d/msys-vertica stop
  • /etc/init.d/msys-riak stop
  • /etc/init.d/msys-app-webhooks-transmitter stop
  • /etc/init.d/msys-app-webhooks-batch stop
  • /etc/init.d/msys-app-metrics-etl stop
  • /etc/init.d/msys-app-adaptive-delivery-etl stop
  • /etc/init.d/msys-rabbitmq stop
  • /etc/init.d/eccmgr stop  (exists only on the first platform/manager/log aggregator node)
  • /etc/init.d/ecconfigd stop  (exists only on the first platform/manager/log aggregator node)

Controlled Startup of Momentum 4

To start all processes associated with the Momentum application suite, issue the following commands in this order:

  • /etc/init.d/ecconfigd start   (exists only on the first platform/manager/log aggregator node) 
  • /etc/init.d/eccmgr start   (exists only on the first platform/manager/log aggregator node) 
  • /etc/init.d/msys-rabbitmq start
  • /etc/init.d/msys-app-metrics-etl start
  • /etc/init.d/msys-app-webhooks-transmitter start
  • /etc/init.d/msys-app-adaptive-delivery-etl start
  • /etc/init.d/msys-riak start
  • /etc/init.d/msys-vertica start
  • /etc/init.d/msys-cassandra start
  • /etc/init.d/msys-app-adaptive-delivery-api start
  • /etc/init.d/msys-app-metrics-api start
  • /etc/init.d/msys-app-users-api start
  • /etc/init.d/msys-app-webhooks-api start
  • /etc/init.d/ecelerity start  (all services started so far should be up prior to starting ecelerity)
  • /etc/init.d/msys-nginx start
  • /etc/init.d/msys-app-webhooks-batch start

articles.subject: Momentum is Running out of File Handles
articles.keywords: file, handles, sysctl.conf, sysctl, file-max
articles.body:
Momentum is Running out of File Handles 

If you find that your box is running out of file handles, you will want to add the following line to /etc/sysctl.conf: 
fs.file-max = 250000
You can execute the following for the changes after adding the line or reboot the box: 
sysctl -p

articles.subject: Momentum WebUI Showing URL vs Page Name
articles.keywords: momentum, webui, 4, 4.1, 4.0, 4.2
articles.body:
Momentum WebUI Showing URL vs Page Name

On the engagement links page of the Momentum 4 webUI you may see both raw URLs and page names. This is dependent on whether name attribute is specified in an anchor or not and is not a sign of a problem. This has been made to show either link name or the raw URL in versions 4.1.1 or later.

articles.subject: What Versions of TLS does Momentum Support?
articles.keywords: ssl, tls
articles.body:
What Versions of TLS does Momentum Support?

Momentum utilizes the TLS/SSL functions available on the OS level. There should be no compatibility issues since TLS/SSL versions are backwards compatible.

articles.subject: "ec_cluster: No member info" Error in Paniclog
articles.keywords: ec_cluster, no, member, duravip, paniclog.ec
articles.body:
"ec_cluster: No member info" Error in Paniclog

If you use Duravips and see errors similar to the following:

1429041921:ec_cluster: No member info for #ec0-31042#msm-mta08-tor6 removing from 10.4.43.46
1429041921:ec_cluster: No member info for #ec0-31042#msm-mta08-tor6 removing from 10.4.43.163
1429041921:ec_cluster: No member info for #ec0-31042#msm-mta08-tor6 removing from 10.4.3.103
1429041921:ec_cluster: No member info for #ec0-31042#msm-mta08-tor6 removing from 10.4.33.72
1429041921:ec_cluster: No member info for #ec0-31042#msm-mta08-tor6 removing from 10.4.41.200
1429041921:ec_cluster: No member info for #ec0-31042#msm-mta08-tor6 removing from 10.4.43.43

You should check if you have unplumbed bindings on the host seen in the errors. You can do so by using these commands in the ec_console:

scriptlet eval msys.core.config_get_binding_id_from_name("<binding name>")
scriptlet eval msys.core.binding_get_unplumbed (<binding id>)

Please note that the binding name needs to be in quotes, as shown above. You will need to do the config_get_binding_id_from_name command first to get the binding ID and put that number in the second command. The results will look something like this:


​

The output for scriptlet eval msys.core.binding_get_unplumbed (<binding id>) will be a binary. If it returns '0', your binding is plumbed. If it returns '1', you have a Duravip that is unplumbed. 

If you have an unplumbed Duravip, you can try the this command from the ec_console on the cluster manager: broadcast cluster duravip announce view

If you still have unplumbed Duravips, you will have to restart Ecelerity.

articles.subject: 3.6.2 - eccfg commits fail if password not supplied / doesn't prompt for password.
articles.keywords: eccfg, 3.6.2, svn, repository, repo, commit, password, prompt
articles.body:
3.6.2 - eccfg commits fail if password not supplied / doesn't prompt for password.
 

Symptoms

When trying to commit ( eccfg commit ) in 3.6.2 without adding the --password or -p eccfg will return error 76- ( Authentication failed ) which may be misleading as a shim/config error. Shim will return correct, and adding of new directories will be successful but the user will not be able to commit

Summary

Examples: 

FAILURE: 

bash-3.2$ /opt/msys/ecelerity/bin/eccfg commit --debug --username msys -m 'ecelerity.conf msystest' 
executing: svn info '--config-dir' '/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/.eccfg' '--xml' '/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf' 
Subversion info succeeded 
executing: svn status '--config-dir' '/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/.eccfg' '--xml' '/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf/global' 
Subversion status succeeded 
executing: svn status '--config-dir' '/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/.eccfg' '--xml' '/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf/global' 
Subversion status succeeded 
executing: svn status '--config-dir' '/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/.eccfg' '--xml' '/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf' 
Subversion status succeeded 
executing: svn status '--config-dir' '/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/.eccfg' '--xml' '/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf' 
Subversion status succeeded 
executing: svn commit '--config-dir' '/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/.eccfg' '--username' 'msys' '--no-auth-cache' '--message' 'ecelerity.conf msystest' '/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf' 
Temporarily accepted untrusted server cert 
ERROR: Authentication failed at /opt/msys/3rdParty/lib/perl5/vendor_perl/5.16.3/Expect.pm line 760. 
Unable to commit changes. If the configuration is out of date, please run 
"eccfg pull" to refresh it. 


WORKING: 

bash-3.2$ /opt/msys/ecelerity/bin/eccfg commit --debug --username msys -p XXXXXX 
executing: svn info '--config-dir' '/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/.eccfg' '--xml' '/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf' 
Subversion info succeeded 
executing: svn status '--config-dir' '/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/.eccfg' '--xml' '/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf/global' 
Subversion status succeeded 
executing: svn status '--config-dir' '/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/.eccfg' '--xml' '/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf/global' 
Subversion status succeeded 
executing: svn status '--config-dir' '/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/.eccfg' '--xml' '/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf' 
Subversion status succeeded 
executing: svn status '--config-dir' '/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/.eccfg' '--xml' '/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf' 
Subversion status succeeded 
executing: svn commit '--config-dir' '/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/.eccfg' '--username' 'msys' '--no-auth-cache' '--message' 'No message' '/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf' 
Temporarily accepted untrusted server cert 
Subversion commit succeeded 
Sending default/cdb/psl 
Adding default/dummy_commit 
Sending default/ec_rotate.conf 
Sending default/ecelerity.conf 
Adding default/ootest 
Adding default/ootest/basic.lua 
Adding (bin) default/ootest/luac.out 
Adding default/ootest/super.lua 
Transmitting file data ....... 
Committed revision 837.

Workaround

Workaround is to add in the password on the command line. 

If there are concerns about the password being stored in the bash history you can add $ echo "HISTCONTROL=ignorespace" >>~/.bashrc then when entering in the eccfg command putting a space before the command and it will not be stored in the bash history.

articles.subject: Adaptive Delivery Reporting on the WebUI is not Showing
articles.keywords: adaptive, delivery, 4.2, webui, Web, UI,
articles.body:
Adaptive Delivery Reporting on the WebUI is not Showing

If you are experiencing issues with Adaptive reporting on the 4.2 webUI, please check the downloads page on support.messagesystems.com for a bundle later than 4.2.1.50062. If that is not available, please open a ticket with support@messagesystems.com and we will get you a copy of the bundle. 

If you have obtained a newer bundle off of the Downloads page, please upgrade your instance.

If you have received a bundle directly from Support, you can upgrade your instance, or you can upgrade the rpms listed here: 
msys-ecelerity-logging-event_hydrant-4.2.1.50753-1.rhel6.x86_64.rpm
msys-ecelerity-adaptive-4.2.1.50753-1.rhel6.x86_64.rpm
msys-app*

(any package that starts with msys-app will also have to be upgraded)

Once those packages are upgraded, you should see AD statistics populated in the webUI.

Excessive "Throttling" Messages in Paniclog

articles.subject: Issues with CloudMark Authority finger prints on Momentum 3.5.8
articles.keywords: cloudmark, 3.5.8, cartridge, mta
articles.body:
Issues with CloudMark Authority finger prints on Momentum 3.5.8

A known issue that affects versions 3.5.8.41051 r(Platform:3.5.8.0) (64-bit) 
Details:

We had seen cases where fingerprints from the Cloudmark Cartridge which were unable to be reproduced from the raw mails. They include fingerprint data of parts which aren't actually contained within the email.
A customer was investigating the issue with Cloudmark Support but could not find anything that could explain the issue, they also could not reproduce the issue actively. They have seen multiple cases of customers reporting false positives with could be attributed to this issue.
According to Cloudmark Support they had at least one other customer with a similar issue which got it fixed by a patch provided by Message Systems but they couldn't provide any more detailed info on that.
A configuration consideration, use_wire_rep = true must be set.  In this case it was set but did not solve the issue. 
They use Cloudmark CMAE Cartridge version 3052.2.0.26
 
Fingerprints from the last case they could find at the moment:
Fingerprint created on our MTA (and added as X-Header):
v=2.1 cv=AMBFt/iA c=1 sm=1 tr=0 p=amXx_SpKqbL0OSfekooA:9 a=id12o1H8vyLFSkcZczdHkw==:117 a=id12o1H8vyLFSkcZczdHkw==:17 a=iH6nVvkAFkcA:10 a=xqWC_Br6kY4A:10 a=e9J7MTPGsLIA:10 a=jU4qhlNgAAAA:8 a=A_Ya8HAiAAAA:8 a=zxKZjvZ5AAAA:8 a=oenKYiqTAAAA:8 a=frI3oWvN2JOWR02lhUAA:9 a=wPNLvfGTeEIA:10 a=JQMwCzFwJn0A:10 a=bCFWs6U6SaQA:10 a=RJ9ZwYoF-SwA:10 a=V6nRfSHCctsA:10 a=uGujNk4otazW4EFA1hsA:9 a=7IUIYKW13RVlW7kU:21 a=_W_S_7VecoQA:10 a=Yaq4ad2znTlVYdZ1Le4A:9 a=KQqxNPgzF0kA:10 a=Sf_gFPzhefAA:10 a=X0RIC5txGPsA:10 a=xJzADCuJm7EA:10 a=ah6hqn9EgaMA:10

X-CNFS-Score: 99
 
Fingerprint on raw mail if processed by Cloudmark support (also on cat.cloudmark.com):
v=2.1 cv=HP9NF+dv c=1 sm=0 tr=0 a=id12o1H8vyLFSkcZczdHkw==:17 a=iH6nVvkAFkcA:10 a=xqWC_Br6kY4A:10 a=KGjhK52YXX0A:10 a=e9J7MTPGsLIA:10 a=jU4qhlNgAAAA:8 a=A_Ya8HAiAAAA:8 a=zxKZjvZ5AAAA:8 a=oenKYiqTAAAA:8 a=frI3oWvN2JOWR02lhUAA:9 a=wPNLvfGTeEIA:10 a=JQMwCzFwJn0A:10 a=bCFWs6U6SaQA:10 a=RJ9ZwYoF-SwA:10 a=V6nRfSHCctsA:10 a=uGujNk4otazW4EFA1hsA:9 a=7IUIYKW13RVlW7kU:21 a=_W_S_7VecoQA:10 a=Yaq4ad2znTlVYdZ1Le4A:9 a=KQqxNPgzF0kA:10 a=Sf_gFPzhefAA:10

Resolution:
An upgrade to version 3.5.10 solves this issue.

articles.subject: msys.cloudmark.score_ip returns false positives/negatives
articles.keywords: cloudmark, 3.6, false, positives, negatives
articles.body:
msys.cloudmark.score_ip returns false positives/negatives
 

Symptoms

Cloudmark's "score IP' function returns bad values in one of two ways: 

1) consistent false positives 
2) random false negatives

Summary

While updating the cloudmark module to be supercharger-compatible, we discovered that our error handling in the cloudmark_score_ip function (wrapped by msys.cloudmark.score_ip in lua) was very broken. The actual error value returned by the cloudmark API was disregarded and the variable that should have been storing it was uninitialized stack memory, meaning it would either indicate no error or, occasionally, a random value.

Workaround

There is no real workaround, however this has been resolved as of 3.6.5.

articles.subject: Out of Band bounces being not or mis-classfied.
articles.keywords: oob, out, of, band, mdn, MDN, misclassification, not, being, 3.4, 3.5, 3.6, 4.0, 4.1, 4.2
articles.body:
Out of Band bounces being not or mis-classfied.
 

Symptoms

Misclassification of OOB's this will not be apparent unless the customer is monitoring their bouncelog.ec for incorrectly classified oob's or if they are unsubscribing based on oob's. This latter cause is the one that is much more serious from the perspective of the customer.

Summary

This issue was caused when the Boogie Bounce product was pulled from the product in a variety of versions but most specifically in versions post 3.3.3. Preceding this version the Boogie Bounce product utilized the smtp_classification.ovr pushed out by our Live Bounce update to classify both inband and out of band bounces. However, when this was removed from the product this was no longer the case, smtp_classification.ovr is now only being used for mail that adheres RFC's in relation to codes and headers. Since this is the case anything that falls through RFC verification, is body parsed to match the mdn_classification.ovr file regexes. However, since this particular files does not exist, it is currently falling through this and being assigned to classification of 1 which equates to "550 [internal] [oob] The response text could not be identified.". Now in certain circumstances this may be correct, however, since we do not currently have a mdn_classification scheme and since a large proportion of OOB's are not RFC compliant this leads us to the customer having to create their own user_mdn_classification override file.

Workaround

Currently the only workaround for a customer with an issue like this is to setup two possible solutions: 

1. Create a maildir that stores the domain for their oob's messages locally on disk and introspect each of the messages in the queue until they are sure none of the oob's are being misclassified, this involves opening each message in this mail directory and comparing the classification of the message vs the classification number in the bouncelog.ec 

2. Add a recipient to the rcptto list as the oob is passing through the system and this new recipient will be a mailbox in their company mail server that allows them to gather this information using their mail client, this way the customer can read these from the mail app and then compare them to the logs on the manager or node for the bouncelog.ec, this still requires the customer to compare the oob with the classification that was given to it. 

Both of the above then require you to setup an MDN classification file using the following methodology: 

bounce_classifier_override { 
user_mdn_classification_override = "/opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/conf/default/user_mdn_classification.ovr" 
custom_classes = [ 
55 = "Recipient is not accepting mail with embedded images" 
] 
refresh = 900 
} 

and then adding in the user_mdn_classification.ovr file something like this: 

60,|out of office 
60,|out of the office 
60,|absent 
60,|out of touch 
40,|recipients failed 
22,|mailbox unavailable 
55,|accepting mail with embedded images 

Please note that unlike the smtp_classification.ovr the mdn classification file will only allow two arguments, not the three required for smtp classification.

articles.subject: How to drain Cassandra queues prior to shutdown via the nodetool drain command.
articles.keywords: Cassandra, nodetool, queue
articles.body:
Shutting down Cassandra needs nodetool drain command to be executed before

Before you stop Cassandra (with /etc/init.d/msys-cassandra stop), issue an /opt/msys/3rdParty/cassandra/bin/nodetool drain to ensure all queues are drained.

This action will flush data entries in memory to the cassandra db, along with stopping all listening by the cassandra node. Generally you do not want any processes doing more writes.

articles.subject: The search functionality in the Web UI does not show suggestions or return results
articles.keywords: 4.1, webui, Web UI, suggestions, results
articles.body:
The search functionality in the Web UI does not show suggestions or return results

The search box in the Web UI does not give suggestions or any results.

Affects Momentum versions 4.1.

Work around:

Edit this file:  /opt/msys/3rdParty/nginx/conf.d/web_proxy.conf  

Adding the block below to the /api/v1 section:


location /api/v1/metrics/domains {
    include "../conf.d/default.cors";
    more_set_headers 'Content-Type: application/json';
    more_set_headers 'Cache-Control: no-cache, no-store';
    echo '{"results":{}}';
}

articles.subject: What does it mean when I see this error in my paniclog: 1407725673:MQ-01135 Couldn't re-summon recycled domain
articles.keywords: paniclog, re-summon, recycled, MQ, 3.6.5, 4.1.0.4
articles.body:
What does it mean when I see this error in my paniclog:
1407725673:MQ-01135 Couldn't re-summon recycled domain
 

When the TTL runs out for a given domain that Momentum is tracking while there are still messages in the queue we flag the domain as "recycled" in a particular table.  During the periodic maintenance we do on the mail queue structures then, that table gets checked, to see if there are any messages that need queueing.  This error just means that by the time that occurred there were no messages meeting that criteria still present.

Since it's something of a "non-error" in normal operation it is already flagged in our engineering backlog to have its debug level increased so it won't be shown in normal operation, but in the current release it is.  You can safely ignore it.

This issue was fixed in version 3.6.5+ and version 4.1.0.4+ If you see further evidence of this occurring please let support know.

articles.subject: Why do I have a large number of directories inside /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/ starting with conf followed by 6 random chars?
articles.keywords: config, multiple, 3.3, repository, repo, commit
articles.body:
Why do I have a large number of directories inside /opt/msys/ecelerity/etc/ starting with conf followed by 6 random chars? 

That happens due to a change not commited to the repository; to resolve this, you can delete all the additional conf directories and then do a commit. Please see the following page to learn how to commit to the repository:
3.x : https://support.messagesystems.com/docs/web-ref/conf.adding.configuration.files.php
4.x : https://support.messagesystems.com/docs/web-momo4/conf.overview.php#conf.ecconfigd
​
Once this is done it will prevent directories from being created seeing the repository will now be in sync. This was a known issue on 3.3.x and earlier, but post this should no longer be an issue. You may find that you have one directory created like this if you have not recently committed and have still made changes but there should not be multiples of these.

articles.subject: Why do I see "ec_cluster: cannot open reader..." errors in the paniclog?
articles.keywords: ec_cluster, paniclog, Ecelerity, cannot,open, reader
articles.body:
Why do I see "ec_cluster: cannot open reader..." errors in the paniclog?

Here's an example of what you may find in your paniclog. If these appear in your MTA's paniclog, please continue for more info.  
[Thu 01 Jan 2014 15:55:58] [serious] ec_cluster: cannot open reader <nodename> on /var/log/ecelerity/rejectlog.cluster
[Thu 01 Jan 2014 15:55:58] [serious] ec_cluster: cannot open reader <nodename> on /var/log/ecelerity/acctlog.cluster
[Thu 01 Jan 2014 15:55:58] [serious] ec_cluster: cannot open reader <nodename> on /var/log/ecelerity/paniclog.cluster
[Thu 01 Jan 2014 15:55:58] [serious] ec_cluster: cannot open reader <nodename> on /var/log/ecelerity/mainlog.cluster
[Thu 01 Jan 2014 15:55:58] [serious] ec_cluster: cannot open reader msbadger on /var/log/ecelerity/bouncelog.cluster
This is a known issue, due to a race condition that occurs upon initial startup of the Ecelerity process. However, the race condition eventually clears and the log files are opened by the process as usual. Unless you see these errors constantly repeating, they can be safely ignored. Otherwise, you may need to look into some filesystem limitations such as lack of space, file handles, inodes, etc.

articles.subject: How can I do a blackhole testing?
articles.body:
How can I do a blackhole testing?

You may want to do some blackhole testing in PowerMTA, and there are a couple of ways to do so.  Whenever starting blackhole testing it is best to have no messages currently in the queue, and make sure to not do any production mailings during the test.  Also, by default PowerMTA can accept no more than 30 inbound connections at a time, so make sure your feeding application is set accordingly.
 
1. Sending Messages to the Dummy (blackhole) SMTP Port
You can have PowerMTA discard the mail instead (without queuing) by feeding directly into a discard (blackhole) port.  To do so, you would set the following global directives and then restart PowerMTA:
#
dummy-smtp-port    2525  # requires a restart of the service
dummy-smtp-has-chunking yes
dummy-smtp-has-pipelining yes
dummy-smtp-has-mailmerge yes
#
 
After making these changes, you would point your feeding application to the port defined in the dummy-smtp-port directive versus the standard SMTP port.  Once your feeding application is done you'll want to again run the command:
  pmta show status
To determine what types of rates your feeding application was able to obtain.  As the messages are immediately discarded, no additional cleanup steps are required.
 
2. Holding Messages in the Queue
Define the global directive:
#
total-max-smtp-out 0
#
After making this change, reload PowerMTA.  This tells PowerMTA not to make any outbound connections, and instead just hold all messages in the queue.  After your test is complete, look at the output of the command:
  pmta show status
To determine what types of rates your feeding application was able to obtain.  Once you have the results you would run the following command to clear the queue of messages:
  pmta delete --queue=*/*
Or you could stop the PowerMTA service and delete all the directories under the spool directory.  Either of these should clear all message from PowerMTA.
 
3. Queue Messages to Disk and then Discarding
You can have PowerMTA discard the mail after queuing by having global <domain *> defined with a "type discard", for example;
#
<domain *>
  type discard
</domain>
#
I would suggest stopping and starting the service as well after setting this method.  Discarded messages in this fashion would show as being delivered in the status monitor and accounting file; however, the accounting file records would show a type of discard versus smtp.  Once your feeding application is done you'll want to again run the command:
  pmta show status
To determine what types of rates your feeding application was able to obtain. .
 
 
On all three of these tests you should be using your feeding application to get an idea of the maximum rate at which your application can inject messages into PowerMTA.  With those numbers in hand you should rerun the same test using:
-On Windows our \pmta\api\dotnet\examples\bechmark.exe program.  Run the command at a command prompt for usage.
-On Linux the postfix smtp-source application (http://www.postfix.org/smtp-source.1.html) which is available from your PowerMTA download page at the bottom of the page under tools.  Run the command at a shell prompt for usage.
 
Both of these programs can feed PowerMTA at very high rates, and can be tested locally or across the network.
 
Let us know the results of the testing with your feeding application versus the benchmarking programs.  This should help give us a good idea of where the bottleneck is, and what can be done to increase the injection performance.

articles.subject: How can I implement a hot backup server?
articles.body:
How can I implement a hot backup server?

Most customers go with a 2 server setup.  Typically both servers are running, and if one fails, new mail gets sent to the backup by the feeding application.  If the spool directory is recoverable, it is added as a second spool to the backup, and the service is restarted to pickup this spool, sending all new and old mail.  The old spool directory can be set to read only so that it will empty over time and be removed.  A sample config would be:
#
<spool /var/spool/pmta-old>
  delete-file-holders true
  deliver-only true
</spool>
# 
 
When the production server is backup and online, new mail is redirected back to the production server, and the hot backup is left running until all mail has been delivered or bounced.  After the mail is gone from the hot backup, it is put back into its original single spool state, and is kept idle until the next time it is needed.

articles.subject: How do I configure a pool of IP addresses?
articles.body:
How do I configure a pool of IP addresses?

To set a pool of IP addresses, it is best to use a VirtualMTA pool.  You'll first create a set of VirtualMTAs, each with one IP address and the matching PTR record, and then you'll add the VirtualMTAs to the pool.  The setup would look similar to the following (replacing the IP addresses and host-names with your own):
#
#
<virtual-mta vmta1>
  smtp-source-host 192.168.0.11 mail1.yourserver.com
</virtual-mta>
<virtual-mta vmta2>
  smtp-source-host 192.168.0.12 mail2.yourserver.com
</virtual-mta>
<virtual-mta vmta3>
  smtp-source-host 192.168.0.13 mail3.yourserver.com
</virtual-mta>
 
<virtual-mta-pool vmtapool1>
  virtual-mta vmta1
  virtual-mta vmta2
  virtual-mta vmta3
</virtual-mta-pool>
#
#
 
Once this is setup, the only thing you'll need to determine is your VirtualMTA selection method.  This is covered in section 8.4 of the User's Guide but a few of your options include:
--by including a X-virtual-MTA header in the message
--by regular expression matching of the SMTP "MAIL FROM" address, "RCPT TO" address, or a message header.
--by configuring a default virtual mta on a <source> directive selected by the IP address and port in the PowerMTA machine that you connect to
--by configuring a default virtual mta on a <source> directive selected by the source IP address
 
If you need to you can list a VirtualMTA more than once to have it receive more mail than the rest of the VirtualMTAs.  For example, let’s say you have 4 VirtualMTAs in a pool, and vmta4 is no performing well.  You could lessen the amount of email it processes with the following:
#
<virtual-mta-pool myvmtas>
  virtual-mta vmta1
  virtual-mta vmta1
  virtual-mta vmta1
  virtual-mta vmta2
  virtual-mta vmta2
  virtual-mta vmta2
  virtual-mta vmta3
  virtual-mta vmta3
  virtual-mta vmta3
  virtual-mta vmta4
</virtual-mta-pool>
#
 
In the above case, vmtas 1-3 would each get 30% of the email, and vmta4 would get 10%.

articles.subject: How do I configure TLS with PowerMTA?
articles.body:
How do I configure TLS with PowerMTA?

To use opportunistic TLS on outbound, set the following:
#
<domain *>
  use-starttls yes
  require-starttls no
</domain>
#
 
If you want to enable encryption on inbound  these are the steps.  The certificate used in the global smtp-server-tls-certificate directive should be created using procedures found on http://www.openssl.org/.  Here some very basic instructions for creating the required certificate on Linux.  Let me know if this helps:
 
Generate a CA
1)    openssl req -out ca.pem -new -x509
        -generates CA file "ca.pem" and CA key "privkey.pem"
 
Generate server certificate/key pair
        - no password required.
2)    openssl genrsa -out server.key 1024
3)    openssl req -key server.key -new -out server.req
4)    openssl x509 -req -in server.req -CA CA.pem -CAkey privkey.pem -CAserial file.srl -out server.pem
        -contents of "file.srl" is a two digit number.  eg. "42"
               
...
Enter PEM pass phrase: YourPasswordHere
Verifying - Enter PEM pass phrase:
...
Country Name (2 letter code) [GB]:US
State or Province Name (full name) [Berkshire]:YourState
Locality Name (eg, city) [Newbury]:YourCity
Organization Name (eg, company) [My Company Ltd]:YourDomain.com
Organizational Unit Name (eg, section) []:
Common Name (eg, your name or your server's hostname) []:mail.YourDomain.com
Email Address []:
...
A challenge password []:
An optional company name []:
 
 
5)   cat server.pem server.key > smtp-cert.pem
6)   mv smtp-cert.pem /etc/pmta/
7)   To use inbound STARTTLS in PowerMTA the following directives need to be applied. Add the following globally to the PowerMTA config:
#
smtp-listener 1.2.3.4:465 tls=yes
smtp-server-tls-certificate /etc/pmta/smtp-cert.pem "YourPasswordHere"
smtp-server-tls-ciphers "HIGH:MEDIUM:!ADH:@STRENGTH"
 
<source 0/0>                 # matches all
    allow-starttls yes
    require-starttls-before-auth yes
    allow-unencrypted-plain-auth no
</source>
#
 
8) Reload PowerMTA
 
The smtp-listener directive sets the IP, Port, and the use of STARTTLS.  The file should have the following format:
 
-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
YOUR CERT HERE
-----END CERTIFICATE-----
-----BEGIN RSA PRIVATE KEY-----
Proc-Type: 4,ENCRYPTED
DEK-Info: DES-EDE3-CBC,EBA505536010547C
 
YOUR PRIVATE KEY HERE
-----END RSA PRIVATE KEY-----
 
 
Please see the User's Guide for additional information and let us know if you have any further questions.
 
 
<domain example.com>
     smtp-client-certificate /path/to/file password  
</domain>

articles.subject: How do I DKIM double sign?
articles.body:
How do I DKIM double sign?

We have added full support for 2 DKIM signatures on a message within PowerMTA starting in v4.0r14, available from http://download.port25.com .

All of the existing dkim-* directives now support the prefix "second", and which are used for the second signature (bottom most one) for the message.
We use the same domain-key directives for both signatures.  Here is the list of new directives used for the second DKIM signature:

second-dkim-add-body-limit
second-dkim-add-timestamp
second-dkim-algorithm
second-dkim-body-canon
second-dkim-expire-after
second-dkim-headers
second-dkim-headers-canon
second-dkim-identity
second-dkim-sign

and which are used just like their equivalent dkim-* directives. 

A configuration example is below which sends messages with both a customer signature and ESP signature, which are only to be applied to messages in virtualMTA 12345.  The customer signature is based on the domain of the
From: header (customerdomain.com) while the ESP signature is based on the second-dkim-identity option defined (espdomain.com).  PowerMTA would include gmail's required Feedback-ID header in both signatures for messages to gmail only. 

<virtual-mta 12345>
    domain-key esp,espdomain.com,c:\pmta\keys\esp.espdomain.com.pem
    domain-key
    customer,customerdomain.com,c:\pmta\keys\customer.customerdomain.com.pem
    <domain gmail.com>
       dkim-headers Feedback-ID
       second-dkim-headers Feedback-ID
    </domain>           
    <domain *>
       dkim-sign  yes
       second-dkim-sign  yes
       second-dkim-identity @espdomain.com
    </domain>          
</virtual-mta>

Note: The x-dkim-options header method is not supported for the second signature, but still can be used for the first signature.

PowerMTA will still deliver the message if due to message attributes and config settings, there are no signatures to be applied, only one signature to be applied or both signatures are to be applied.

This is only available starting in v4.0r14.

articles.subject: How do I find the PowerMTA User Guide?
articles.body:
How do I find the PowerMTA User Guide?

The documentation is always included with the product and can be found in /usr/share/doc/pmta/ on Linux, and in \pmta\doc on Windows.  Also, you can find a copy at the download URL https://download.port25.com.

articles.subject: How do I get Sender-ID and SPF working with PowerMTA?
articles.body:
How do I get Sender-ID and SPF working with PowerMTA? 

Sender-ID and SPF are configured outside of PowerMTA, and it is a setup that we typically do not have to get involved with when working with PowerMTA.  The setup itself is usually quite straight forward, involving your DNS records and some mail formatting.  It is best to use the wizard available at Microsoft's site here:
http://www.microsoft.com/mscorp/safety/content/technologies/senderid/wizard/
 
These will provide you with the step by step instructions to properly configure the records to best suit your needs.
 
You can also find more information here:
http://www.openspf.org/Forums
 
Or Microsoft's Sender-ID site here:
http://www.microsoft.com/mscorp/safety/technologies/senderid/default.mspx
 
Once you have set your DNS records in compliance with the above sites, you can use our automated testing tool, send a sample of a marketing email or newsletter to get the summary results. Senders can choose where the results should be sent:
-If you wish to receive the results at the address in the "mail_from," the sample message should be sent to check-auth@verifier.port25.com.
-If you wish to receive the results at the address in the "from" header, the sample message should be sent to check-auth2@verifier.port25.com.
-If you wish to receive the results at a different address from one of the addresses above, the address need to be added to the check-auth address. For example, to send the results to:
    jsmith@yourdomain.com
the sample message should be sent to
    check-auth-jsmith=yourdomain.com@verifier.port25.com.

articles.subject: How do I move PowerMTA from one server to another?
articles.body:
How do I move PowerMTA from one server to another?

Assuming that PowerMTA is installed on the other machine, and the PowerMTA config file is the same on both machines, specifically with the VirtualMTA names, all you need to do is stop the service on both servers, move the spool files, config file, and license over, and start PowerMTA on the new server.
 
You need to make sure that the new PowerMTA machine has the same exact VirtualMTAs defined that are in the other PowerMTA installation, (the config settings for the vmtas can be different but the VirtualMTA names *must be the same*) otherwise,  PowerMTA will bounce messages out of the queue that it finds whose VirtualMTA no longer exists.  For example, if messages were queued for vmta46 on machine 1, and which you then move the queue to machine 2, if vmta46 is not defined in the config file on machine 2, these messages will bounce out of the queue on the restart, since there is no vmta46 on machine 2 to handle these messages.

articles.subject: How do I set the inbound connections limit?
articles.body:
How do I set the inbound connections limit?

PowerMTA has a default inbound limit of 100 connections.  Feel free to change this amount with the unpublished global directive "total-max-smtp-in".  Inbound and outbound connections effect CPU usage, and if this directive were set too high it could result in high CPU usage, and that is why it is unpublished.  You should be able to get away with a setting around 200 without issue.  This would be done with the following:
#
total-max-smtp-in 200
#

articles.subject: How do I set the outbound connections limit?
articles.body:
How do I set the outbound connections limit?

PowerMTA has a default outbound limit of 1200 connections.  This cap can be raised with the unpublished global directive "total-max-smtp-out" directive.  This directive is unpublished because connections are directly related to CPU usage, and raising this to high may cause unwanted CPU load.  If you are going to raise the connections, I would recommend doing it incrementally and keeping an eye on the CPU usage during this time.  As long as the CPU usage stays under 100%, you should be fine.  To raise the limit to 1500, you would put the following in your configuration file:
#
#
total-max-smtp-out 1500
#
#

articles.subject: How do I setup DomainKeys?
articles.body:
How do I setup DomainKeys?

DomainKeys
Instructions on the setup of DomainKey records and signing can be found in section 10.4 of the User's Guide, and you can use our DomainKey Wizard for additional assistance in key creation.  The wizard can be found here:
http://www.port25.com/support/domainkeysdkim-wizard/
 
If you are using our wizard, you'll need to enter the TXT record into your DNS record for the public key as outlined in the wizard, and then save the private key to the PowerMTA server.  From there, start at step 11 in section 10.4.2 to configure PowerMTA, and there are only a few things that need to be added to PowerMTA.  First you'll need to define the domain-key directive.  This directive specifies the DomainKey selector, the domain that your "from" address header should match, and the private key.  Second you'll have to define those domains for which you want to sign messages.  The setup will look similar to the following:
#
#
domain-key key1,somedomain.com,C:\pmta\key1.somedomain.com.pem
<domain yahoo.com>
  dk-sign yes
</domain>
<domain gmail.com>
  dk-sign yes
</domain>
<domain verifier.port25.com>
  dk-sign yes
  dkim-sign yes
</domain>
#
#
 
To use our automated testing tool, send a sample of a marketing email or newsletter to get the summary results. Senders can choose where the results should be sent:
-If you wish to receive the results at the address in the "mail_from," the sample message should be sent to check-auth@verifier.port25.com.
-If you wish to receive the results at the address in the "from" header, the sample message should be sent to check-auth2@verifier.port25.com.
-If you wish to receive the results at a different address from one of the addresses above, the address need to be added to the check-auth address. For example, to send the results to:
    jsmith@yourdomain.com
the sample message should be sent to
    check-auth-jsmith=yourdomain.com@verifier.port25.com.

articles.subject: How do I track with an outbound TLS connection has been successful?
articles.body:
How do I track with an outbound TLS connection has been successful?

We currently have no method of easily tracking (e.g. in the acct file) if a connection successfully used TLS.  It is something we are looking to add in the next major release due out later this year.  For now, you can assume that if the below settings are in place and the acct file field "dlvEsmtpAvailable" shows STARTTLS that the email was sent over an encrypted channel.
 
Keep in mind that by default require-starttls is set to true, so what you really need is:
#
<domain *>
  use-starttls true
  require-starttls false
  log-tls true
</domain>
#
 
Without setting require-starttls to false messages will bounce if no encryption is available.
 
For testing, simply run a command similar to the following:
 
pmta trace port25.com
 
You should see a line like:
2014-06-19 10:12:30 tls:TLSv1.2 connected with 256-bit DHE-RSA-AES256-GCM-SHA384
 
This indicates the connection was encrypted.

articles.subject: Is it possible to issue a license without a MAC address?
articles.body:
Is it possible to issue a license without a MAC address?

As we have not yet released 4.5, we don’t have our final plans in place for how we are going to handle issues for license needs during non-business hours, but we are working to develop a solution that works well for our customers. 
 
We currently have no plans to offer a PowerMTA 4.5 license without requiring a MAC address.  If there are concerns around redundancy and ensuring that in the event of a server failure a new license can be obtained, we offer a hot backup license.  This license allows for a second server to be sitting idle that is ready to go in the event the primary server goes offline.  In general, most customers who are concerned about redundancy usually run at least two full production instances of PowerMTA.

articles.subject: Is it possible to use DMARC with PowerMTA?
articles.body:
Is it possible to use DMARC with PowerMTA?

As far as our reading of the current draft (and some here closely following the list discussion), these are just additional text records in DNS related to an existing SPF and DKIM implementation (and a sender's policy when a mismatch occurs), so there does not appear to be anything new that touches the sending mail server (outside of having the mail server support DKIM of course).  We are looking at the possibility of parsing the inbound data sent from the gateways like gmail that support this, however that remains to be seen right now, depending on demand.  If you believe that there is something more to it, and that touches PowerMTA, please let us know what you are thinking of course, and will definitely give it serious consideration.

articles.subject: I've been having DNS issues with PowerMTA, is there any known issues?
articles.body:
I've been having DNS issues with PowerMTA, is there any known issues?

The only time we see DNS issues are when the customers DNS cannot keep up with PowerMTA.  As a temporary fix, try adding the following http://www.opendns.com servers to your config file and let me know if this resolves the issue.  Keep in mind, this is a free service, so for higher volumes you may need to use their paid service.
#
name-server 208.67.222.222
name-server 208.67.220.220
#
 
The directives are global, and a reload should take the change.  If this resolves the issue, you may want to look into getting a faster/dedicated DNS server, like bind.

articles.subject: I've been having issues with a Windows 2008 install, how can I troubleshoot it?
articles.body:
I've been having issues with a Windows 2008 install, how can I troubleshoot it?

When you did the install did you run the install as an administrator?  Can you try to run the repair again, but this do the following:
 
Open a command prompt as an administrator (right click and select run as administrator)
Run the PMC MSI from within this window
select repair when prompted

articles.subject: I've been having PMC issues, how do I troubleshoot it?
articles.body:
I've been having PMC issues, how do I troubleshoot it?

What version of PMC are you running?  What version of PowerMTA?  It would be helpful to see the PMC Diagnostics.
 
Log into PMC.
Click Support.
Click "Gather Diagnostics" for the PMC.
Fill out form and click "Send to Support".
 
Also, when convenient, can you compress and send over the following logs;

articles.subject: What are the mail merge rules within PowerMTA?
articles.body:
What are the mail merge rules within PowerMTA?

There is an RFC limit to 1000 characters per line.  Mail merge fields are limited to < 998 bytes, if your fields need more space, you need to break them down to multiple fields.  Mail merge does not look at where you use the fields.
 
Use one backslash to escape the quotes.
Example:
        "Jimmy "Jay""
becomes
        "Jimmy \"Jay\""
(The enclosing quotes are needed because the variable has white space.)
 
If you need a backslash in the field, add another one to quote it:
        back\slash
becomes
        back\\slash
 
If you have spaces or tabs in the field, you need to put it in quotes.
 
The [ needs to be escaped by adding another [, so [ becomes [[ unless, of course, it is meant as a mail merge field.
Example
        Dear [name], here are braces: ([{ )]}
becomes
        Dear [name], here are braces: ([[{ )]}
(Assuming a merge variable called name.)
 
There can be no line breaks \n or \r in the fields; you need to use parts if you need multiple lines.
 
Nested merge fields are not supported.  For example:
XDFN v1="100"
XDFN v2="200"
XDFN v3="http://www.example.com/[v1]/[v2]"
